SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate as a States House expresses its grave concern-
(a) at the continued failure of the Tonkin Liberal Government in South Australia to honour its 1979 Election promise to provide increased employment opportunities for unemployed persons;

(b) that both the Australian Bureau of Statistics and the Commonwealth Employment Service unemployment figures for January 1981 show that South Australia continues to have the highest number of unemployed persons in Australia;
(c) that the ABS unemployment figures for January 1981 show an increase of 1,900 from January 1980;
(d) that the CES unemployment figures for January 1981 show an increase of 4,410 since January 1980;
(e) that in percentage terms ABS figures show that 8.2 per cent of South Australians are unemployed and CES figures show that 8.8 per cent are unemployed; and
(f) that due to lack of employment opportunity South Australians are leaving the State in alarming numbers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer the Minister to published reports in recent weeks which suggest that the Government is planning to push through the Parliament as much legislation as possible before it loses control of the Senate in July. I refer the Minister to frequent rhetoric in this place from Government Ministers about the role of the Senate as a House of review. Will the Minister give an assurance that proper time will be given for study of and debate on all legislation which comes into the Parliament prior to June? Does he agree that it would be totally against the public interest if the Government used its temporary majority in this place to force through legislation designed to benefit particular friends and vested interests, notably by means of changes to the broadcasting and television legislation and to the two-airline agreement?

—Nobody, in the interests of entertainment, would ever want to stop and limit the time for such rhetoric, however melodramatic it may be. So the answer is quite clear. In that regard, and in that regard alone, Senator Button will not be frustrated. It is not true that the Government is planning to push through an undue amount of legislation because of some change in numbers after 1 July. I take it--
—That is a euphemism-'some change in numbers'.

—Mr President, the Australian Labor Party itself will not command the numbers in the Senate, and therefore I take it that the Labor Party will perform according to its numbers. The fact is that the Government has been given a mandate. It will put through the legislation for which it was given a mandate through the ballot box. I have no doubt at all that the Labor Party will co-operate in putting it through. Indeed, from time to time it has said that it would not resist legislation for which the Government had a mandate. As to full time to consider legislation, I am arranging that the Labor Party, through its Whips and through its Leader, will be fully informed, as it has been in recent sessions, of the intentions of the Government. The Labor Party will be invited to work with us to ensure that the whole of the business of the Senate is put through in an orderly fashion. Mr President, Senator Button talks about bringing in legislation for vested interests. The only vested interests that we will legislate for are those for which the ballot box gave a mandate last October and for which last Saturday we were given a renewed mandate.
—I ask a supplementary question. What mandate arising from the last Federal election does the Government have in relation to changes to the broadcasting legislation or the two-airline agreement?
—I suggest that hypothetical questions need to await any changes, real or hypothetical, that may emerge in the future.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Transport inform the Senate whether the Federal Government recently undertook an experiment which proved that private contractors could do road construction work for about one-third less than it would cost with normal day labour supplied by the Department of Main Roads? If so, was it envisaged that the Department of Main Roads also should tender for the work? Again, if this is so, who would be responsible for the final acceptance of a tender? What has been the response of the various State governments to the Federal Government's suggestion that private contractors be allowed to tender for the construction of national roads?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware at this stage of any recent Commonwealth Government studies specifically directed towards comparing the relative costs of undertaking road construction work through private contractors with the cost of day labour forces employed by the State road authorities. It is possible, however, that this issue was touched upon in the context of earlier studies relating to the construction industry. I will follow up this matter for the honourable senator and see whether I can get some further information for her.

ANSWER.PARA: I might observe, though, that there seem to be considerable difficulties in seeking to draw generalised conclusions about the relative efficiencies of the two methods. The situation would obviously vary between individual projects and according to the capabilities of individual contractors. It is, however, for this very reason that the Commonwealth Government believes that in order to obtain value for money in road construction competitive forces should apply. Accordingly, the Government has announced its intention to amend the legislation so that grants to the States and the Northern Territory for national roads can be made conditional upon the application of open tender negotiations. It is envisaged that State road authorities would be able to tender for work. However, detailed administrative arrangements have not yet been worked out. The views of the States are that whilst most of them are already making considerable use of contractors on national road works, they would wish to retain the discretion as to the works which would be undertaken by contractors.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Has the Government expressed or will it express a view on the present situation in Central America and in particular on President Reagan's expressed view that the United States will do what it can to maintain the present Government in El Salvador and on the United States Government's intention to withdraw aid from Nicaragua because of its differences with that country's government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I would need to refer the question asked by Senator Grimes to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. The Government has seen reports with regard to some of the matters raised by him but I am unable to give any explicit information. I will refer the question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and seek an early response.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. The Minister will no doubt be aware of the aid impasse between the governments of Vanuatu and France resulting in massive problems to this new nation, including an urgent need to recruit teachers to go to Vanuatu. I ask: Has the Government responded to Father Walter Lini's request to the Australian Government for financial assistance to help Australia fulfil a much needed commitment to its close newly independent neighbour at a time of dire need?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Government has been actively studying the needs of Vanuatu following its achievement of independence. I think it is known that we have pledged the sum of $12.5m over three years to assist Vanuatu. The Government will consider any request addressed to Australia for additional assistance. I note the mention of teachers by Senator Watson. I will refer his question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I give the assurance that Australia would consider any requests that were made for additional assistance. As I have said, we have already pledged a certain sum to that country.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is it a fact that the Government intends to cut back staffing arrangements in regional offices of the Australian Taxation Office throughout Australia? Is it proposed to reclassify the position of manager at these offices and also to withdraw tax investigators?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am not aware of any of the matters relating to staffing arrangements stated in the question asked by Senator Primmer. I will refer them to the Treasurer for his response. I have not heard of any change in attitude with regard to reclassification of positions or the withdrawal of tax investigators. They are matters that can be properly addressed to the Treasurer. I will seek an early response.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Defence to an article which appeared in Newsweek of 16 February 1981. It states:

QUESTION.PARA: Truong Nhu Tang, a high-ranking Vietnamese defector now in Paris, says the Soviet Union is building piers and other facilities to service nuclear submarines at a former US supply base in Vietnam. Tang is a former justice minister in Vietnam's Communist Regime. Pentagon sources maintain there is no evidence to support his story, but foreign intelligence agents say they have been told that US satellite photos have confirmed Tang's report of nuclear construction at Cam Ranh Bay. Such an installation would facilitate a Soviet presence in the Indian Ocean.
I ask the Minister: Is this report correct? If so, what threat does such an installation pose to Australia?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the report to which Senator Bonner referred nor am I aware of this matter. I will refer the question to the Minister for Defence and ask him to provide an early answer.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: APPROPRIATION FOR ABORIGINES IN THE NORTHERN TERRITORY

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cavanagh Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I refer to the Minister's letter to me dated 23 January 1981, which was the subject of questions raised yesterday, in reply to my question on whether Aboriginal welfare money was used to build airstrips in the Northern Territory for a bankrupt private airline company. The amount appropriated by the Parliament was $3,042,000. The explanatory notes of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs stated:

QUESTION.PARA: The item provides for the expenses involved in the support of Aboriginal and other organizations who supply welfare services to Aboriginals which are not, or cannot be, effectively provided by Government agencies.

These organizations concentrate specifically on the problems of juvenile delinquency, child neglect, malnutrition and other social problems (particularly those related to alcoholism) and provide general advisory services.

I seek the Minister's assurance that the amount of $286,000 which was allocated to the Northern Territory, as stated in his letter, was spent fully in accordance with the reasons given for parliamentary approval. In his letter the Minister stated that he was unable to assure me that the moneys have not been used to upgrade airstrips in the Northern Territory. Is it correct that some or all of the $2,756,000 unaccounted for in the Minister's letter which was intended for use in areas outside the Northern Territory and for Aboriginal welfare, including preventing malnutrition, may have been used for airstrips in the Northern Territory?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to a series of questions from Senator Cavanagh and Senator Ryan yesterday on the possible use of Commonwealth funds for the renovation of airstrips in the Northern Territory, I said that I would seek further information from my Department on the situation. I can inform the Senate that none of the funds appropriated for the benefit of Aboriginal communities under the item to which Senator Cavanagh has referred has been spent on the renovation of airstrips. The money appropriated was not and is not under the control of the Northern Territory Government. I think I made that clear in my letter to the honourable senator.

ANSWER.PARA: Prior to the Northern Territory Government's assuming responsibility for essential services, the Department did from time to time provide funds for Aboriginal communities to upgrade airstrips. I refer to the situation of out-stations where many of the strips were bush strips and had to be renewed after each wet. No moneys have been appropriated by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs in 1980-81 for the upgrading of such airstrips in the Northern Territory.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now you can assure us?
—I now can assure the Senate of that.

—Will the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs ask the Minister to instruct his Department to ensure that the unemployment statistics which are published quarterly are dissected in order to show the following categories of the unemployed: Firstly, those under 21 years of age; secondly, those without dependants; and thirdly, sole breadwinners with dependants, and other categories so that a more factual picture of the unemployed can be highlighted and analysed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will refer the question to the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs. I think the Senate is aware of the release of figures by the Australian Bureau of Statistics and the Commonwealth Employment Service. As to the categories that have been referred to, I am not aware that details are readily available in the present statistics that are gathered, but I will seek from the Minister the information that has been requested and see that the Senate is advised.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CENTRAL INTELLIGENCE AGENCY ACTIVITIES IN AUSTRALIA

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate as a matter of policy, although it may also concern the Attorney-General since it relates to allegations of illegal activities in this country by the United States Central Intelligence Agency. By way of preface I will say that the Australian Democrats are not at this time bringing into question the desirability of the Pine Gap installation, its uses or relevance to the defence requirements of the United States or Australia. That understood, I ask the Minister: Following allegations of illegal activity in Australia by the CIA through its use of the Nugan Hand Bank, including association with criminals and drug trafficking, has the Government made it plain to the Government of the United States that illegal acts of this kind in Australia cannot be tolerated? If the Government has not taken this action, why has it not done so? When will it do so? Can the Minister give an assurance to the Senate that any such illegal activities by the CIA in Australia will be investigated and treated by our law enforcement agencies in the same way as any other crime? In view of considerable public disquiet that the CIA-controlled installation at Pine Gap may now replace the Nugan Hand Bank as the centre for CIA activities, will the Government consider the case of Radio Free Europe in Munich which some years ago was removed from CIA control and placed under more responsible supervision? Since Pine Gap does operate on Australian soil and our Government is supposed to have some control over it, will the Government discuss with the Government of the United States the desirability of Pine Gap also being removed from the control of the CIA and placed under a more responsible agency?

—I think there is some possible overlap in the responsibility of Ministers in this matter. I take it that the Attorney-General may wish to add to it. The first of two things I want to say is that as far as I know our Government has no information of any illegal activities by the CIA in Australia. There may be allegations, but as far as I know there is no information as to them at all. Secondly, I want to make it clear that no illegal activities, whether by an Australian national or a foreign person, in Australia would be tolerated by this Government. Senator Mason would acknowledge that. Having said that, the substance of the series of questions is such that I think I should refer the whole of the question to the Prime Minister for consideration.

—My question which is addressed to the Attorney-General relates to victim compensation programs within Australia and in particular to the present situation whereby the Commonwealth and the Australian Capital Territory are the only jurisdictions in the country without a government program designed to provide compensation to the innocent victims of violent crime. Will the Attorney-General inform the Senate why a victim compensation scheme has yet to be established in either jurisdiction? Does the Attorney-General agree that, for a combination of practical and humanitarian reasons, there is sufficient justification and need for an official compensation program in the Australian Capital Territory and in the Commonwealth? If so, what discussions and research are currently being conducted by the Government or government agencies into the desirability of introducing such a program? Has consideration been given by them to the Australian Law Reform Commission's proposal to have a tribunal, constituted by a member of the Commonwealth Employees Compensation Tribunal, with a right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, to perform the claims function?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that the Commonwealth and the Australian Capital Territory are the only jurisdictions in Australia without a government program providing for compensation to the victims of crime. That has been a matter of concern to me since I became Attorney-General. I refer Senator Missen to the statement I issued on 22 August 1979 in which I announced that the Government had approved the preparation of legislation to establish a criminal injuries compensation scheme for the Australian Capital Territory. That legislation was to provide compensation for the type of situation that Senator Missen correctly identifies as existing in the States. The scheme, as approved, will provide that the Commonwealth will be liable to pay amounts up to $7,500 in compensation. That figure was based upon the amounts provided for in other schemes operating at the time. The scheme that I then approved was that where proceedings had taken place the court should determine the amount to be awarded by way of compensation. In other cases the award was to be made by the Registrar of the Supreme Court.

ANSWER.PARA: The matter has been referred to the Legislative Drafting Division of my Department for the preparation of an ordinance for the ACT. I am advised that that ordinance has reached an advanced stage of preparation, and I am hoping that the legislation will be brought into force later this year. I think I should say that in view of the delay that has occurred I will look again, at the more appropriate time, at the amounts because they may well have changed since 1979. That is the situation in relation to the ACT. The nature of Federal legislation generally is such that the possibility of a victim suffering personal injury from a breach of a Federal law is remote. Therefore, we had not considered the extension of the scheme to Federal law generally. The obvious need was that in the ACT the general criminal laws should deal, as they do in the States, with the likelihood of criminal breaches resulting in injuries. However, as Senator Missen has raised that question again, I will give it further consideration before the ordinance is finalised.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CENTRAL INTELLIGENCE AGENCY ACTIVITIES IN AUSTRALIA

TALK.START.PARA: —Further to the question asked by Senator Mason and the answer given by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, my question relates to the imminent departure of Mr Michael Sidnaoui, Central Intelligence Agency chief of station in Canberra, as reported in Sunday's Sun-Herald newspaper. The Government must be aware of the collapse of the CIA-controlled Nugan Hand merchant bank and its well established links with drugs, arms dealings and the illegal movement of large sums of moneys. Is the Government aware of the imminent departure of Mr Sidnaoui? If so, does it intend to question him before he leaves Australia about his Nugan Hand activities or does the Government still believe that the CIA operates here in Australia's interests?

—Senator Melzer has made unqualified statements that she is aware of Central Intelligence Agency links with the Nugan Hand bank and of particular activities of the Nugan Hand bank. If, indeed, she has any evidence of CIA links with the Nugan Hand bank or any evidence at all of illegal activities engaged in by that bank, I invite her to come forward and tell the law officers. I think governments, both State and Federal, are seeking information regarding such illegal activities. I am not aware of a person, named or otherwise, who might be regarded as the head of the CIA in Australia. I am therefore not aware that any such person is departing. I will refer the substance of the question to the Prime Minister.
—Rip Van Winkle.

—I again invite Senator Cavanagh to give us specific details-but not inside this Parliament; outside the Parliament-of who this person is and how he knows that this person is a member of the CIA and has acted illegally. I think it is easy to make such claims in this Parliament by innuendo. I am not aware of what Senator Melzer alleges but I invite her to give us whatever evidence she can. I will refer the remainder of her question to the Prime Minister because the facts are not available to me.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Education. I refer to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts relating to children's television. Has the Minister seen newspaper reports concerning the establishment of a Children's Television Foundation by the Australian Education Council? Does this move by the Council imply that the Government has accepted in part recommendations 6 and 14 of the Senate Committee's report which urges the establishment of an independent programming body and calls for greater attention to be given to research in this field? As the governments of Victoria and New South Wales have agreed to share in the initial costs of this Foundation, what are the Commonwealth's plans in relation to its contribution in terms of money and time? Does the Minister know whether the results of the work of this Foundation will be supplied to Queensland, which is reported to have declined to join the scheme?

—Senator Davidson has asked me a number of questions. I fully understand this because he was the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts which inquired into the impact of television on the development and learning behaviour of children, I think in 1978 and thereafter. My understanding is that the Australian Education Council at its meeting last week supported the establishment of the Children's Television Foundation and agreed to establish a steering committee with a view to creating the Foundation. Without refreshing my memory, I imagine that recommendations 6 and 14 form a parallel with the establishment of that Foundation. A decision on the contribution which the Commonwealth may make to the Foundation will be based on a consideration of the steering committee's report. I cannot comment on the final or penultimate question relating to the sharing of moneys. I will refer those questions to the Minister, Mr Fife, and perhaps to the Prime Minister.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs. Is it a fact that Commonwealth Employment Service job interview cards are sent to unemployment beneficiaries unenveloped for all to see? I raise this question because I have received a letter from a country resident in Tasmania who said:

QUESTION.PARA: As it is my personal mail I do not think I am asking too much for the card to be enclosed in an envelope, not even a Miss, Mrs or Ms, I am not young therefore it is humiliating.
She goes on to state:
In these country towns people always gossip.

In fact in this case, the roadside mail deliverers' passengers happen to be very good gossips. Is it not possible for the Minister to raise with her colleague the suggestion that all communications from the CES to unemployment beneficiaries and those registered for employment be sent in envelopes? Otherwise, as this lady says:
It may as well be over the radio then everyone would know, the odds are about the same now.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine raises a valid point, I think, with regard to the privacy of mail that goes to any person seeking a government service. I will certainly refer the matter to the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs and draw his attention to the disadvantages that exist for a person who receives mail without a covering envelope. I will see what his response is in relation to this matter and whether any valid reasons may be advanced that would prevent a change to something that would give the privacy of mail which I think everyone would expect from government.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: INDUSTRIES ASSISTANCE COMMISSION: INQUIRY INTO IMPORTED CANNED HAM

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs. Can the Minister advise when the report of the Industries Assistance Commission inquiry into imported canned ham will be handed down? Secondly, can the Minister particularly request that consideration be given to the effect that expected imports of up to 30 per cent of the total Australian market will have on pig raisers, feed growers and producers, can makers, bacon producers, meat workers and many other people? Thirdly, is it reasonable still to consider Romania and Yugoslavia as developing countries for the purpose of receiving export benefits on such sales to Australia?

—I have no information as to when the report from the Industries Assistance Commission will be handed down and no information, therefore, on the particularities that Senator Archer seeks in regard to the employment situation and the general state of the industry. With regard to the dumping complaint about canned ham from Romania and Yugoslavia, I understand this was made on 20 August last year. The departmental inquiries have now been completed and consultations have been held with the Romanian and Yugoslavian governments. Voluntary price undertakings by the exporters in Romania and Yugoslavia not to export canned ham to Australia at prices below assessed normal values have been accepted by those Governments. The investigation has therefore been suspended on the basis of those undertakings by those exporting nations.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry whether it is a fact that at a recent meeting of the Australian Agricultural Council it was agreed that a plant variety rights scheme for Australia be introduced by way of national legislation during this autumn session of Parliament. If so, will the Government guarantee that any such Bill will lie on the table for at least six months to enable the fullest public discussion on this topic? The discussion has so far been conducted heatedly but in the absence of a concrete proposal.
—I will refer that question to the Minister for Primary Industry, including the request for the consideration the honourable senator sought.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry advise the Senate of the latest position regarding Government policy on the dairy industry and underwriting arrangements in light of the claims that have been made about falling milk production in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some information from the Minister for Primary Industry on that matter. I am advised that he is aware of claims within the dairy industry that if milk production continues to decline at the rate it has in recent years, Australia may reach a position where insufficient milk is available to meet total domestic demand for milk and dairy products. It is the Government's policy, and has been for some time, to maintain a viable dairy industry in Australia directed primarily towards supplying domestic market needs with an export capability. Exports to remunerative markets are needed as a buffer to ensure adequate supplies of dairy products for the domestic market.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has, in fact, assisted the industry towards this end by providing a greater degree of certainty and stability through legislative backing for its marketing arrangements and by underwriting returns for prescribed products. The Government has sought the views of the industry regarding a longer term domestic pricing and underwriting arrangement which links domestic pricing to trends in Australia's export returns and aims to protect farmers from unexpected and sharp falls in market returns without masking the underlying long term market trends. The Government hopes that a new scheme will be agreed upon in time to operate from 1 July this year. With greater stability in returns and the considerably improved market outlook, the Minister is of the view that the right production response should be forthcoming from the industry and that the Government's basic aim, as expressed, will be achieved.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister for Finance refers to her ministerial responsibility for the Royal Australian Mint. During the recent disgraceful chaos surrounding the issuance or non-issuance of the $200 gold coin, did she tell people who complained about the non-delivery of their coins that responsibility rested with the Treasurer and not with herself? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The plain fact is that the Mint is the responsibility of the Treasurer; it is not the responsibility of the Minister for Finance. The Treasurer has made certain statements with regard to gold coinage. If there is specific information that Senator Walsh seeks, I will see that it is provided to him.

—I ask a supplementary question. Can the Minister explain why the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette-admittedly when Mr Robinson was the Minister for Finance last year-listed as an organisation included under the heading 'Minister for Finance' the Royal Australian Mint? Inquiry via the Parliamentary Library yesterday confirmed that there had been no change to that arrangement.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will seek information on the changes that were made and see that Senator Walsh and the Parliamentary Library are advised. If Senator Walsh makes any specific requests for information on gold coinage I will see that the Treasurer is advised. If the honourable senator provides some information as to what it is that is disturbing him, instead of talking in somewhat abusive terms about chaos, we will see that he is advised accordingly.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications on a subject that has been raised here on many occasions. Can the Minister say when the people in the Streaky Bay area of South Australia will be able to receive a television service from the earth satellite station that I understand is currently being installed? QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEATH OF MR FRANK NUGAN: INVESTIGATIONS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General, firstly because he is a senior member of the Government and, secondly, because he is the chief law officer of the Commonwealth. I ask: Has the Government given any consideration to recent reports in the Australian Press relating to the circumstances surrounding the death of Mr Frank Nugan? Has the Federal Government and/or the Australian Federal Police or any other Federal agency any information indicating that Mr Nugan's death may have been other than suicide? Does the Government intend to instruct the Federal Police or any other agency to provide any information on the circumstances of the death to the current coronial inquiry being conducted by Mr Walsh in New South Wales? If so, can the Minister state when such information will be placed before the inquiry?

—The responsibility for the investigation of the circumstances of the death referred to by Senator Gietzelt is clearly one for the New South Wales Government, the police and the laws of that State. The Federal Government has been concerned about the activities of the Nugan Hand Bank because, of course, they may involve, in the light of some allegations, breaches of various Federal laws. We have arranged with the New South Wales Government for a task force of Federal and State police to investigate those matters so far as they may be in breach of Commonwealth laws as well as State laws. That task force investigation has been under way for some time. As I understand it, the specific matters to which Senator Gietzelt's question refers would be within New South Wales law. However, if there are some aspects of them that may involve any breach of Commonwealth law, obviously the task force will be available to consider them. —Is the Minister representing the Prime Minister aware of recent problems faced and industrial action taken by the officers of the Australian Coastal Surveillance Centre because officers of the centre are required to work 40 hours a week compared with similar Commonwealth employees whose working week is considerably shorter? Can the Minister say what action is being taken to overcome these problems, particularly to provide equitable working conditions for these officers? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly the Government is aware, and my brief indicates awareness, of recent industrial action taken by certain staff of the Australian Coastal Surveillance Centre. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Wheeldon Sen The Hon J.M.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

I think a very honest attempt is being made to look at what could be the great benefits to all States from the capacity to interchange and to use different times of peak and base loads. If I have any later information on the grid I will let Senator Rae know.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister representing the Minister for Health may remember that on 2 December last year I asked him a question concerning the safety standards of sunbeds used in suntanning clinics. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

—I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister put those specific questions to the Minister for Transport, as I hope we may have an early answer in the Senate.
—Yes.

—Mr President, my question might best be directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence or to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, so can I play it safe and direct it to the Minister representing the Prime Minister? My question follows an answer which I received from the Minister for Defence to the effect that the chemicals 2,4,5-T and 2,4-D were tested on Queensland railway property at Redlynch and at Freshwater, 10 miles north of Cairns, in 1968 and in 1969. In view of the now widespread concern at the possible physical and genetic effects of the use of agent orange, have any medical checks been carried out on the personnel who conducted the experiment or on railway workers and nearby north Queensland residents?

—I am not aware of that particular chemical test being conducted at that time. Certainly, the information will be brought to the attention of those who are investigating the agent orange problem. The Government is keen that anybody who has information relating to this matter, or who feels that he has experienced some exposure to the chemicals, should come forward. I think the best thing for me to do is to invite the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Messner, to take note of this question and to consider extending an invitation to such people to come forward. —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Has progress been made in recent months towards a peaceful settlement of the Namibia question? Does Australia's offer to provide troops for a United Nations peacekeeping force still stand?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I understand that the latest round of negotiations on the United Nations plan for a settlement of the Namibia dispute took place in Geneva in January. The meeting, which was convened by the United Nations Secretary-General, was attended by South Africa, the South West Africa People's Organisation, the front line states, representatives of the western contact group and observers from the Organisation of African Unity, Nigeria and the Council for Namibia. It was hoped that the meeting would smooth out the remaining obstacles in the way of the implementation of the United Nations plan. Unfortunately, largely due to the attitude of the South African Government and those political parties in Namibia which support its position, the meeting was adjourned without reaching agreement.

ANSWER.PARA: The failure of this meeting was a matter of considerable regret to the Government. It is our hope nonetheless that those involved in the negotiating process will continue their efforts to arrive at acceptable terms for a settlement and spare Namibia the prospect of an increasingly bitter and protracted guerrilla war. Australia remains ready to contribute a military engineering contingent to the United Nations Transition Assistance Group which will have the responsibility for supervising the ceasefire in Namibia and arranging elections.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. In view of the recommendations made by the Minister, the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council and the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources that hydrocarbon plants be given a high priority and emphasis in future research, can the Minister tell the Senate why an application in May 1980 by the South Australian Institute of Technology for a grant of $140,500 over three years was refused? The Institute aims to develop efficient methods for recovery of hydrocarbons from plants, initially from the cotton bush. As the South Australian Government and the Shell Co. of Australia Ltd have considered the project of sufficient importance to fund it to this stage, I ask the Minister whether he is acquainted with the work being done by the Institute, on what grounds the support grant was refused and whether he will again review the application.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

It was set up to consider the whole range of research activities into alternative energy sources and to make recommendations upon application. The Minister, in this case me, receives the recommendations from NERDDC either by way of an affirmative, to go ahead, or a recommendation that it has looked at the application and has declined it.

I will look at the question and see whether there is available a reason advanced by NERDDC for it declining that application. I will let Senator Elstob know the outcome.

I am aware of the work that the institute undertakes in a wide range of matters. In Australia we undertake research into biomass, that is, the production of hydrocarbons from a variety of agricultural matters. I will look at the work that has been done by SAIT. In response to a question I mentioned that the total amount of moneys made available by the Commonwealth Government for salinity control was $4.5m. I have been advised that the more up-to-date figure is $6m. I correct the information which I gave yesterday.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

I am advised that the transfer of the Mint to the Department of the Treasury was reflected in the Administrative Arrangements Order published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette on 3 November 1980.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Button proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The lack of Government planning for the resources boom.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition raises the question of the lack of government planning for the resources boom as a matter of public importance not in a spirit of partisan hostility but rather to draw attention to some aspects of the much discussed resources boom which have been overlooked and which should no longer be overlooked by governments. The energy resource boom is now upon us. It has been talked about for a long time. It has been talked about by Liberal-National Country Party Ministers, firstly, as an alibi for consistent failure to deal with unemployment problems in the Australian manufacturing industry and, secondly, as an alibi for failure to deal with the problems of the manufacturing industry in general. 'Stick to it for a while', the unemployed of Australia are told; nirvana is around the corner and everything will be all right at some undefined period in the future. It is, of course, cold comfort to those people who are unemployed in the metropolitan areas of Australia. There is an awful gap between the dream of the benefits of the resources boom and the actual reality for those who are currently unemployed and for those who hope in the future to be beneficiaries of that resources boom.

SPEECH.PARA: The resources boom has been talked about in terms of breathless exaggeration by people such as Sir Phillip Lynch reeling off figures of intoxicating magic. He has climbed the ladder of social aspiration from the Stumpy Gully estate to Surfers Paradise's Golden Gate. The resources boom has been talked about by people such as Senator Carrick. According to a recent Press report he has a tendency to add a somewhat rosy gloss to his own National Energy Advisory Committee's interpretation of prospects for proposals such as the Rundle shale oil development project. The resources boom has been talked about by Senator Carrick in terms of the employment multiplier effects of the new mining projects. There is, I would suggest, a touch of euphoria about his references in answers to questions asked by me in the Senate on the beneficial effects of the boom. He said the effects will be 'the employment of families, the creation of societies and neighbourhoods'. What sorts of families, societies and neighbourhoods are being created and will be created as a result of a resources boom? Many questions have to be asked about the implications of resource development. The questions will have to be asked by members on both sides of politics, which accept the benefits of a resources boom. Questions will have to be asked also about the effects on other export industries. So too will questions about the effects on the rural sector in Australia, questions on the effects of the capacity to mobilise capital for other projects of importance to Australian people and questions about effects on the long term consequences for the labour market in Australia. More important are questions about the relationship between State Government and Federal Government responsibilities. The most important question of all is: What is the proper role of a national government in co-ordinating a national plan for resource development?

Might I suggest that some sort of crude guidelines might be adopted by a national government in planning resource development. First of all, perhaps there should be a national investment strategy. Secondly, there should be a clear decision about how essential services in development areas are to be funded. Thirdly, social planning should be undertaken well ahead of the construction phase. Fourthly, there should be a program to retrieve some of the existing very poor conditions which have been created as a result of resource development. There should be financial contribution perhaps to community needs by the development companies and economic planning to broaden as far as possible the economic base of development areas.

The question of a national plan or strategy goes right to the problem of what is the role of a Federal government in relation to these matters. Firstly, one would imagine that the role in terms of the delivery of services to the people might be to see that forces are given some sort of rational direction to ensure that the benefits of resource development are distributed in the national interests, that is, for the benefit of the Austraian people and particularly to ensure that the needs of Australians in those areas which are directly affected are catered for by governments or by the corporations which are the principal beneficiaries of resource development projects. If the needs of the people who are right at the centre of the resource development projects are not looked after, what hope is there in the future for the rest of Australian society? Again I ask: What sorts of neighbourhoods is Senator Carrick talking about when he speaks of the beneficial consequences of resource development in Australia?

The towns and regions in Australia which are, if I may put it his way, at the eye of the storm in relation to resource development, are places such as Gladstone in Queensland, the Latrobe Valley in central Victoria, the Hunter Valley in New South Wales, Portland in western Victoria and the Roxby Downs area in South Australia. Those areas are clearly marked for development and growth as a result of resource projects. At the very heart of the mineral resources boom at present is the central Queensland town of Gladstone. Gladstone has already gone through one boom and it now faces another. It has a population of 27,500. By the end of 1980 more than 62,000 people will be living there. Already Queensland Alumina Ltd is taking 5 million tonnes of bauxite from Weipa each year and shipping out 2.5 million tonnes of aluminium. More than 6 million tonnes of coal a year is being carried by coal loading units from fields at Moura, Blackwater and Gregory. The power house is the biggest in Queensland. Plans have already been announced and schemes now being investigated will accelerate this development. Two smelters are on the drawing boards. There is the Rundle shale oil project, a coke making plant and so on.

These are all dramatic and very exciting figures for those who are mesmerised by that sort of excitment. But vast wealth will be generated for this country from places such as Gladstone. When one looks at the consequences and the effects of this development on the people of Gladstone there are some important questions to be asked about the role of governments in delivering community services to the people who are at the heart of the whole resources boom question-Australians who are involved in generating that vast wealth.

Since the first industrial boom began in Gladstone in the 1960s no contribution at all, either private or government, has been made to the city's infrastructure needs. Ratepayers have had to foot the bill entirely. Average rates in Gladstone have risen by 164 per cent in seven years. They rose by more than 14 per cent last year alone. The city's loan program has trebled in a year to meet sewerage, water and trunk road requirements. Sewerage treatment is at capacity. The water supply is inadequate. Roads are substandard. There is no public transport in Gladstone. Caravan parks are crowded and new ones are filled before construction is finished. In the town of Gladstone there is the development of what is called already a caravan culture. Schools are overcrowded and just under half the city's primary school children are accommodated in classrooms described as non-permanent. As if these problems were not enough, there is a serious and growing threat of pollution. Gladstone has only one welfare officer operating with a tiny budget in a town where there are enormous social problems because of the nature of the work, the environment and the heavy use of alcohol and analgesics.

Most people are appalled at what is happening in Gladstone, but not the Premier of Queensland. It might be said in the Senate by a subsequent speaker: 'Well, that is a responsibility of the Queensland Government', but the Premier of Queensland does not say that. The Premier of Queensland shrugs off the conditions in Queensland by saying Gladstone 'is a work town, not a play town'. That is the sort of remark which might have been made at the time of William Blake's great hymn during the Industrial Revolution in England. He wrote:
And was Jerusalem builded here amongst these dark satanic mills.

That is what we are doing in Australia towards the end of the twentieth century in places such as Gladstone where vast resources are being generated for this country. Vast wealth is being generated, those are the standards which exist in a town such as that and that is the reaction of the Premier of that State.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose it didn't happen overnight, though.
—I am not saying that it did. That does not make it right. I know it did not happen overnight.
—It must have been an evolving process.

—Sure. The towns of the Latrobe Valley in Victoria are quickly developing symptoms similar to those of Gladstone. The Latrobe Valley is an area which will increasingly become important in terms of resources and particularly brown coal resources. There is a three-year waiting list for housing in the Latrobe Valley. Two out of every five of those waiting for public housing are single parents. There is a shortage of welfare accommodation, high rents are charged, caravan parks are filled to capacity and there is the growing prospect of a water shortage and pollution. The Latrobe Valley, Gladstone and Portland in Victoria are just three of the regional centres which will bear the brunt of the so-called resources boom. Portland has a district community service task force which was set up under the sponsorship of the Victorian Department of Community Welfare Services to assess the impact on Portland of the proposed smelter. This task force has described the housing situation in Portland as one of crisis. I remind the Senate that when the Whitlam Government lost office in 1975 the waiting time for a housing commission home in rural Victoria was down to three months. It is now three years, and the residents of Portland will feel the effects of that.

SPEECH.PARA: Victoria as a State is not alone. It is now receiving only one-seventh of the amount it was allocated six years ago. In the year 1974-75 the States were able to spend three-quarters of their Federal payments on housing programs while the remaining quarter was absorbed by debt payments. Now, however, three-quarters of this money is going into debt repayments. It is not difficult to see why, after unemployment, housing is the most serious social problem in Australia. Its seriousness is worsened in the mining and mineral processing areas such as Gladstone and the Latrobe Valley. This development is being carried out without government planning and without government concern for the residents of these places who are at the eye of the mineral storm. Without concern and planning these problems can be replicated again and again. Surely it is time that some intelligent appraisal was made of the implications of this type of development.

This development is occuring in non-metropolitan areas of Australia where there are already glaring inequalities with the rest of the country in terms of the provision of education, transport, housing, communication and welfare services. These are all services which are provided by government. That is why I asked at the beginning of my speech: 'What is the role of government, and particular the national Government, in relation to these matters?' I remind the Senate that in the time of the Labor Government from 1972 to 1975 regional growth areas were identified and supported. It may be said by way of criticism in hindsight that perhaps there was a lack of rationale for some of those developments in that they were not natural growth centres. They were growth centres designed, perhaps in an artificial way, to take the heat off the big metropolitan centres of Australia. But all of these places involved in the mineral boom are natural growth centres. They are all suffering, as I have already pointed out, from the inadequacy of government planning.

At the beginning of my comments I indicated some things which should be done. It can easily be said that these things are the responsibility of the State governments. They are also the responsibility of the Federal Government in terms, as I said earlier, of the wealth generated in places of this kind and in terms of the standards which every Australian is entitled to expect from a government which says it is a government for all the people of Australia. If Ministers in this Government, with their eyes popping out on stalks, are going to talk their heads off about the importance of the resources boom-they are entitled to do that; it is, no doubt, a pleasant pastime-they also have to confront the consequences of a resource boom in terms of its effects on the need for social and environmental planning in Australia in the sort of areas which I have delineated.

The resources boom will put State governments under increasing pressure to offer incentives to companies but it may not be compatible with the national interest of Australia. The Fraser Government has given almost automatic approval to State borrowings for resource projects. The Government did this 30 years ago with the car industry. Look what has happened to the car industry today. The only way to stop the cycle of competitive bidding among State Premiers is through Federal Government involvement and leadership. This is required to co-ordinate investments and to support infrastructure requirements in these areas. There has been a total lack of planning. The Government cannot have it both ways. It cannot have the benefits of a resource boom and deny responsibility for any dire social consequences for Australians, as I have indicated. As I said, these projects are occurring and will occur in non-metropolitan areas of Australia. I have already mentioned some of the vast inequalities in services which already exist in these areas and which people generally are subjected to outside the capital cities in comparison with those people living in the big cities of Sydney or Melbourne, for example.

Of course, some attempt must be made by government to ameliorate the consequences of these sorts of things which are happening. I suppose that it will again be said by honourable senators opposite that they will wash their hands of these responsibilities because they are the responsibilities of State governments. It is not the responsibility of State governments solely to handle these matters. It is the responsibility of governments which are concerned about the people of Australia and which are particularly concerned about those people who are bearing the vast burden of wealth generation and development in this country. The Labor Party is pledged to reducing these inequalities. Crash programs are needed with national government initiatives to solve some of the problems to which I have referred in some of the areas such as Gladstone, the Latrobe Valley and which will occur shortly in Portland and so on. There should be national co-ordination and leadership with those programs. Only in that way will we stop the sort of dark, satanic mills of the twentieth century developing in this country. Great riches will grow for those who are helping in the development.

We are pledged to reducing these inequalities. Any government ought to be pledged to reducing these inequalities. The present Government ought to be pledged to reducing these inequalities. That is why we raise the question of the lack of planning in relation to the resources boom. Economists and others are always very happy to talk about the economic implications of the resources boom. They write learned articles about very real problems almost every day of the week. There are very real problems of an economic nature associated with resource development on a huge scale. But enormous social problems have occurred previously. There has been a lack of planning and initiative by governments to ensure that those developments take place in the interests of Australian people not only in terms of wealth generation but also in terms of the interests of people who are living in the towns and areas concerned. Any government ought to be pledged to do something about that.

We are concerned about the lack of planning which has been displayed to date. We are concerned about the dimensions of what will be necessary in terms of infrastructure development in the future. The sad fact is that the ratio between expenditure on community services and the provision of hardware, as it were-infrastructure development for the mining industry-has been completely turned on its head in the last few years. The percentage being devoted to community service and development, to education, transport, housing and welfare services and so on, has gone down and down. The relative percentage devoted to the building of port facilities, railways and things of those kinds has gone up and up. The beneficiaries of such developments will be found in Japan, the United States of America and the United Kingdom and in the boardrooms of countries all around the world. The development should not be at the expense of the people who live in the remote areas. We commend this matter of public importance to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomas Sen A.M.

TALK.START.PARA: -I would like to tackle this matter of public importance about the claim of the lack of government planning for the resources boom, which has been brought on by Senator Button under five headings. First of all, I will discuss some recent examples of planning which the Western Australian Government has embarked on in conjunction with the Federal Government to illustrate the complete inaccuracy of Senator Button's comments. Secondly, I will make general comments about resource development. Thirdly, I will discuss the Australian Labor Party's policies or lack of policies in this area. Fourthly, I will discuss the Government's policies and, fifthly, I will discuss recent economic and employment data. I draw the Senate's attention to a speech made recently in this place by Senator Puplick. I think it was made in December last year. He illustrated very clearly the totally inept and almost criminal way in which the New South Wales Government is handling resource development in New South Wales. He gave many examples of environmental studies being totally ignored by that Government. To that degree I have to agree with Senator Button that a little more guidance and leadership is needed.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to my State of Western Australia. Senator Button correctly identified that the States do have the constitutional rights and powers to develop their own resources. The Commonwealth Government has a large interest in this area. Many people in various government departments in the Commonwealth have an involvement in this area. I suggest that in some cases they have too much involvement because there are many examples of the Federal Government holding up development unnecessarily. The Western Australian Government has many departments and commissions whose job it is to plan ahead. Of course, until some indication is given by a company or government that a certain development is to take place, it is impossible to get down to the details of a planning program. One example is that a series of seminars has been conducted up and down the coast of Western Australia by the State Government in conjunction with the North West Shelf developers where the pipeline is to be sited to bring natural gas to the southern parts of my State. The purpose of these seminars is to allow the people in those towns to appreciate the scale of the project and to allow them to plan for the part they will play in the development of that project.

During my Senate committee's current inquiry into the alumina and aluminium industries it was demonstrated very clearly to us when we were in Western Australia how necessary it is that the planning is carried out in a proper way. It was demonstrated to us that gas from the Dongara field would not have been available to the people in Perth if the field had not been developed in conjunction with the alumina refinery industry. This means very careful planning on both accounts. Similarly, with the North West Shelf gas, without the enormous energy demands from the aluminium smelters it would not have been economic for that resource to be used by the people of Western Australia. I also point out the work done by the State Government with regard to environment and to the total public participation in the environmental studies. It is almost a requirement now that the companies involved in resources development employ their own environmental consultants. This is happening more and more, which is very pleasing. The State Government employs consultants and has established a very intense and thorough environmental network. I agree with this. I agree that public opinion and public concern are demanding that governments of either colour get more and more involved in environmental matters. I have given some examples. I could give many more where the Commonwealth has co-operated with the Government of Western Australia. In particular, although I do not have time now, I could discuss the involvement between the two governments with regard to employment and training schemes. This has been a major accomplishment and it is a major job because the mineral boom certainly will require many more trained people to take full advantage of it.

I direct the Senate's attention to a publication by the Department of Industry and Commerce in December 1980. It contains 191 pages of small print, listing the major development projects for the future. If anybody doubts this mineral boom is with us he has only to skim through that publication and he will see the tremendous variety and range of development resources that can be tapped in this country. We do not deny that there are social and economic challenges to be faced with this resources boom; nobody denies that at all. I will demonstrate that the Government is well aware of those problems and is meeting the challenge. There are also challenges to the employers and to the unions, but there are great opportunities. The great mineral resources which will be developed in the 1980s will enhance the prospect of improved standards of living for all our people. They will provide more jobs for young people and an increase in job opportunities for those who choose to join the work force. The funds generated by these great developments will assist the governments to respond to the particular needs of the aged, families, the disabled and others in need.

It is rather extraordinary that during Senator Button's address-although this debate is really supposed to be about the economic and social effects of resources development-he totally ignored the massive benefits that will flow to the Australian community. If we took the Australian Labor Party's advice, the resources boom in Australia in the 1960s and early 1970s was a disaster for this country. How ridiculous! Its spokesmen might have a hard task in convincing the Government that no benefits arise from the taxes and royalties paid by these giant corporations. The workers who are receiving the high wage levels paid in the mining towns will treat Senator Button's comments with the contempt which they deserve. The contractors who are building and maintaining the mining developments know how the benefits of the natural resources development are being distributed; so do small businessmen who are benefiting from these developments. I can illustrate by stating the position in my own town of Geraldton, which is a relatively small town compared with some of the larger towns of the east coast. That town already is gearing itself to play a major part in the development of the North West Shelf gas field. There are mechanisms by which new jobs are created from mining development, real jobs which are created by encouraging enterprise and the initiative of the Australian people.

When Senator Button began his address he questioned some of the figures, in particular those Senator Carrick has been citing in this place. I draw his attention to an answer in the Senate Hansard of 30 April 1980 in which Senator Carrick listed many of the projects that he has been talking about and in particular used the names of Mr Manderville and Mr Jensen who conducted a lengthy inquiry into the economic impact of industrial development at Gladstone. At the present time Mr Manderville is conducting an inquiry into the economic impact of the Weipa bauxite mine. These figures were used by Senator Carrick when he gave the multiplier effect of employment development. We on this side of the chamber certainly know what socialists mean by the words 'planning' and 'leadership'. It is not what I understand those words to mean. Senator Button should go to the Pilbara if he questions the amount of resources that companies are providing for the well-being of the people who live in those areas. They are enormous. I can also take him to places in Western Australia where development is taking place and where the companies involved are making a major contribution to the schooling and social life of the people in those areas.

With regard to the Labor Party's policies, or lack of them, what was the Labor Party's answer to the resources boom of the 1960s? Its answer was to stop almost totally Australia's development. The hopeless policies conceived by the Labor Party stopped mineral exploration in Australia. The overseas enterprises which assisted Australia with the know-how and capital packed up and went home. The Opposition will be aware of Professor Blainey's book The Rush that Never Ended. It could be said that the final chapter in that book could have been written by the Labor Party. That chapter talks about the rush and the ending of that rush. When Senator Button and his colleagues speak about government planning, as I said before, we all know what sort of planning they mean. It ultimately means the total nationalisation of those industries. Such policies are anti-business, anti-foreign investment and anti-mining. They would expand the public sector and increase taxation. There would be no room left in the Australian economy for a resources boom. I suspect that Senator Button does not really mean what he says, so I give him that amount of regard. I understand from Press reports his rather tenuous future representing the State of Victoria. Recently Mr Hayden was kind enough to give the Australian people an idea of what the Labor Party is all about. Two weeks ago Mr Hayden made a particularly interesting speech at the Hilton Hotel in Sydney. He said:
. . . re-affirm the ALP's steady and unflinching commitment to democratic socialism.

Does anyone believe we would be entering the 80s with such confidence if the country had been governed by such socialistic doctrines over the last five years? Who would have been prepared to invest when private enterprise was held in such low esteem by the Government, when its economy was riddled with inflation and its deficit soared out of control? It took Bill Hayden and two other ALP Treasurers just three years to wreak havoc on the Australian economy. Yet the same sort of prescription for economic disaster continues to emerge from the ALP policies. I refer again to Mr Hayden's use of the term 'socialistic planning'. I suggest that the Australian Labor Party cannot plan for three months let alone a decade. Mr Hayden said on 19 August:

Retail sales are flat, production has been pretty disastrous, motor car sales have been dreadful, unemployment is starting to climb again and inflation is taking off . . . I would argue that it will be in excess of 12 per cent by the end of the year.

We all know what inflation was at the end of the year. In fact, the Treasurer (Mr Howard) said today in the other place that figures for the September quarter of 1980 indicate that private sector investment was no less than 36.7 per cent above the level of the December quarter of 1979. Furthermore, the Treasurer continued today:
The investment from the private sector in capital expenditure for the December quarter shows a continuation of that same strong growth.

Just as the Opposition was writing-down the economy, strong growth was under way. The figures cited by the Treasurer are the latest in a long line of statistics which indicate with increasing strength the pace and momentum of the economic recovery taking place in Australia at present.

I wish to speak now about government policies in this area. It is recognised that Australia is on the threshold of the greatest development the country has ever seen. It is also recognised by people in this country and in other countries that Australia, because of its relatively cheap energy resources -we have been kindly treated in that regard -and in order to make a contribution to its own welfare and particularly to countries which lack these resources, has an obligation to develop these resources at a reasonable rate. The Fraser Government has dramatically changed Australia's economic prospects. The Government has been determined to create real jobs and to restore business and consumer confidence. The Government has done this in four particular ways: By fighting inflation; by restraining government expenditure; by encouraging wage restraint; and by taxation reform.

A survey released recently by the Department of Industry and Commerce indicated that 306 projects were committed or were at the final feasibility stage in the manufacturing and mining industries. This represents a total investment of over $33 billion. This latest survey doubles the level of projected investment identified in October 1979. Honourable senators will remember that in the 1977 election the Government stated that some $6 billion worth of investment projects were planned in Australia. We heard a chorus from Opposition members to 'show us the list'. I have already referred to part of that list in the publication produced in December 1980 by the Department of Industry and Commerce.

Recently there has been a flood of encouraging economic data. I have cited some. The Opposition, which has been bitterly critical of our policies, has been forced at last to admit to the improved outlook for the economy of Australia. The labour market has shown consistent improvement over the last two years. Almost 170,000 new jobs were created in 1980; some 70 per cent of this increase related to full time jobs. There has been a total increase of almost 300,000 jobs in the last two years. The labour market has been more receptive to school leavers. Junior unemployment rates were lower in 1980 than in previous years. The latest figures show that the number of teenagers looking for full time employment is 12,500 below the level for January 1980. Unfilled vacancies have increased substantially over 1980. As more people are seeking work and as the participation rate is the highest for four years the fall in the unemployment rate is not as dramatic as the growth in jobs might indicate.

The Government is optimistic that its continuing youth employment and training initiatives will progressively enable increasing numbers of young people to improve their job prospects. I have proved to the Senate that the Government is participating fully in the resource development of Australia. I mentioned before that the States have the constitutional power and the resources to steer this resource development but that the Commonwealth is playing its part where it feels there is a need. I suggest that in some areas the Commonwealth is overzealous in the job it does with regard to exercising control over resource development and that the States, particularly my own State of Western Australia, are well equipped to handle this problem. We do not deny that there are problems but I strongly suggest that the States and the Commonwealth is well equipped to handle them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the matter of public importance proposed by Senator Button concerning the lack of government planning for the resources boom. The Australian Democrats support the thrust of the discussion. I compliment Senator Button on his speech. He dwelt on the social and economic conditions manifest in various parts of Australia because of the lack of planning in the so-called resources boom. I support his comments. Senator Button canvassed the boom town of Gladstone and pictured the economic and social consequences of the lack of planning already manifest in that town. He also described conditions in the Latrobe Valley, which I too have visited, in which caravan parks and caravan towns are sprouting up without the ancillary back up facilities of education, health and social welfare. This spells tragedy for future generations.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Button touched on the town of Portland. To develop on that, one sees this beautiful little country town into which a multinational, Alcoa of Australia Ltd, is about to descend to create a multibillion dollar complex. It will spray the town with fluoride and impact an environmental crisis upon it. Alcoa will do that assisted by the Victorian Government which is massively subsidising this impoverished multinational. I will speak more of that in a moment. Senator Thomas responded to Senator Button's speech. Apart from the fact that his speech was in good humour and contained no abuse, just as one would expect from the thoroughly decent man that he is, it did not enlighten me as to the justification for the Government's policies. He spoke of massive benefits to the Australian people out of the resources boom. This catch phrase which is being taken up by members of the Government was initiated by Mr Fraser and seconded by Mr Anthony. They said that this resources boom will give massive benefits to everyone.

There is no doubt that we are about to embark on a resources boom of breathtaking proportions. A figure of $29 billion has been mentioned; I do not necessarily query it. I think the point of how much the boom will be worth is irrelevant. There will be a massive boom with huge mining projects in all sorts of areas. Bauxite, alumina, coal and iron ore projects-just to mention a few-are about to begin yielding billions of dollars to the entrepreneurs involved. I think it is time in this debate for me to paint a backdrop to the boom. Let us ask ourselves: Who owns those resources and who will benefit from them? To me those questions seem essential to a debate such as this particularly when one is discussing the lack of planning for the boom that is inevitably to take place.

I will cite some figures, even though figures are boring, because I want them on the record. These figures come from the United Nations publication Trans National Corporations in World Development, New York 1978. The figures concern foreign control or ownership of industrial sectors in Australia. We are talking about a resources boom. The publication states that 55 per cent of all mining ventures in Australia are owned by overseas companies. Some 36 per cent of manufacturing, 48 per cent of service industries and 62 per cent of all Australian chemical, coal, rubber and petroleum industries are owned by multinationals or overseas companies. Some 46 per cent of fabricated metal product industries are similarly foreign-owned. Those are 1978 figures. I apologise for using them, but we cannot get later figures because one of the little known scandals of statistics-keeping in this country is that by order of this Government that section of the Australian Bureau of Statistics which keeps statistics on foreign investment and ownership was disbanded two or three years ago. Let us remember that we are talking about a resources boom. I am asking the simple and honest question: Who will benefit from those resources and who owns those resources? If we dig deeper under those general figures that I cited we find that the Australian motor vehicle industry is 100 per cent foreign controlled, that oil refining is 91 per cent foreign owned, that oil exploration is 74 per cent foreign controlled, that tin production is 81 per cent foreign controlled and that the mineral sands industry is 62 per cent foreign controlled. We also find, for goodness sake, that 51 per cent of advertising agencies are owned by foreign companies. So those claims by Government supporters and Ministers that massive benefits will be given to everybody in this boom sound a little hollow.

The Age newspaper has said: 'So far so good, but we must question, in respect of this boom, where most of the billions of dollars will finish up'. The Age aptly puts it: 'For whom will the boom really bang?' Few Australian companies will share equitably in the bonanza. Of course, some will do quite well, including some mining companies which are still owned by Australians and those companies building mining equipment. But the vast majority of Australians will not gain much at all from the boom. We know that the resources boom entails capital intensive industries and that, therefore, the contribution to lessening unemployment will be minimal. I was interested to hear Senator Thomas talk about the multiplier effect. All economists whose writings I have read do not foresee much of a multiplier effect on other industries springing from the resources boom. For example, I hope that the next Government speaker can explain to me how the clothing, textile, footwear and car industries will benefit in any significant way from the resources boom of the 1980s. The real beneficiaries will be the large multinational corporations which control much of the mining industry at the moment-CRA Ltd, Utah and Alcoa, to name just a few.

I digress slightly to illustrate one of the sickening things that is happening in this country today. I refer to the Foreign Investment Review Board, which will be the subject of some further detailed criticism from me in later months. I find incredible the disposition of this Board, which is charged with the task of keeping Australia for Australians, in putting up a most pathetic record of bowing to the wishes of multinationals.
