In response to anything that a foreign company wants with respect to the removal of the 70 per cent or 50 per cent of Australian ownership clause, the Foreign Investment Review Board seems to be grovelling by saying: 'Yes, multinational or foreign company, we will grant your wish'. I may be doing the officials on that Board an injustice. It may well be that they are acting under ministerial direction.

How about this for a pathetic un-Australian action? It concerns the recent takeover by Caltex Oil (Australia) Pty Ltd of the Golden Fleece company. The Caltex company, in return for offering a very small percentage of itself to Australian shareholders, will now be able to trade much more easily through the foreign investment guidelines laid down by the Government. The performance of the FIRB in promoting Australian ownership of Australian resources already leaves a lot to be desired. It seems that following the Caltex decision we are in for yet another multinational invasion. Of course, to accompany this resources boom we now have an influx of international financiers. They are arriving in force to cash in on the boom. How much joy is that for small Australian investors and shareholders? I cite Citibank, Morgan Gauranty and the Bank of America as just a few of the merchant banks and financiers coming to Australia.

Let us look at some other questions. What should be done? First, Australian ought to develop a resources policy and an energy policy. At the moment we do not have a resources or energy policy. In fact we have eight different resources policies for a country of 14.5 million people, and that is insane. We have one alleged policy espoused by the Federal Government. Each of our little State Premiers also has his State energy or resources policy. Of course, the eighth policy is the energy policy determined by the foreign companies or multinationals to suit themselves. The Australian Democrats believe very strongly that there ought to be a referendum with all parties getting together to recommend to the Australian people that powers over resources and energy should be a Federal responsibility and not a State responsibility. We now have the rather amusing sight of State Premiers going overseas, waving bits of paper to impoverished multinationals and saying: 'Please do not go to Victoria, which is providing electricity at a give-away price of 1.4c a kilowatt. Come to my State. I will undercut other electricity suppliers. I will sell you electricity at 0.9c a kilowatt. It does not matter that we put Western Australians, Tasmanians or whoever in debt for the next 20 years as long as we get the precious multinational in our State to dig the guts out of our ground and to exploit our people'. That is the be-all and end-all in policy-making. It is time that stopped.

I have just returned from Tasmania, where there are forces at work amongst State politicians to dam one of the most beautiful rivers in the world to create power. I suppose that the creation of power is a worthy object, but when one asks them whether they have a market for the power or whether they need it, they say: 'Oh yes, we will sell it allright'. I ask: Where are the bits of paper with signatures on the dotted line showing undertakings to buy this power? That sort of evidence is conspicuous by its absence. We are saying that there has to be a national policy on energy and resources which would allow some planning. We have to allow the small Australian investor a chance to invest in Australian resource development. I again bring to the notice of the Senate the insanity of Australia's policy of having a double tax on income from investments for small investors. To my knowledge we are the only country in the Western world, other than Canada, which has a double tax on dividends for the small investor.

I believe we ought to have a resource tax. I believe the Federal Government ought to tax the mining companies and those exploiting our resources at the source-when they rip the stuff out of the ground. I am sure of the fact that we do not know and cannot know what real profits multinationals are making in the exploitation of our resources. I have previously cited the case on record of Alcoa's selling alumina from Australia to its United States parent company at $108 a tonne in 1978 at a time when the world price was $150 a tonne. Clearly the price it charged its parent company was the cost price in Australia. Therefore, it could say to the Australian Taxation Office: 'We made no profits. It cost us $108 a tonne to make and we sold it at $108 a tonne'. The parent company then sold it to the client at $150 a tonne.

I have discussed that question with former Deputy Commissioners and Commissioners of Taxation, men not renowned for their radical beliefs or their left wing tendencies. They are tax gatherers. They told me that they have spent hours, weeks, months and years with the best brains in the Taxation Office trying to find ways of catching multinationals which under-cost those sorts of exports. They told me that there is no way they can do that because a multinational's accountant can always produce every document that is asked for. Therefore, the Australian Democrats would support very strongly a resource tax so that at least we would have some chance of getting something for the assets that are being taken out of our ground.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support strongly the matter of public importance raised by Senator Button, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The lack of Government planning for the resources boom.

I very much regret that the Minister for National Development and Energy, Senator Carrick, has not seen fit to enter this debate and, as the relevant Government Minister, to indicate where a proper defence can be mounted against this matter of public importance. What we on this side of the chamber are asking for-and I very much applaud Senator Chipp for his contribution on behalf of the Australian Democrats-is not for government intervention of a heavy kind which would require blue prints which would so stultify the accumulation and the marshalling of capital and manpower by private enterprise that resource development would come to a standstill: Far from it. I think all Australians would welcome a resources boom which was so controlled, so developed that all Australians would benefit from it. What we are looking for is some sort of strategy, some sort of co-ordination, whereby those national resources can return proper dividends to every Australian.

Senator Chipp made a plea for this area to be regarded as one of truly national concern. But one does not even have to go as far as that to query whether the Government is really interested in evolving some sort of strategy of co-ordination to ensure that this development does benefit the Australian people. At a meeting of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources on 3 February which was attended by top bureaucrats within the Federal structure, I put this question: To your knowledge over the past three years has there been any forum of ministers, or very high level officials where all the proposals for the aluminium industry expansion have been put on the table by the various State governments so that they can be scrutinised? The answer of Mr Monaghan, the Director of the National Energy Office, was:
I do not think so.

So there we have a top public official, the Director of the National Energy Office, admitting to a Senate Committee that even accepting the constraints of federalism there was no co-ordination involving the Australian Minerals and Energy Council, at which all the relevant Ministers concerned could discuss, co-ordinate and evolve a strategy to ensure that the benefits of the resources boom did flow to the Australian people. So it is not good enough for the Government to hide behind constitutional barriers and to say that this is a State responsibility whereby the forums constructed in deference to the Federal structure have themselves not been utilised. In my view, it is disgraceful that the various Ministers of the State and Federal governments have not got together to ensure that our resources are not auctioned off in the way in which Senator Chipp so graphically illustrated.

I will give some examples of where the lack of planning has a concrete focus. I do not suppose that there would be any greater concern within the community at the moment than the question of pricing of electricity to these great resource projects. Every consumer of electricity is asking whether he or she is subsidising the energy costs of the aluminium industry, for example. Every householder who has to pay his or her electricity bill as it increases quarter by quarter is asking that question. But I think of equal concern to the Australian Democrats and to the Labor Party is the fact that the smaller commercial and trading concerns, the smaller entrepreneurs, the businesses which are paying commercial tariffs are also asking the question. So it is not only the domestic consumers but also the other consumers of electricity within our trading and commercial enterprises who are asking whether, in the absence of the great resource muscle of the very big projects, they are being forced by tariff policies of State electricity commissions to subsidise the energy components in the finished products of, for example, the aluminium industry.

What is the Federal Government's attitude in the face of this concern within the community? Is it even putting itself in a position where it can aid the plant allocation of electricity energy resources in this country? I regret to say that the answer is-and I was astounded when I heard it during the Senate committee hearing-that not only is the Federal Government not demanding that State governments supply that information, but it is not even requesting it. I refer very briefly to page 704 of the transcript of evidence of the meeting of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources on 3 February 1981 which records my asking Mr Monaghan, the Director of the National Energy Office, this question:

What formal request has the Department made, for example, to the State Government of New South Wales or its Electricity Commission or any State government where relevant, to obtain the tariffs which you say are regarded by them as confidential?
Mr Monaghan replied:

I mentioned earlier arrangements for obtaining information which is not regarded as confidential by the authorities. We have not made a formal demand on the authorities for information which they consider to be confidential because we have not felt that we had the power to do so.
I interposed:
I did not say 'formal demand'-
I interpolate that such a phrase has all the characteristics of perhaps breaking into constitutional areas which are not those of the Federal Government-
I said 'formal request'.
Mr Monaghan said:
I amend my response with the words 'formal request'.

In other words, the Director of the National Energy Office, no doubt acting under ministerial direction, has not seen fit even to make a formal request on the Government's behalf to the State governments and electricity generating authorities concerned to try to find out what is the actual level of tariff being charged by these great energy projects. How can the Government have the gall to appoint Senator Carrick as Minister for National Development and Energy when it prevents him from even asking those sorts of questions.

Two consequences are readily apparent from this failure of the Government even to ask for this sort of information. One has already been alluded to by Senator Chipp. The Government is not then in a position to know the true costs of the production process if it does not know what this energy component input really costs the producers. Therefore, the true level of profitability cannot be correctly analysed and the Commissioner of Taxation is not in a position to ensure that the revenue is not being led astray when it comes to ensuring that the community shares in the very profitable use of Australian energy resources. I add that further evidence of lack of planning would be the fact that the Government has not yet seen fit to put aluminium along with bauxite and alumina on the list of those commodities over which the Government will exercise some sort of surveillance when export contracts are entered into. Once again, the problem of transfer pricing is thereby not faced up to. Unless the Australian Government has a surveillance role in relation to the pricing of aluminium ingots when they go overseas no doubt the highly integrated aluminium industry will ensure that transfer pricing means that the true benefits from the exploitation of these Australian resources do not flow to the Australian people.

A second consequence is that this Minister for National Development and Energy is in no position to say whether the coal or gas resources, whichever might be used for the generation of electricity, say, in the Hunter Valley or in Western Australia are being used in the best possible manner, or whether, for example, they ought to be reserved for coal liquefaction plants to overcome our transport fuel difficulties which may be expected to emerge, say, in 15 years' time. We do not know, for example, whether that coal ought to be allocated for export to the growing steaming coal market. What I am saying is that the Government's lack of planning has totally prevented the so-called Minister for National Development and Energy from acting in a way which would give any bite or credence to that portfolio. Instead the national Government is hiding behind a constitutional veil. As I said, it refuses to recognise the truly national character of these resources and the responsibility of the Government to ensure that the resources flow to benefit all Australians.

I was pleased to hear Senator Chipp, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, say that there is a need to consider the introduction of a resource rent tax in this area. Indeed in doing so, the Democrats once again are joining the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources. It was acknowledged by senators from all sides of the chamber on that Committee that sensitively handled in a way which does not remove the incentive to invest, sensitive to the fact that some of these projects are indeed risk projects, a resource rental tax will ensure that some of the very great profits generated by these projects go into the Federal Treasury for proper disbursal to the Australian community. In the absence of that disbursal certain things will occur and are occurring. State governments will increase their charges, for example as the Queensland Government does in regard to the rail freighting of these materials around Queensland. In other words, State governments will recognise that there is a gap in the return to the community from these highly profitable operations and will be in for their share.

An even more surprising aspect concerning the Government's neglect is the fact that the people directly employed by these projects perceive that there is an opportunity for them to share in a greatly profitable enterprise to the neglect of the greater Australian community. In that instance unions, of course, will be bargaining as hard as they are able in order to ensure that the great profits generated-the Utah company is a well-known great example-go to the workers directly employed in that industry. My question is: What will be the effect of that very high escalation of wages within those very few projects and industries on the overall employment market within Australia? We know that what will be involved will be a poaching of employees-skilled tradesmen, particularly in the electrical and the metal trades-from existing employers. Has the Government undertaken any planning to try to forecast the effect on existing employers by these projects poaching with offers of very high wages to very skilled tradesmen?

The other effect which also is becoming apparent, is that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee) is indeed becoming the Commonwealth Employment Service of the resource projects. Skilled tradesmen are being sought overseas instead of the Government using its power, which it constitutionally has whether by virtue of the Foreign Investment Review Board or by export permit control, to say to these project developers: 'Permission to export your product will not be given unless you satisfy us that you have a fully worked out program of training of Australians to work within your industry'. Unless that is done and unless apprenticeship training and skilled tradesmen training are undertaken, not only of young Australians presently unemployed but also by way of upgrading the skills of people already within the Australian work force, I believe that these developers ought to be told now that the Government will not assist by way of immigration in the manpower shortages that may be expected to occur.

In this very short time it has been quite impossible to cover the whole gamut of matters which ought to be touched upon in a debate of such importance to Australia's future. The Australian Labor party is concerned that these resources be developed in such a way and at such a pace that the whole of the Australian community benefits. We want an increase in national income. We want an increase in national living standards. We believe that a resources boom, properly planned for, can guarantee the achievement of those very desirable objectives, but it will require planning, initiative and leadership by the national Government to ensure that there is a true integration of national aims, State government aims, and the legitimate aims of private enterprise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join in the debate on this matter of public importance, namely, the lack of government planning for the resources boom. The contributions to the debate from both sides of the chamber have been constructive, although undoubtedly my colleagues and I are probably at variance with some of the propositions put foward by the Opposition. Nonetheless, the general tone of the debate has been constructive. Senator Button, when he led this debate, waxed quite poetic and quoted William Blake's wonderful poem, now a hymn, Jerusalem. The second verse is: 'Bring me my bow of burning gold, bring me my arrows of desire'. Let me take some of those arrows and see whether I can puncture a few of the balloons that have been floated this afternoon.

SPEECH.PARA: The resource boom actually started in the 1960s. I well recall it because then the primary industries of our country were in really desperate straits. The wool industry was in a bad way and there was a very bad drought which affected western Queensland. It was there that we started to see the vast exodus of people from those rural areas. As the resources boom was picking up at that stage it provided many jobs that otherwise would not have been. Right from that stage it has had an advantageous effect in providing employment. Of course, that has picked up since. Costs as they have been related to the primary producer are such that he no longer can afford to employ as many people as he once did and employment has been provided, particularly at some of the mines away from the capital cities and the coastal areas.

We all agree that there are problems involved, but does this indicate a lack of government planning or does it indicate that the Government has provided, by its policies, an atmosphere in which large scale investment and development have been able to take place and that maybe we have not been able to keep up with it. How would one plan for a resources boom? I believe that much has been done. Much needs to be done. The Federal Government is a little limited. Mention has been made of its constitutional powers; they are there. The States very jealously guard their constitutional powers and they hold many of the keys to the locks on the doors which need to be opened in order to provide for this large scale development. The development is there. We could not expect it to go along as though it were on a rainbow. There have been bumps on the road. We accept that. The point is that we learn and try to prevent them happening in the future and try to fix the problems as they arise.

Many mining towns are in a pretty good situation now. The size of the caravan parks is decreasing. Senator Button and Senator Chipp alluded to Gladstone, which has problems. It is pretty close to where I live. Infrastructure needs to be provided. But the situation is not all that bad. Senator Button referred to the dark satanic mills of William Blake, but that is not altogether what Gladstone is about. There are problems, I have admitted that, but it is still a very desirable place in which to live. Many people are living there quite happily. It has a wonderful area for boating and for fishing. Heron Island is off-shore. There are many things available there which make life a little more enjoyable. The problems are there, but it is not the pariah of places in which to live, as some people would indicate.

The Federal Government has been trying, indeed with a fair bit of criticism, to increase Australian equity in these projects. It is a well-known fact that the Australian investor is pretty tardy when it comes to investing in risk projects, and indeed some of the mining programs are risky. We are having a lot of trouble in increasing Australian investment. We may not have the statistics available to which Senator Chipp alluded but I think the Foreign Investment Review Board is doing a good job keeping tabs on what money is coming in. It is trying to be sympathetic and is recognising the lack of Australian investment. It wants to get some of these projects off the ground. When we look at the State governments involvement-I refer to my State government's involvement in Queensland-we see that they have done a pretty good job. There are some large scale mining areas in Queensland. They are giving the Commonwealth and State governments and the people of the State a very good return.

Senator Tate mentioned the freight rates charged by the railway. I wish to go through this matter again. It is a greatly misunderstood aspect of the Queensland Government's policy. Much was made in the early days of the fact that the royalty was, I think, 6d a ton. Somebody said it was a tomato for a ton of coal. It was never intended at that stage that the State Government would recoup any money from resources through royalties. They were merely a token. The recoupment was effected through the railways freight scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —Isn't that a pretty devious way of doing it?

—No, I do not think it was. I think it was a pretty good way. The honourable senator should wait one minute. The railway on which I worked is quite magnificent. Not one cent of the cost of it was paid by the taxpayers of Queensland or, indeed, of Australia. It was part of the agreement that the mining companies provide that complete railway network from the largest diesel electric locomotive to the last dog spike. Not one cent of taxpayers or railway customers' money was used for that. The money was provided by the companies. The repayment was to be made by way of freight rates. The freight rates were organised so that, I think working on a 15-year contract, the freight rate would escalate, starting off at a low base. I think the mining companies would have been repaid for their original investment. It is a very good railway. In my first speech in the Senate I mentioned the new technology that it brought into the railways alone, let alone the technology that it has brought into the mining industry in relation to the bulk handling of coal and the ports of Hay Point and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: We have reaped a wonderful reward in Queensland. I think the Queensland Government has done an excellent job in the contracts it has organised with the mining companies. I do not think the mining companies like the contracts. Nonetheless at the conclusion of the period-I think it is to be a lesser period because the tonnages have increased-we will own a magnificent railway and the rolling stock. This does not apply so much to the wagons because they are made specifically for the coal traffic, but the diesel electric locomotives will be fit to be used on any other section of the Queensland railway network. I think the Queensland Government has done a very good job indeed in its organising of those contracts for the benefit of the people of Queensland.

This situation is in marked contrast to the current situation in New South Wales. It is unfortunate for the people of New South Wales that the State Government seems to have taken a different attitude. We have heard about the coal loaders that are going into Newcastle, where I think the depth of the water in the port is such that it can take only 60,000 tonne to 80,000 tonne ships. The Botany Bay coal loader has been abandoned. This is all having its effect. Of course, contractors are looking to other States. It is most unfortunate for the coal industry, the mining industry, the resources boom and ultimately, of course, the people of New South Wales. Unfortuately, the New South Wales Government, instead of investing money in education, health and all the other essential services, is buying into the resources boom when there is no necessity for it to do so. I understand that the Electricity Commission of New South Wales has bought or is buying shares in coalmines to the tune of $800m. That certainly will not be advantageous to the people of New South Wales. It is unfortunate that that is happening. I just instance the marked contrast between that and what has happened in my own State of Queensland.

Mention has been made of the resources tax. Neither I nor, I think, any of my colleagues, would support the concept of a resources tax. This afternoon we are talking about the resources boom. We recognise that the mining companies pay company tax, rail freights and royalties. All in all, these companies probably pay about 60c out of every dollar they earn. I think that is a pretty good contribution to the coffers of Australia. I could not go along with the thought of a resources tax.

I shall make brief mention of union involvement, which has sought to divide and maybe even to isolate the mining industry. Senator Tate rightfully touched on the fact that very high wages are being paid in the mining industry and that that is having a very heavy social effect on the surrounding area. Other employers cannot get workers. People on the land probably within 100 miles of the central Queensland coalfields find it very hard to get people to work on their land because they cannot afford to pay them the high wages that are being paid on the coalfields. If a person is selling petrol in a service station in a town such as Blackwater or Moranbah, there is no way in the world that his employer could expect to give him the same conditions or pay him the same wages as the mining companies can afford to pay. So we are experiencing quite a problem in that area. It is one to which there is no ready answer, but I think it must be acknowledged.

I return to the situation at Gladstone. At present maintenance workers at the Gladstone power station are on strike for an $81 a week site allowance. We have already acknowledged the fact that there are problems associated with living in Gladstone, but I do not think the maintenance workers at that power station have any greater problems than do most of the other workers in that town, whether they are pumping petrol or working in the railways. It is unfortunate that people are capitalising on this situation, not only dividing the community but also providing further problems in the future. They are not acting altogether responsibly.

Part of our resources boom is associated with the development of our uranium mines. I worked in Cloncurry for many years and carried yellowcake from the Mary Kathleen mine to shipping. I know most of my colleagues in the railway are not one little bit concerned, yet we see the Australian Railways Union, I would say not with the will of its members, trying to ban the shipment of uranium, which, of course, will be a much needed resource in the future for the provision of power.

Our steaming coal exports are mounting. I have no objection to that, except for one thing. I ask: Just how much further can we go with burning these masses of coal and pouring the pollutants, including carbon dioxide, into the atmosphere? One thing that we are not sure of, of course, is the ultimate greenhouse effect that it will have on this continent, maybe even in our lifetime. I think we must consider quite reasonably just where to cry halt to the burning of masses of steaming coal and where we can bring in one of the cleanest methods of power generation, that is, nuclear power generation, until something cleaner and better comes along. I reject the suggestion that the Government is lacking in its planning, but I welcome the opportunity to take part in this debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to Senator Thomas for some information he revealed during his speech which had not come my way before; that is, that the Western Australian Government intends using North West Shelf gas to generate electricity to be supplied to the proposed aluminium smelters. I was not previously aware that the Western Australian Government had such a policy. The Government is vulnerable to criticism, as is stated in the wording of the matter of public importance, because of the lack of forethought and planning on its part in the resources boom. It is vulnerable for reasons other than lack of planning. It is vulnerable in the sense that Senator Button spoke of-that is, in respect of providing an adequate social infrastructure for people who will populate the developed mining areas. The clearest manifestation of Government ineptitude, of its inability to handle the resources boom, is its categorical rejection of a resources rent tax. High tory dogma has taken precedence over national interest, economic rationality and social justice. I will deal with those three points.

SPEECH.PARA: On the social justice question, I assert-it is an assertion backed by value judgments-that mineral bonanzas are public property, that those who mine are entitled to rewards, both to capital and to labour, but that abnormal profit, which economists call 'economic rent'-that is, the return to capital or labour above the going market rates of return for both of those inputs-ideally should be appropriated by the state. In reality, since we live in something less than an ideal world, that means that such an economic rent and those abnormal profits should be taxed progressively. The national interest, given the high degree of foreign ownership of our mineral resources, which is something that is likely to continue in spite of some cosmetic adjustments that are being made now, surely demands that they be adequately taxed inside Australia.

Both of those points, as I conceded initially, are at least to some extent value judgments. They reflect personal, political and philosophical views which I and my colleagues hold. Even to those who reject those philosophical and ethical views, the case for a resources rent tax as against quantum levies-that is, royalties based on the level of output, on production-on purely technical grounds is irrefutable. When I say 'purely technical grounds', I mean on evaluations as bereft of value judgments or emotive content as the arithmetic laws from which the case for a resources rental tax is derived.

The essential difference, which I repeat for the benefit of the high tory ideologues and innumerates who populate the Government benches both here and in the House of Representatives, between quantum royalties and a resources rent tax is that quantum royalties are levied on the volume of output and a resources rent tax is levied on profits. I note that although Senator Collard has some objection to the principle of a resources rent tax, which was not clearly spelled out, he has no objection to and indeed applauds the existence of a very crude and inefficient attempt to levy a resources rent tax in Queensland by way of excessive rail freight charges. The charges are excessive in relation to the costs incurred in providing the service.

Traditionally, taxes on mining enterprises in Australia have been levied on production. They are quantum royalties, although some very crude and inefficient attempts to tax profits are in existence. I refer to the sliding scale of royalties which have been long established in Broken Hill; the Western Australian Government practice of imposing by an Act of Parliament royalties on iron ore development in the 1960s on an individual project basis; the coal export levy, which is extant despite a five-year-old promise by the Fraser Government to remove it; and the question of railway freights in Queensland to which Senator Collard has already referred. I will be saying something more about railway freights later.

The best existing example of the technical unacceptability of quantum levies, or mining royalties as they are generally referred to, is the crude oil levy. I shall use approximate figures but they are close enough to reality to demonstrate very clearly the technical unacceptability of any royalty or levy based on output instead of on profits. Currently Australian oil produced from Bass Strait oil fields receives a market price of $27 a barrel. Of that $27, $20 goes on taxation, almost entirely to the Commonwealth Government through the crude oil levy, and about $7 goes to the producers. The current cost of producing the oil is less than $2 a barrel. When the cost of producing that oil rises-as it inevitably will as the fields approach the end of their producing life-above $7 a barrel, production from those fields will cease unless some other changes are made to the taxing arrangements.

Oil producers are not philanthropists. I see no reason why they should be. The simple reality is that if the market price is $27 a barrel, if the tax is $20 and if the cost of extraction exceeds $7 a barrel, production will cease and oil which has a market value of $27 a barrel and a production cost of less than $8 a barrel will remain in the ground until such time as that inept taxing policy is altered. If this Government survives long enough to outlive the major producing life of the Bass Strait oil fields, which is highly unlikely, despite its reiteration of high tory dogma as recently as yesterday, it will be forced to change those arrangements.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you suggest should happen? What are you suggesting is the cost of secondary recovery? How do you suggest the taxing arrangements should be related?

—The tax should be related to profits instead of output. The effects of inept quantum royalties are less obvious but still apply to mining in general. They apply because they affect the cut-off grade-that is, the amount of payable mineral in the ore which determines whether the ore will be pulled out of the ground and processed. There is a point at which the extraction and processing of ore becomes payable. If a fixed royalty related to the volume of output applies, that is something which must be taken into account by the producer before his cash and capital costs of production are dealt with. If these two factors exceed the market value of the commodity then ore which is economically recoverable will be left in the ground. The essential point, which relates back to the question which Senator Young raised a while ago, is that this means at the margin, at the point where the market value of oil and the cost of pumping it out of Bass Strait, or wherever the field may be located, are equal, or at the point where the cost of extracting and processing ore is equal to the market price of the product, there must be no taxation. A proper profits-related resources rent tax automatically ensures that that happens. A quantum royalty guarantees that it does not.

SPEECH.PARA: In sticking to this policy the Commonwealth has abdicated its responsibilities. It has created a tax vacuum which is being filled in two ways: Firstly, in Queensland, it is being filled by excessive rail freights-I use the definition of 'excessive' that I used earlier, that is, in excess of actual cost-and, secondly, it is being filled sometimes by the small number of skilled people but at other times by the not particularly skilled people who are employed in the mining projects. In other words, the economic rent is being appropriated partly by the State governments and partly by members of the work force, acting usually in a collective way through unions. I regard that as inequitable and inefficient. The inefficiency of quantum royalties has already been proved. I regard the practice of appropriating the economic rent by the work force as inequitable. I believe-I think this is the correct ethical and moral position for any social democrat to adopt-that the windfall gains of the economic rent should be appropriated by the State for the benefit of the whole of the community and not by the relatively small work force actually associated with the extraction of the product. Members of the Government probably do not care much for that sort of value judgement. They probably think it is irrelevant. But what ought to concern even them is the macro-economic effects of the extremely high wages paid by the Utah Development Company in Queensland and paid to some extent by other companies in other parts of Australia and likely to be paid to workers employed on other resource projects if the present policies are continued.

The potential benefit of a flow-on of high wages throughout the rest of the economy, exacerbated by specific labour shortages in some cases-this is another example, of course, of government negligence; the absence of an adequate manpower or labour training policy-will be dissipated by high inflation generated by that flow-on among other things and the contractionary economic policy which such a condition would inevitably evoke from this Government. In other words, the resource riches are in danger of being transformed not into rising material welfare but into rising unemployment and misery.

There are other related examples of the Commonwealth's abdication of power and responsibility in this area. Most notorious of all, especially in view of the fact that constitutional constraints have been raised as a problem in the application of a resources rent tax-constraints which are not insurmountable, but I do not have the time now to explain why-is the pathetic, craven abdication of power and responsibility last year by the Fraser Government under the territorial seas legislation when it transferred back to the States power over off-shore resources which the High Court of Australia had determined belonged to the Commonwealth. So we may see repeated in the area of territorial sea resource development the same self-destructive competition between States that we are witnessing now in respect of aluminium smelters.

The other glaring example of abdication of power was the decision in December 1978 of the Fraser Government to give the States virtually unlimited power to borrow both at home and abroad for infrastructure development. That was tantamount to a declaration of open season for irresponsible State borrowing. We did not have to look very far or to wait very long for examples of such irresponsible State borrowing. I refer to the World Trade Centre in Melbourne and, possibly before this decade is out, the staging of the Olympic Games in Melbourne. That declaration of open season for irresponsible borrowing by States underwrites the self-destructive competition between States for industries which would have located in Australia anyway.

Obviously the Government had no appreciation of what is required to manage the impending resources boom in the national interest. Its response to it is limited to gung-ho eulogising of what it believes will happen and the gutless surrendering of the national interest to foreign interests and to parochial State interests.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The proper development of Australia's resources for the economic benefit of all those concerned, having regard for environmental protection, as has been mentioned in this debate today requires the full co-operation of governments at all levels, industry and very importantly the trade union movement. I suggest that the Fraser Government has, since its return to the treasury bench, developed a climate whereby industry has been encouraged to get back to the job of developing Australia. The first and foremost requirement was to bring under some control the tremendous inflation rate that we inherited when we came into office. I think that is central to a government's responsibility of creating an economic environment in which development is encouraged to take place.

SPEECH.PARA: I have listened with interest to what the speakers have had to say in this debate. The question of foreign capital rose time and time again. I think it is proper for a government to be very careful about how foreign capital is to be used in Australia. I think the Government is aware of the need to survey and to continue a surveillance on the use of foreign capital. When debates of this type are taking place in this place I always think of the experience of the United States. The history of America shows that it used foreign investment very largely and almost entirely to develop the resources of that country which today is the most powerful industrial nation in the world. I cannot see anything wrong with encouraging the wise investment of foreign capital in this country to develop our resources.

In 1968 or 1969 I visited Gove. It was at a time when exploration was being carried out there and the exploitation of the minerals had not taken place. At that time I asked what the proposal was in respect of Australian equity. I was told that the Gorton Government policy required a 51 per cent Australian equity and that that was the objective. I went back a year or so later when mining had commenced and I examined the tremendous industrial growth that had occurred there. I again asked what Australian equity there was in the project. I was informed that the developers were able to get only 33 per cent from Australian sources and that the rest of the finance had to be attracted from Aluswiss. I have to ask the question: Why is this so?

The situation in Australia today seems to be that the savings banks have record savings in their vaults. Are we doing enough to encourage Australian people to take their money out of the banks and to invest it in the development of Australian companies and Australian resources? I think that is a question that is attracting the attention of the Government-it should attract the attention of the Government-in order to encourage more Australians to invest in their own country. I am not opposed to the discreet use of foreign investment provided that government has regard for the application of such investment and it makes sure that it gets appropriate taxes from the development companies to boost our revenue.

Since the Fraser Government has been in power it has done much to encourage the provision of infrastructure finance for various projects throughout Australia. I think it is quite firmly the Federal Government's responsibility to promote and to continue to encourage the provision of such finance. Last year the Federal Government decided to approve the infrastructure finance required for the Redcliff project in South Australia. This will entail the provision of a new power station which is under construction at the moment at Port Augusta. A wharf facility and the duplication of a pipeline from the Cooper Basin are also involved in that project. The housing requirements, which will have to be met by the State Government, and things of that nature are an intregal part of the development of this type of industry. I think the Federal Government has accepted that responsibility in other areas as well.

While I am talking about this matter I would like also to remind the trade union movement of its responsibility. It seems to me that when we are dealing with the development of uranium, which Senator Collard referred to earlier, we become frustrated by certain elements of the trade union movement. This attitude is certainly impeding the development of South Australia. We have quite large uranium deposits at Beverley and Honeymoon in the north-eastern part of the State, as well as the huge deposits at Olympic Dam on Roxby Downs station. Those projects will mean much to the development of South Australia and to the people who are at present looking for work in that State. That is an example of the type of development which will provide tremendous job opportunities not only directly but also indirectly.

The deposit I will highlight is the Beverley deposit. Senator Young is very familiar with this project. I believe that the mining of that deposit will be carried out by a leaching process whereby fluid is injected into the ore body and the ore is extracted, pumped out, in slurry form. I understand that can be done in a very short time span-from memory, in the order of two years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Less.

—Or probably less, as Senator Young reminds me. Associated with that project-and my figures from memory go back three or four years or perhaps even longer-was the contemplation of a requirement of $100m worth of plant to be prefabricated. Of course, that could be done at a place such as Whyalla or another of the northern Spencer Gulf industrial cities which would provide fringe benefits, indirect work opportunities, for those areas.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Olympic Dam project really gets off the ground-and there are about 250 people currently working there carrying out $58m worth of continuing exploratory work to establish the true nature and extent of the ore body-it will provide work opportunities for many hundreds of people. I understand from what I have heard from industrial sources and from State government sources that a town population of 35,000 to 40,000 people could live in that area. I think that sort of encouragement, given by the Government in the first instance in providing infrastructure requirements for those developments, has been provided quite responsibly by the Fraser Government. Apart from that, of course, we have provided money to ensure that adequate railway systems are available to connect South Australia to the Northern Territory. This will ultimately mean tremendous benefits to the development of mineral resources in not only South Australia but also the Northern Territory.

Another aspect that concerns me and perhaps others in this chamber is that governments need to recognise the necessity of providing additional financial assistance to local government in these growth centres. Mackay has been mentioned. I was at Port Augusta on Friday of last week to open a Commonwealth office which will provide regional headquarters for several departments and a service to the 27,000 people living in that area. The growth in that area over the next few years will be considerable. The added population will require additional services to be provided by local government. This matter certainly requires additional attention by the Federal and State governments. I think this would apply in many other growth centres throughout Australia. Whether or not this should be done by providing a long term, low interest loan or in some such way, I believe that is an urgent requirement which needs further attention by the Federal Government and the State governments concerned. I think that the debate has been quite interesting. I hope the Government will take note of some ideas that will flow from it. I move:
That the business of the day be called on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
