PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 27 November, on motion by Senator Davidson:
That the following Address-in-Reply be agreed to:

We, the Senate of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled, desire to express our loyalty to our Most Gracious Sovereign, and to thank Your Excellency for the Speech which you have been pleased to address to Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I have the pleasure of calling Senator Hearn, I indicate to honourable senators that this will be the honourable senator's first speech in this place. I trust that the usual courtesies observed on these occasions will be extended to the honourable senator. I have pleasure in calling Senator Hearn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hearn Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr President. I thank the Tasmanian Parliament for the confidence placed in me by appointing me to replace Ken Wriedt for the remainder of his term of office. I thank the people of Tasmania for the responsibility that they have entrusted to me to represent them in this Parliament. I feel very humble before the stature of a man such as Ken Wriedt. He is a caring and able man. He is a good man who has the respect of the whole community. He earned the approval of more than 70 per cent of farmers for his handling of the primary industry portfolio. His concern for peace was practical and balanced. He called for sanity, understanding and trust as a basis for world peace. The principle of a national superannuation scheme was written into Australian Labor Party policy on his initiative. It was a scheme which would contribute much to the security of people in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: My concern is for the people of Tasmania and the people of my country. Everywhere they are sacrificed to a system which puts economic values and profits before the value and potential of a human person. They are sacrificed to a system which has brought our world to the brink of catastrophy, which uses the riches of our earth, not to serve the needs of mankind, but to serve the greed of men who control large corporations. Our finite resources are wasted. Vast sums of money are spent on armaments while millions die of starvation each day. The world has, in kilograms per person, more explosives than food. Yet, it is not only the shortage of food which is the cause of hunger but the price that is put upon food.

During the last few decades, many groups of people and individuals have called for changes in values and priorities, values which put people first. At the United Nations Special Assembly on Disarmament in 1978, many groups, including doctors, scientists, churches, youth groups and women's organisations gave papers which expressed a great concern and tenderness for the human family. They expressed that anger that can sometimes be the greatest expression of love. I wish to read from a paper given by the union of 30 million Catholic women. It states:

We are deeply concerned by the cruelly inhibiting effect on development, produced over the years by the arms race and its spiralling technology. The expanding trade in increasingly sophisticated and expensive weaponry and huge military budgets. We believe that the basic security of people everywhere resides in the availability of food, health services shelter, education, employment and the wholesome, unpolluted environment. It is both irrational and immoral to commit almost half the world's scientific research and technological development to increasing the already unimaginable potential for total destruction. Disarmament is everyone's business. We would ask you to keep in mind that disarmament is a global right-to-life issue, that you are dealing with the future of unique, precious human beings, not abstractions.

All governments, including the Australian Government, were called upon to publicise widely to the people in their countries the declaration from that Assembly, in the hope that an international conscience might develop and that world public opinion might exercise a positive influence on disarmament. This has not happened. If we consider the money that is spent on armaments-as much money is spent on armaments in one hour as is spent on all the underprivileged children of the world in one year-surely it is a matter of shame. The recent North-South report commissioned by the United Nations and chaired by Willy Brandt called for radical, social and economic changes and showed what this could mean. Page 14 of that report states:

One-half of one percent of one-year's world military expenditure would pay for all the farm equipment needed to increase food production and approach self-sufficiency in food-deficit, low-income countries by 1990.
So it continues in like manner. In 1967 Pope Paul VI in his encyclical on the development of peoples, in speaking of the liberal society, said:

But it is unfortunate that on these new conditions of society a system has been constructed which considers profit as the key motive for economic progress, competition as the supreme law of economics, and private ownership of the means of production as an absolute right that has no limits and carries no corresponding social obligation. This unchecked liberalism leads to dictatorship rightly denounced by Pius VII as producing 'the international imperialism of money.' One cannot condemn such abuses too strongly by solemnly recalling, once again, that the economy is at the service of man.

These calls, also coming from Australian churches and welfare groups, are for the redirection and redistribution of wealth. As Australia approaches the bicentenary year of 1988 we must assess those things which we have achieved for future generations and we must seriously examine the failures during those 200 years. We must look at the aims and the aspirations of the early settlers and the hopes of those who came here in servitude. They hoped for a new society and a new life, free from the poverty, the injustices and the class distinctions that they had experienced. They wanted, more than anything, hope for the future of their children, the opportunity to work and build security and for a democratic society of justice, equality and human rights for everyone. The pioneering spirit, the courage to fight injustices and the comradeship which made life bearable in a new land are qualities which are still necessary now. Perhaps much of this has been lost. But perhaps much more of it is still in the souls of the Australian people and is expressed in the attitude of a fair go.

We who are here today, who are responsible for this time in history and the effects of our actions on future generations, must ensure that the hopes and the dreams of those early settlers are realised. We must be mindful of the hopes and the expectations of the later settlers who have made Australia their home and who have brought so much to our culture. We must ensure the rights of older people in our community to realise their hopes. Are the actions of government, which deny work to our young people in a country where there is so much work waiting to be done, actions which will kill their dreams and hopes for the future, for marriage and family and which deny the satisfaction of work, of security and of human dignity for the sake of the economy something which we can look upon with pride or with shame?

Working people are not to be discarded as an item of cost at the swing of an imbalanced market, because people have a right to work. The fact is that the declaration of the Assembly of the United Nations in December 1965 on the promotion amongst youth of the ideals of peace, mutual respect and understanding, expressed the recognition of the need for young people to have an assured future, that peace freedom and justice were among the chief guarantees that their desires for happiness would be fulfilled. The declaration also included the recognition that it is the young who are destined to guide the future of mankind and it is the young who should know respect for and develop a cultural heritage of their country. The fact is that this declaration has not been promoted by Australian governments, as requested by that assembly. This shows the disregard by government of the important place of youth in our community. Youth brings with it the spirit of the future, and we must ensure that there is a future. We educate, it is hoped, to give the capacity to think free from bias, to develop a creative potential of the human person and to give a clear and wide vision of the world in which the young have a part and a responsibility. The youth of today see a world where more than half of humanity is starving and the other half have much more than they need. How can they accept this as making sense and how can they respect the actions and the policies which have brought this about?

Is the exploitation of our natural resources, belonging to the inhabitants of this country, including the original Australians, and is the exploitation of our environment by overseas interests for their own profit something for which we feel pride or anger? Let us consider Alcoa in Western Australia, about which the Conservation Council of Western Australia said:

We'd argue that in fact the wages bill might well be outstripped by subsidies on things like gas and rail freight . . . and as far as corporate taxation is concerned Alcoa didn't pay any tax from 1964 through to 1978 in Australia and yet they made 276 million dollars profit . . .

Can the workers avoid paying tax for 14 years? Farmers in Western Australia are justified in their concern about the fall-out of fluoride from smelters destroying productive farmland. Should the Australian people's money be used to subsidise the huge infrastructure and to train the skilled workers needed to enable foreign corporations to exploit our raw materials which will then provide employment and profit in some country overseas? How does government assess what is in the national interest or people's interests when it gives approval for foreign companies to acquire Australian-owned industries? The recent takeover of a food company and a leading alternative energy resource group is cause for grave concern. Decisions could be made by foreign companies in the future which could affect the nutrition of Australian people and the development of new energy resources. These are basic needs of the Australian people and should surely be controlled by Australian interests. The greed of the men in control of corporations is destroying the enterprise and the initiative of small Australian business people. Is the fact that 60 per cent of wealth is owned by 10 per cent of the people a fulfilment of the dream of the early settlers? Is the fact that more than 2 million Australians live well below the poverty line and experience the denial of the right to food, housing, security and human dignity a matter of pride or shame?

This is the time when our nation must decide whether we continue to follow the path which puts the economy, and values of profit, property and materialism first or whether we follow the path which puts the human person, and the human values of equal rights, freedom and fraternity as our first priority. At a conference in 1980 on future directions for Australia there was a general acceptance that things must change to democratise our institutions, both corporate and government, and put people first in our goals as a nation. Only the latter path can give us true democracy. Democracy can flourish only when there are equal rights for all, when each person is enfranchised in the work place, in the community, as well as at the ballot box.

If the only motive in the work place is the economy, man merely becomes a cog in the machine. When working people have the democratic right to make decisions in the work place about issues which affect them and their community, such as technology, industrial health, child care, consumerism and the production of socially useful products, then there will be a real democracy. When members of a community, as individuals and collectively, have the conditions and the responsibility to participate in decision-making, then there will be democracy. Only when people have the knowledge and the freedom of information necessary to make correct judgments and choices can they use human intelligence to find the answers to the problems which society faces. How can people make decisions about Pine Gap if they do not know the facts? How can they judge the plant varietal rights issue when governments have been discussing it for 11 years and the people have known about it only in the last eight months? Only when people are able, as equals and in freedom, to work together for the common good, both in the community and in the work place, can we have a healthy economy. The economy, according to the Oxford Dictionary, is 'The administration of concerns and resources of a community-the theory of the production and distribution of wealth'. I would suggest that this Government's definition of the economy ignores the concerns of the community and shows bias in the distribution of wealth. We should not forget that the economy exists because of human ideas and human labour and the resources of nature working together to provide for the needs of people.

It is necessary that there be not only equal distribution of wealth but also a redirection of money towards people-orientated needs-the right use of taxpayers' money. Compared with the 10 per cent spent on health, the 27.4 per cent on social welfare and the 9.8 per cent for defence, the total of 2.4 per cent of the Budget allocated to housing, urban and regional development and the environment, culture and recreation is very small. A very large increase in this area would help to alleviate much of the health costs and the social costs in our community. It would also eliminate much misery and prevent the undermining of family well-being. This would lead to a much happier and healthier society. There are many examples of the inefficient use of people's money, the limited and uncertain funding for essential community services, such as family planning and child care services, that prevent them from making long term planning and efficiency. It is wasteful of the energies of voluntary groups in the community who work so hard in these areas and it is also wasteful of the taxpayers' money.

We are moving toward the year 2000. It is estimated that the percentage of elderly people of pensionable age will increase from 11.5 per cent now to 18.6 per cent in the year 2020. The work force percentage of the population, including the increasing amount of part time work, will increase from 44.5 per cent now to a possible 48.8 per cent in the year 2000. This increase of only 4 per cent will mean a much reduced tax base to support an increased demand for social welfare benefits. How can this greatly increased aging population be cared for in conditions of human dignity unless we direct the rich resources of this country to services and benefits? We have a debt to the elderly in our society for their contribution, and that debt has to be honoured.

One of the most disturbing events in recent years has been the attack on the trade unions in this country. Unionists are not a race apart; they are the fathers and mothers, the sons and daughters, the husbands and wives, the consumers and the producers in our society. They are the people who through struggle have raised the living standards of this country and whose labour has built this nation. It should not be forgotten that the fascist regimes of Hitler and Mussolini first attacked and decimated the trade union movement in order to take power and establish dictatorship. It is with great concern that we see this happening in our own country. The media and the Government continually publicise the days lost through strikes but they rarely mention those days lost through injury, work-induced illnesses and accidents although these often far exceed days lost through strikes. There is no mention of the days lost through unemployment or the resultant loss of productivity.

It will be said that the things I have spoken of are idealistic, impractical and emotional. But I believe that people are very practical if given the opportunity to use their experience of life and the freedom to use their skills. I think that ideals are both the mark of man and the inspiration for progress of humanity. They can be the cure for apathy. Women are considered to be emotional and I make no apology for that. I think it is the lack of emotion and the lack of emotional concern in male-dominated parliaments for human issues, which have allowed the problems facing the world at present to arise. The young people of our nation need not only economic solutions-which I believe will come from people themselves if people are placed first-but also ideas to inspire them; they need hope to encourage them and help to implement those ideas. They need a belief in humanity and a belief in themselves. They need a belief in the future. They need to know human dignity and human rights. They need a belief in peace, justice, freedom, love and generosity and reason and wisdom. We have a grave and vital reponsibility to the youth of our nation to ensure and protect the development of the creative human spirit in young people. They must not be crippled by the failures of government.

Members of this Parliament have been given responsibility by the people of their respective States to work for their well-being and the well-being of their children; they have not been given responsibility to work for the multinationals or for the profit or privilege of the few. I do not believe that that responsibility is being fulfilled by government. The shaping of our common future, the direction our people must take and the example our nation must give to our neighbours and the world are too important to be decided by government and bureaucratic experts alone. But the people of Australia must exercise their right to know the truth and to have the information and the facts presently denied. This will enable them to make correct judgments in their communities and in the Parliament. There must be an outflow of information and an input of the people's wishes and ideas in the light of this knowledge. The Government must find the machinery to enable this to happen. The human person is the highest value and must be our first consideration. I have the greatest faith in the wisdom and responsibility of an informed and democratically free Australian people to choose the way leading to peace and to the well-being and happiness for future generations and the way that might make our nation honoured when the pages of history are written. We must ensure that people have the opportunity in freedom and in knowledge to direct this country in that way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that all honourable senators congratulate Senator Jean Hearn on her maiden speech in this place. I know that many of us share the points of view that she expressed so clearly and well. I refer to her concern for people and for a just distribution of the nation's resources and to her statements on generosity, peace and other matters. In fact, I know that honourable senators from all parties come here with ideals and a very real concern for people. Warm sentiments such as those that Senator Hearn expressed then take the shape, according to our political philosophies, of hard particular policies that are very much the subject of debate in this chamber. Speaking on behalf of, I think, all honourable senators I welcome the first speech that Senator Hearn has made in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: In the Address-in-Reply debate, of course, we are directly responding to the Governor-General's Speech which he made when he came to open this Parliament. In his remarks in this chamber to the combined sitting of the House of Representatives and the Senate he referred to the policy speech last September of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and said that the Government's program was most particularly and specifically set out. He said that in his address to the Parliament he would refer in general terms to the broad issues to which the Government would address itself. In doing so he gave a further commitment that his Government-the Fraser Government-would fulfil during the period of this Parliament, all of its policy commitments as set out in the Prime Minister's policy speech of 30 September.

I believe that the Governor-General has brought a very real sense of prestige and ability to the position that he so ably fulfils. In coming here to speak in the Parliament he continued the high standard that he has set in his public activities throughout the nation. I have very high respect for Sir Zelman Cowen and I am grateful for the contribution he has made to Australian life and to the high office of Governor-General. At the same time I want to identify myself most particularly with the form of words before the Senate as the Address-in-Reply; that is, that we as senators express our loyalty to our Most Gracious Sovereign and thank His Excellency the Governor-General for the Speech which he was pleased to address to Parliament.

Last evening the Prime Minister and in this chamber the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Carrick, spoke directly about the engagement announcement of Prince Charles. I identify myself again with the expressions of loyalty to the sovereign and of joyfulness with the royal family in the happiness of that announcement. I think there are times such as this Address-in-Reply to the Governor-General's Speech when it is appropriate, not just in symbolic terms and not just by general reference, to note the strengths, the unity of purpose and the continuing momentum and tradition of our Australian origins that the monarchy supplies. The Queen of Australia is very much respected and looked to by the Australian people. On such an occasion as the Governor-General's Speech there are high emotions in the chamber when not only senators and members, packed in shoulder to shoulder on special seats added to the chamber, but also many guests and representatives of the diplomatic corps in Canberra are present. I can only say that it is a splendid occasion which is really a fitting beginning to a parliamentary session.

Of course, as a Liberal senator listening to that address by the Governor-General I was all the more heartened and encouraged because it was my party's and Government's program which the Governor-General was announcing. His reflections upon the direction of the Government's program for the coming three years were very much reflections on a program for which I had worked hard in the election period and which had been worked for through the high degree of consultation and dialogue which Ministers and back bench members pursued here in Canberra inside and outside the chamber and with the people of Australia. I like to think that I contributed some small part to the program which the Governor-General announced.

It is also usual on these occasions to make some reference to the election itself and to the immediate consequences in the re-arranged ministry. I regard the election result as another great win for the Fraser Government in terms similar to those of 1975 and 1977. This Government has now been elected most substantially and by very significant popular support at three elections in a row. There is, however, a tinge of disappointment in the actual result of the latest election in that I believe too many of our Liberal colleagues were defeated by very narrow margins. I believe 13 lost their seats. That is disappointing because I believe the Government's program, its legislative achievements and its fulfilment of policy promises were sufficient to have won it an even better result than the good result it achieved. As everyone may recall, in the early weeks of October there was a great deal of media speculation that the Government was even more directly threatened. I did not share that view. Nevertheless, I believe that in those first two weeks in October the Liberal campaign unfortunately did not sufficiently portray its strengths to the ordinary people of Australia.
Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner, in this Address-in-Reply debate I was reflecting on the election result of last October and noting that for the third time in succession the Fraser Government had been elected by an overwhelming popular vote. I also noted my smaller disappointment that some 13 colleagues, Liberal Party members of the Parliament, had lost their seats. I indicated that I believed that this was a loss for the Liberal Party beyond what should have been the result had we communicated the real strengths, the real achievements, the real policy gains, the real legislation that had been achieved in the preceding Parliament-not in the least comparable to the alternative program put forward by the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: There was a sense of disappointment that our success was not greater. I think the reason can be summarised by saying that we needed much more of a human face in the presentation of our policies to the people of Australia during the election campaign. It is all very well for me as a Liberal back bencher to be aware of the strengths of my own Government, of the Fraser Ministry, and to know that Liberal philosophies are being followed carefully in the foundation of what we are doing for the benefit of all Australians; but it is very important in the campaign context for those too readily assumed strengths of the Liberal Government actually to be communicated to the ordinary voters of Australia. This sense of identification by members of this Government team with ordinary people, communicating in ordinary language, should not involve too much grandstanding, should not involve our commending ourselves but rather should allow the natural dialogue and strength of our policies to become evident and allow the people to make their own judgment. I believe that had we been better at campaigning our policy strengths would have been better supported and perhaps my colleagues would not have lost their seats.

Of course in South Australia we had a particularly pleasing result in that whereas across Australia in first preference voting terms the average swing towards the Labor Party was 5.5 per cent, in South Australia it was only 1.8 per cent-the smallest swing in any of the Australian States. I believe that this was a direct result of the particular campaigns of Liberals in the House of Representatives and the Senate, not the least being those of Ian Wilson in the Sturt electorate and Grant Chapman in Kingston. Another contributing factor was the very real success of the Tonkin Liberal Government in its first 12 months in office. The identification of the State Premier of South Australia with the Federal campaign in October could not have been greater. He stood shoulder to shoulder with us in commending Liberal policies to South Australians. He was one of our most frequently used speakers in media advertisements. The confidence that the Premier of South Australia inspired in South Australians was, I believe, a factor in the very good result that we had in South Australia. In fact, in South Australia, in two party terms the swing was as low as 0.9 per cent compared with a two party preferred Australian average of 4.2 per cent. So once again, South Australia stood out as an area of very significant Government support.

Turning to the three by-elections held last Saturday, the South Australian vote was once again distinctive in that in the Boothby by-election there was a swing to the Government despite the long established track record of results at by-elections leading to swings against governments. The people know that a by-election will not lead to the fall of a government and they try to show some degree of criticism, some peppering of the government that is then in office. This happens whichever party is in power and it happens in any of the Western democracies. But in South Australia there was a swing to the Government and Steele Hall's result in Boothby is, I believe, further confirmation of support for him as a candidate, for the Liberal Party in South Australia and for the Fraser Government.

I turn now to the composition of the Ministry that was appointed following the election result. I support the decision of the Prime Minister to reduce the number of Ministers in that with the reduction of the Ministry by one and the re-arrangement of portfolios into a more rational grouping, we have a smaller government and a trend towards making sure that we fulfil our Liberal principle of opposing big government and of getting decisions made closer to the people. The welcome change to the composition of the Ministry meant that the Senate now has six Ministers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very good ones.

—As Senator Chaney notes, they are very good ones. I point out that not only have Senator Baume and Senator Messner been appointed to the Ministry as a result of the election but also Senator Chaney has joined two other Senate Ministers in the Cabinet. So, as a result of Liberal senators' strong requests to the Government, the number of senators in the Ministry has been increased from four to six and the number of Senate Ministers in the Cabinet has been increased from two to three. This is a welcome change and I urge the Government to add another senator at each point of restructuring the Ministry so that in the not too distant future one-third of the Ministry is comprised of members of this chamber. This clearly is the path for the Government to follow in the involvement of Ministers from the Senate. It does not agree with the minority point of view that some honourable senators genuinely hold that there be no Ministers in the Senate. I am one of those who are very much opposed to this so-called reform that would take Ministers out of this chamber, this half of the Parliament. I believe that in the debates of this chamber Ministers bring a sense of direct responsibility in what we talk about and a direct answerability on the part of the Executive Government under question from senators. This makes it a much more realistic and responsible chamber for debate. If there were no Ministers in this chamber it would become a debating hothouse in which all manner of topics could be discussed without our really engaging in the practical responsibility of governing this country. I believe that strongly and I welcome this trend in the rearrangements of the Ministry following the election whereby there has been a substantial increase in the number of Senate Ministers.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the Governor-General's Speech itself. He spoke of the key elements of the Prime Minister's policy speech and outlined five areas in particular; youth employment, the economy, caring for people, the Public Service and, finally, foreign affairs and defence. Briefly, in the time available to me, I think it would be profitable to add some comments of my own to each of those five areas. Youth unemployment is clearly the most tragic social problem facing our country, and that is why it has received maximum priority in the policy decisions of the Government. The programs of assistance for transition to employment, to encourage employers to take on apprentices and other employees, the present review calling for public consideration of better ways of helping under 18-year olds than simply giving them the dole hand-out, are examples of responsible initiative by the Government which I support.

There was an immediate reaction by a few in the community who said: 'What a scandal. After the difficulties which unemployed youth have suffered in these years, to take the dole away from them is cruel and horrendous'. I believe they are short-sighted and are superficial in their reaction to what in fact was an alternative announcement by the Government. Surely we must be able to do much better for those unemployed under the age of 18 years than allow them to remain as dole receivers. So I believe we must give very careful public attention and seek the views of every area of the community as to how we can improve the transition scheme and other schemes for better assisting unemployed youth.

One view which I have held for many years now is that unemployed young people do not have a fair go in Australia in competing with adults in trying to gain jobs in the market-place. When a school leaver-perhaps seeking an unskilled job, of which there are fewer and fewer-goes to an employer and applies for a job, he competes with middle-aged women, with adults in their twenties, thirties, or even in their fifties who, in many cases, have a degree of maturity, skill and stability. Those qualities may well lead the employer overwhelmingly to choose the more mature, more reliable and more skilled applicant. Therefore, the young person who has to compete for that job is not getting a fair go. He is not able to say: 'I want to receive 80 per cent of an adult wage for six months in order that I may gain some skills, some experience, and may learn from my involvement in this company so that I can then say to an employer that I am worth the full wage'. I believe we need to see a restructuring of wages so that young people can get a fair go and can compete in the market-place.

The Governor-General talked about the economy, the importance of restoring healthy economic growth, of maintaining, as a first priority, the fight against inflation and of encouraging the private sector. The Governor-General said:

My Government will give particular attention to encouraging the growth of the private sector and to increasing the freedom of choice of taxpayers in spending their own incomes. It will be an important policy objective to continue to restrain public expenditure so as to provide scope for reducing the burden of taxation.

The emphasis in those words was on reducing public expenditure, and I believe that is the realistic option before the Government in this parliamentary period in order to reduce the burden of taxation. The Government has already made decisions this week that the alternative options of an indirect tax, whether a retail tax, a wholesale tax or some other form of indirect tax, have inflationary consequences which would outweigh the benefits of their being introduced and would have complications in terms of the timing of their introduction and the machinery for their implementation.

The real alternative, to gain the kind of tax relief that so many Australians seek, is to ensure that public expenditure comes under increased scrutiny and that we see careful economising in the area of the present Commonwealth Government programs. The committee which has been set up to review the functions of government and which has been called the razor gang still, despite media rumouring, will present a hard hitting, careful assessment of those functions which need to be eliminated, those functions which need to be reduced, those functions which need to be transferred to the public sector or those functions which need to be transferred to the States. It will be seen in the coming weeks what that committee of review brings to the Cabinet and what the Cabinet decides on Sir Phillip Lynch's committee's recommendations. I believe the findings of that committee should not be razor thin, as the media speculate, but should truly be evaluations of those functions which we need to re-arrange to economise on our expenditure and to fulfil more faithfully our responsibilities as the Commonwealth Government.
The Governor-General's address directly referred to caring for people and in particular referred to Australian families. He said:

My Government has already introduced a number of measures designed to assist families. It will be looking closely at its policies with the objective of further enhancing the position of Australian families.

I believe the first of the two reforms that should most capture the Government's attention to fulfil that statement of intention by the Governor-General should be the actual achievement of the income-splitting proposal which was put forward by a back bench committee of Liberals in the Parliament, chaired by Ian Wilson. Secondly, the Government should substantially increase the family allowance so that it more than catches up with its previous purchasing power which has been eroded by inflation since it was introduced in 1976. This means that it is now of much less value to families than it was when it was first introduced. I continue to welcome the Fraser Government's introduction of the family allowance and I believe it should be substantially increased. I am aware that earlier tonight I talked about expenditure restraint and about easing the taxation burden. The only way in which the family allowance can be increased with real equity and the only way in which personal income tax can be reduced, I believe, is for the family allowance to be part of taxable income. (Quorum formed).

The fourth area to which the Governor-General referred was the Public Service. He was quick to acknowledge that the Government appreciates the contribution which the Public Service as a whole makes to the life of this country. Nevertheless, there needs to be a review of the functions with which the Public Service is directly involved. With that in mind I wish to underline the need, as I see it, to review the superannuation provisions for public servants under the Commonwealth Superannuation Act and under the Parliamentary Retiring Allowances (Increases) Act so that the superannuation provisions of the Commonwealth are much more in line with the ability of the community to pay in every area of Australian life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Governor-General's Speech, which lays down in very broad outline the program of the Fraser Government for the next three years. I wish to give most of my attention to what has happened since the Governor-General's Speech was delivered. On 5 December last year the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) sought to give some philosophical underpinning, if I may use that grandiose phrase, to what in the words of Gilbert and Sullivan might otherwise be described as 'a bald and unconvincing narrative'. In a sense it was an attempt to create order out of chaos, to offer Liberal members of Parliament some understanding of what they are all about, a feeling which has clearly eluded them over recent months. In Adelaide on 5 December the unhappy Senator Chaney had to deliver a speech on behalf of the Prime Minister to a gaggle of the Liberal Party faithful.
—It was one of the best turn-outs we have seen at a function in South Australia.

—I am told that it was a very well-attended function. It was a sea of blue rinse, I can imagine. Senator Chaney was the unhappy mouthpiece unveiling the latest wisdom. I use the expression 'mouthpiece' advisedly, reminding myself of the American underworld phrase 'If you get the right mouthpiece you will get the electric chair'. Unfortunately, the unhappy Senator Chaney got the electric chair just a few months later. I do not wish to dwell on the details of the speech which was given by Senator Chaney on behalf of the Prime Minister on 5 December. To dwell on the details would be tedious indeed. I wish to concentrate on what I might euphemistically call the highlights of the speech, if there were any such things. Let me begin by quoting the opening paragraph of the speech, which, of course, is very significant. The Prime Minister said, through Senator Chaney:

SPEECH.PARA: At the conclusion of his address to parliament, the Governor-General indicated that the Government believes that it is important to explain to the Australian people the philosophy which shapes its policies and actions. This seems an excellent opportunity to make a start.

That is what the speech is all about. In the speech there is a reference, which borrows freely from American political history, to what Liberal Party people describe as self-evident truths-things which are self-evident to members of the Liberal Party but which are clearly evident to no-one else in Australian society. That is what the speech is all about. It is designed to explain to Australians the self-evident truths which are so apparent to members of the Liberal Government.

The speech is high on questions such as the importance of freedom of choice, a concept with which I would think no member of this Parliament particularly disagrees. There are thinly veiled references to the grey socialist societies of the Northern Hemisphere. I do not think that anybody in this chamber seriously disagrees with this strongly argued concept of freedom of choice. But what is ignored throughout the speech is what these concepts mean in reality in the context of the Governor-General's Speech. One is entitled to ask: What choices are available in Malcolm Fraser's brave new world of 1981 which were not available in Australian society previously and to whom are these new choices available? What choices, one is entitled to ask, as a result of five years of Fraser Government are available to the unemployed? What new choices are available to the sick, particularly the uninsured sick? What new choices are available to the uneducated as a result of the policies enunciated in the Governor-General's Speech and the previous five years of government? What new choices are available to young people in Australian society? Are there more or fewer choices? Is there a widening or a reduction in the range of choices for the average Australian? What the speech has to say about freedom of choice was interesting, but what does it all mean? It goes on to talk about beliefs in checks and balances. We are not told to which checks and balances it refers but interestingly we are told the following:
It--
That is, liberalism-
believes that society is healthier . . . when responsibility, enterprise and power are spread widely throughout the community rather than concentrated in one or a few places.
That is the ideal to be aimed at and any deviation from it requires special justification.

That is an old story but, again, what does it mean? What does the whole notion of checks and balances mean in terms of the relationships between State and Federal governments in Australia? What does it mean in respect of thousands of small businessmen, when we have the highest number of bankruptcies amongst small businessmen in the history of this country? What does the concept of checks and balances mean to them? What does it mean out of the mouths of members of a government which has cut the budget and the staff of the Trade Practices Commission by 20 per cent in real terms and which has amended the legislation to make it less effective in terms of monopoly in Australia? What does the notion of responsibility and enterprise being spread amongst a number of people in a healthy society mean in respect of all those actions of government?

In this chamber this afternoon Senator Jessop expressed his profound admiration for American society. I have a degree of admiration for American society but the things about it which I admire most are the things which we just do not have here in Malcolm Fraser's brave new world. We do not have real trade practices legislation or freedom of information legislation in an effective sense and we have none of the mechanisms for making competition in private enterprise vigorous and really working in an effective sense in this country. Whenever this Government is confronted with those desirable ideals about which it talks it backs off in favour of its great and powerful friends in the corporate sector, who really do not believe in vigorous freedom of enterprise, vigorous competition, real trade practices legislation, freedom of information legislation and things of that kind as the Americans do.

What does this sort of thing mean when it comes from the Fraser Government? What does it mean in terms of freedom of information and trade practices? What does it mean in respect of the system of broadcasting in Australia and the newspaper industry in Australia? What does it mean when the State of Victoria has to have a public inquiry into media ownership in that State because people are very concerned about it? What does it mean in respect of the Government's rumoured commitment to changing the broadcasting legislation in order to help the companies of one particular great and powerful proprietor? I now quote from a very distinguished authority on this question. I refer to none other than Mr Rupert Murdoch who in an interview with More magazine in the United States of America in 1977 stated:
I think it would be a pity if I grew any bigger in Australia . . . That would be against the public interest.

Six months ago a body which had been established by this Government to police the public interest found that Mr Murdoch's enterprise's getting bigger in Australia was against the public interest. That body acted on Mr Murdoch's own advice of 1977 and said it would not be in the public interest for him to get bigger in Australia. This present Government is now about the task of amending the legislation as a consequence of that decision to try to get him off the hook. That is inconsistent with his own philosophy of 1977, is inconsistent with the philosophy of the Liberal Party of Australia throughout the years of this century since broadcasting began, and is totally inconsistent with the garbage contained in the speech delivered by Senator Chaney on behalf of the Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you agree with the principle in the speech?

—I have a lot of agreement with the principle. I think it is a very sound one, but it is absolute hogwash to say that this Government is bent in any real way on carrying out that principle in its legislation. That is the matter about which I believe we have to be concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: A section in the speech deals with the benefits of private enterprise to Australian society and the benefits of private property. Nobody in this Parliament takes issue with the importance of that point as a matter for serious political discussion. It is of no use the Prime Minister rushing around tilting at Leonid Brezhnev, because he is not a member of the Australian Parliament. We do not have to deal with him. Nobody is particularly concerned about him. The subject of debate surely is: What are the desirable limitations on unrestricted private ownership, what are the benefits to Australian society of private enterprise and private property, and what are the things which derogate from the public good in terms of the application of private enterprise? There is no mention of that in the speech.

The speech went on to say, in what I would have thought was a piece of lightly dancing over the truth historically, that private enterprise is responsible for unprecedented improvement in human conditions over the last 30 years. I would have thought that that was an oversimplification. That is one proposition which would be difficult to sell in the People's Republic of China where there has been considerable progress over the last 30 years without the benefit of private enterprise and it is one proposition which I think would be difficult to sell in the social democratic countries of Western Europe where there is both private and government enterprise working side by side in a balanced relationship. Of course it is very interesting that throughout this speech, which espouses the Fraser Government's philosophy for the 1980s, the social democratic societies of the Western world are completely ignored. Sweden, for example, is a society which is ignored. No mention is made of the balance between private and government enterprise in a country such as Sweden.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or of the taxation levels.

—I would not be too sure about knocking those. I suppose the honourable senator will tell us next about the suicide rates. I suspect that that country just keeps better statistics than we do in Australia.
—Because it is a very small, compact country.

—With no resources at all compared with this country. That is the important point. When a person talks about private enterprise being the basis and the condition for the establishment of a free society and ignore a society such as Sweden, he is talking a lot of rubbish because Sweden has had freedom of information legislation for 150 years. This lily-livered Senate is still messing around with a sort of milksop version of what that country has had for donkey's years. I would have thought that in a sophisticated community these were the ingredients of a society in which freedom was allowed to run as far as possible. They are not based necessarily on private enterprise.

SPEECH.PARA: If one were to look at the question of the social democratic societies of the Western world one should surely see that the political debate in Australia should not be directed at these absurdly ideological questions of whether private enterprise is all good and public enterprise is all bad or whether public enterprise is all good and private enterprise is all bad. What we should be looking at is the nature of the sort of mixed economy which would best serve the Australian community. In the present debate we have heard this blind ideological discussion where corporate raiders of the private enterprise sector look at the public enterprise sector in Australia and say: 'We will have that nice lucrative bit of Telecom's work. We will have road transport but we will not have the railways. We will have a bit of the airlines but we will not have the difficult routes which are expensive to operate. We will have the best bits everywhere and then we will be able to say, ''My God, are we not efficient because we have the profitable bits of all the enterprises in Australia''.'

That is what the argument in this country should be about. The argument should be about the sort of mixed economy that a country such as Australia should have. It should not be based on the blinkered ideological rubbish, which is apparent in the newspapers at the moment, which has been created within the environment by the Fraser Government. The sharks of Australian industry feel they can grab the most lucrative bits for themselves in this laissez-faire environment-this absence of leadership-which has been created by the Federal Government. I make my point in the terms of a very distinguished writer, Fred Hirsch, who was the author of a very important book entitled Social Limits to Growth. He summarised the point I am trying to make with the following words:
The principle of self-interest is incomplete as a social organising device. It operates efficiently only in tandem with strong supporting social principles.

We need strong supporting social principles in this country. We will not get them from the private sector. We never have. The private sector is based on self-interest. We will get them from governments which are enlightened and thoughtful about the issues which I have been attempting to discuss. In this very important speech I wish to quote a passage which sets out the virtues of private property. The Prime Minister had this to say:

It spreads throughout society the habits of free activity-the ownership of property, the disposal of one's own income by freely made decisions, the right to decide between security of employment and the risks and rewards of entrepreneurship, the freedom to enter into voluntary contracts.

According to the Prime Minister, these are some of the things which spread like some healthy virus from private enterprises. Let us ask ourselves again: What percentage of the Australian people have those freedoms which he enumerates in that passage-the freedom to spend one's money as one wants, the freedom to enter into entrepreneurial activities, the freedom to own property as one wants, the freedom to make decisions between security of employment and other matters? What sorts of freedoms are available as a result of five years of Fraser Government? How are they better? What are the choices? I might quote from the great poet, T. S. Eliot, when he said:
Human kind
Cannot bear very much reality.
He should have met Malcolm Fraser because, not to put too fine a point on it, that is the understatement of the century when applied to this Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think he had in mind some of your people when he wrote about the bang and the whimper?

—He was a versatile man. A range of things can be applied to all sorts of people. But when one looks at that proposition about the benefits of free enterprise and sees unemployment which is at a record high level, the sorts of choices offered to those people, the fact that family living standards are much lower than they were when the Fraser Government came to power, the fact that taxation is much higher, the fact that we have the highest poverty level for years and the fact that welfare services are in disarray, one must ask what sort of balances are there in all these things to which the Prime Minister can address his mind. Of course the truth of the matter is that the Prime Minister did not write this speech at all or address his mind to any of these issues. I will come to that in a moment.
—I read it.

—I know you have read it, Senator Chaney, but I am telling you that the Prime Minister did not write it. I do not know whether I have sufficient time to examine the nice little passage on the role of the State. The role of the State under this Government has not declined at all. Sixty-four expensive promises which were made in the last election will increase the role of the Federal Government in Australia. Look at what has happened over the last five years. All that has happened is that powers which previously were exercised by the national government have been diverted to the States. The State public services have mushroomed while the Federal Public Service has remained static. That is not much of an achievement in dealing with the role of the State as the Prime Minister has expressed it in this speech.

SPEECH.PARA: The next principle dealt with by Senator Chaney in delivering this speech was what is called the principle of 'Conservatism'. There is a very eloquent and high-sounding statement on the principle of conservatism in this speech. It is summarised in the passage which reads:
Conservatism on the other hand stresses the need for a framework of stability, continuity and order, not only as something desirable in itself but as a necessary condition for a free society.

Speaking only for myself, I do not have much difficulty in agreeing with that proposition. Conservatism does have some very important values to offer to a society, particularly a society undergoing rapid change. In fact, this is a very sound expression of traditional conservative principle. But where is the stability, the order and the continuity in the policies of this Government which the principle of conservatism espouses? Where are all those things? Where is the continuity, the order and the stability in the resources boom which is taking place in Australia? Where is the continuity, the order and the stability in the relationships between State and Federal governments? Where is the continuity, the order and the stability in the delivery of health services and other services to the Australian people? Where is the stability, the continuity and the order in the manufacturing sector of Australian industry? All these questions loom very large in a speech which is not related to the realities of the society of Malcolm Fraser in 1981. It is a speech dealing with a fantasy world. The fascinating thing about this speech is that throughout it there is no reference to equality. The word 'equality' is not used. The word 'freedom' is used again and again. What I suspect is meant by 'freedom' in the context of this speech is the freedom to make as much money as you like if you have the opportunities without running the risk of paying death duties or probate duty, without running the risk of paying a capital gains tax or a wealth tax and without running the risk of clamp downs on your tax avoidance schemes. Those are the sorts of freedoms which have been talked about in this speech if there is no reference to equality. Let me put it in these terms. There is not even any reference to the concept of equality of opportunity.

Without some reference to the relationship between equality and freedom the concept of freedom is meaningless to the Australian people for whom this speech is meant to be of benefit in understanding what this Government is doing. If you believe in freedom to work but there is no equality of opportunity to work, if you are unemployed, for example, it is a meaningless freedom. If you believe in the freedom to spend money-bearing in mind that 2 million of our population have not enough money to spend-freedom to spend money means nothing because there is no equality. That is the most extraordinary omission in the speech. If you believe, for example, in freedom from fear-and half the population of this country, many poor people, are uninsured in respect of medical and health services-there is no freedom of fear because there is no equality. That is why the Labor Party sought in years gone by to introduce a universal health service in this country. If you believe in freedom before the law, as I think we all do, and there is no adequate legal aid system, there is no freedom before the law because there is no equality. Freedom and equality in terms of political concepts are very closely bound, very closely interwoven. They are the essential ingredients of the good life to which all Australians are entitled.

The speech given on 5 December in Adelaide by Senator Chaney on behalf of the Prime Minister made no reference to those things. This point is very interesting because a comparison of the speech with the Liberal Party platform reveals that the platform is full of talk about equality of opportunity, for example. Anyone who looks at Senator Puplick's seminal little work called Liberal Thinking-the little blue book-will find a whole chapter on the question of equality. Although I have my differences with Senator Puplick I admit that he knows what it is about. The section on equality begins by saying this: 'From what we have said about dignity and freedom it follows that the concept of equality will always play a central role in any liberal philosophy. We all of us have an equal claim for our dignity to be respected and are entitled to receive equal consideration from governments and to be held in an equal position with all other citizens before the law'. And so it goes on. Of course that is, if I might say so, the basic tradition of the Liberal Party which became a very thin strand in the speech of 5 December which is described as the philosophical basis of the Liberal Party.

There is nothing in the speech about the relationship between equality and freedom. One must ask the question: Why not? I will tell honourable senators why not. It is because the Liberal Party, the great Liberal Party of old Bob Menzies and young Chris Puplick, has been hijacked by a bunch of B-grade academics from red brick universities. That is what has happened. The great Liberal Party of the past has been hijacked by a collection of academics. What has happened is that the academics have written all this stuff for the Prime Minister. I can see him asking Owen Harries in December: 'For God's sake, what are we doing here? What is it all about? Can you put something down on paper for us?' Off he went to put down on paper this unreal garbage which has nothing to do with the record or the program of the Fraser Government at all; nothing to do with the great traditions of the Liberal Party of Bob Menzies and Chris Puplick to which I have referred.

I hope that by referring to this matter the Liberal Party speakers, in the months ahead, will frequently quote from this speech given on behalf of the Prime Minister on 5 December-'The Philosophical Basis of Liberalism' for goodness sake! When they read that speech they will know what they are on about; they will understand what it is all about, what they are doing here and what they are getting paid for. All those things will come back to them. When the Liberal Government takes away the dole from young kids its supporters will be able to give us a lecture about what this means in terms of freedom of choice for young Australians-new freedoms of choice introduced by the Fraser Government! When the Liberals have a few tensions in their party they will be able to quote this passage:
There is always a certain tension involved between liberalism and conservatism. Liberalism always emphasises the freedom of the individual.

So if honourable senators opposite get a few tensions they will be able to quote from that passage to tell us all about them. When they introduce broadcasting legislation to help Mr Rupert Murdoch they will be able to tell us how much they believe about the division of power in Australian society, the desirability of division of power and polycentric power as distinct from centralist power.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some of us will.

—Honourable senators opposite will be able to tell us all those things. I hope you will, Senator Puplick. When the Government introduces yet another change to Australian health services it will be able to tell us about the conservative principle of order in Australian society which is stressed so much in this speech. At the end of it all I suppose we will all be in an even bigger mess than we are now. Let me give honourable senators opposite a bit of advice: Stick to the old pragmatic survival stuff and do not start to mess around with philosophy. That would be very dangerous for a party such as theirs. At the moment it is a time to face realities. There is a yawning gap between all this waffle in this speech and the reality of the Governor-General's Speech. For those reasons, on behalf of the Opposition I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following words be added to the Address- in-Reply:
'but the Senate is of the opinion that the Government-
(1) Has failed to adequately respond to:
(a) record unemployment;
(b) a high and worsening level of inflation;
(c) reduced and falling family living standards; and
(d) the highest taxation burden in the nation's history;
(2) Allows unsatisfactory administration of foreign investment guidelines which permit an uncritical and open-door policy to the takeover of Australian industry and resources to continue; and

(3) Makes no long-term provision for assistance to manufacturing industry and farming industries, which are likely to be severely disadvantaged as a result of successive exchange rate revaluations and substantially increased imports in the context of resources development'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise in this chamber the subject once again that I raised during Question Time yesterday with the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) regarding the Aborigines who had been evicted from Gordon Downs station. I think it is important that I read into the Hansard the response from the Minister to show that somewhere along the line there has been either a misunderstanding or perhaps a mishandling of the truth. I have grave fears that it is the latter rather than the former. I asked the Minister:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . what action will be taken by the Federal Government in the future to safeguard Aboriginal rights in relation to traditional homes on station properties, particularly in the State of Western Australia.

I asked the Minister what action would be taken as a result of the report of the officer of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs who had supposedly gone to speak to the 50 members of the Gordon Downs Aboriginal community who had been expelled from that station. In response Senator Baume said:

An officer of my Department did go to the area and did consult with the Aboriginal people. It has been quite difficult in the last few weeks, because of the wet, to travel in the area around Halls Creek to get to Gordon Downs and to complete the consultation. Although Aboriginals have a right of entry on to pastoral stations in Western Australia, the pastoralists are not compelled to provide services or accommodation for them. The matter of the people from Gordon Downs is properly one for the Western Australian Government.
After some interjections, in a supplementary question I asked:
Is the site chosen by the group to which the Minister is referring known as Ringers Soak? If so, it has nothing whatsoever to do with the community that I am talking about from Gordon Downs.
I am quoting from page 15 of the Hansard of 24 February. The Minister responded:

I have been advised by my officers who have been in the area and who have spoken to the Aboriginals that the answer I gave is correct-that the Aboriginal people who were so cruelly expelled from Gordon Downs do not wish to return to the station and that they do wish to settle at the site chosen by the group, a site called Yaruman or Ringers Soak. That is my advice. I have no reason to doubt that it is correct.

This afternoon a member of my staff spoke to people in the area where these people from Gordon Downs are now staying, that is, in the Halls Creek area. The Minister admitted that it has been quite difficult during the past few weeks because of the wet to travel in the area of Halls Creek.

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't admit it; I asserted it.
—I am very pleased that the Minister is in charge of the House at the moment because I would like his response to some of the questions I will raise.
—Why didn't you tell me you were going to speak?

—I did advise the Minister's office. I advised the Minister's office at 5.10 this afternoon that I would be the third speaker after the suspension of the sitting for dinner. If the Minister has not received that message I can suggest only that the officials in his office in Parliament House are working no more efficiently than the officials in his Department in Western Australia, if the information he gave to this chamber yesterday, as he asserts, is correct. At the moment the people from Gordon Downs are still living in deplorable conditions in the Halls Creek area. They have been provided with tents and canvasses. They did not make any mention of any provision of food. They are living in wet and swampy conditions. They have inadequate ablution provisions, and the whole scene at the moment is deplorable. At the moment they consider that they will have to move to higher rocky ground to escape the mud and the wet. They have problems with other people bringing alcohol in amongst their community. This is something that did not apply when they were living on the Gordon Downs station. They are concerned that they will have to move away from that area if they cannot get to Ringers Soak very shortly, simply because of the alcohol problem and so that they can remain together. I am assured that their main concern is to get land so that they can restructure their community. That is the first point. They are at present living in deplorable conditions in the Halls Creek area.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the second part of the answer which the Minister gave me yesterday. He said:

. . . that the Aboriginal people who were so cruelly expelled from Gordon Downs do not wish to return to the station and that they do wish to settle at the site chosen by the group, a site called Yaruman or Ringers Soak.

My information is that they have been offered-not that they want to go to Ringers Soak-a small portion of land at Ringers Soak officially designated as a temporary site. I am also given to understand that that could mean a period of as little as 12 months which means that at the end of that time they then have to move their entire community just so that they can stay together. The Government can now say: 'Well, we are not going to provide you with any necessities because you are going to be here for a short time only. You are still on a temporary site'. Anybody who has lived in Western Australia knows what happens to temporary sites in that State because of the political attitude of the Western Australian Government. Senator Kilgariff is in the chamber also, and I would suggest that he should be well aware of the temporary site situations in the Northern Territory. Many of them have been turned into permanent situations where the Aboriginal people have not had the opportunity to get back to their own land.

I asked the Minister whether this site had been chosen by the group. He said that he had been assured that it had been chosen by the group. I am equally assured that it was not chosen; it was offered. In my visits to the Kimberleys-I go there fairly frequently-during 1979 and 1980 I was constantly being asked what was happening to the applications that had been made by this community for the State Government to excise part of the Gordon Downs station. I think I should make the point that what they wanted was a small strip of land on the southern part of Gordon Downs, a part of a pastoral lease known as Coronado to the north of that leasehold and some vacant Crown land which would have provided them with a reasonable amount of land and a viable amount of land for pastoral activities. That application was rejected because, according to an article in the West Australian of 31 January this year, there happens to be uranium exploration in the area. So, what is new? The article reported what the Minister for Lands in the State Parliament, Mr Wordsworth, said. The article stated:
. . . the exploration was one of the reasons why he had rejected a special lease application from the community last year.

However, Mr Wordsworth said that temporary reserves for uranium in the area would not affect any government plans to establish a settlement on a smaller piece of vacant Crown land around Ringers Soak.

He did not tell us whether the vacant Crown land around Ringers Soak is a viable pastoral leasehold for these people to go to and try to become independent and to keep their community together in conditions that they consider to be safe. But he continued:
It was government policy that pastoral leases remain as intact, viable economic units.

He did not make any mention of the fact that Coronado is held by absent leaseholders, that there has been no improvement, and that it has not been worked as a pastoral property for some time. The article went on:
Mr Wordsworth said that the Government had dropped its policy of stopping the granting of pastoral leases to Aboriginal groups. The policy had been instituted during the Noonkanbah dispute.

In other words, during that massive dispute that we had in Western Australia last year, the State Government moved to stop granting pastoral leases to Aboriginals per se. It stopped entirely. Incidentally, that article went on to say that that community asked the Minister, Mr Wordsworth, to reconsider its application for the excision of land from both Coronado and Gordon Downs and the application that it had put in for the small amount of Crown land that was necessary. The article continued:

It claimed that the area it wanted from Gordon Downs was of little economic importance to the station; that Coronado was held by absent and unproductive lease-holders and had never been developed; and that it could be resumed technically because of non-compliance with the lease covenants.
The letter said that the community comprised members of the Djaru people who wanted the land to allow them to re-establish control over important sacred sites.

We have had many debates in this place and in the other chamber about sacred sites, sites of significance and traditional land. In a little while I will read into the record the Western Australian Acting Premier's reference to traditional land. It does not seem to have occurred to anybody that sacred sites, sites of significance and traditional land, depending entirely on who is using those phrases, could mean one and the same thing. The white man's term does not necessarily apply to the black man's language.

Also in the newspaper appeared a few words from Mr Hassell, the Minister for Community Welfare. Mr Hassell has not had a particularly good record in community welfare in Western Australia. He has been quoted as having said that he will wash his hands of the whole affair because he does not really want the bother of tracking down the leaseholder of Gordon Downs into the Northern Territory where, apparently, Mr Sherwin resides. I will come to that in a little while. In the first instance, I think it is rather important to give a detailed account of the whole matter. Whilst the Press in Western Australia have played a magnificent role in this instance-I admit to having been very critical of the role of the print media in particular on a number of occasions in this place-I want to say that I congratulate it on the handling of this matter. It has made the people of Western Australia aware of what has happened to this community. It is continuing to apply pressure to ensure that something is done to try to counteract the reputation that Western Australia has gained over the Noonkanbah debacle last year and the attitude that has been constantly expressed by members of the Ministry in the State Government. I want to make it quite clear that it was 13 days after the expulsion before even the Press was aware that this had happened. I suppose that that 13 day gap could be said to have been the fault of the Aboriginal community because it was concerned that if it was learned that the community was not on the property some mischief could have been done to what could be called its sacred sites, its traditional land, its site of significance.

An article on the front page of the West Australian on 15 January under the heading 'Aborigines told to go', pointed out that the new owners of the Gordon Downs station property had been told to leave. It does not give any reason because no reason is known even now, as far as I know. The article states:
About 55 members of the community-including eight old men-are living in poor conditions in Halls Creek . . .

At that stage they were living in poor conditions at Halls Creek. I have already told the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs that when I spoke to people in the area this afternoon I was told they were still living in poor conditions in Halls Creek. They have been there now since just after 2 January. It is about time someone got off his bottom and made sure that their conditions were a little better than poor. The article continues:
Many of the people were born on the station. Some of the men have spent all of their working lives there as stockmen.
It is understood that up to 100 Aborigines have been living on the station. Some of the men are travelling to ceremonies and others have gone to the Aboriginal community at Balgo mission.
A Northern Territory pastoralist, Mr Peter Sherwin, took over the Gordon Downs lease from the British Vestey group in the middle of last year.
Mrs Sherwin said yesterday that her husband was not available for comment.

The article stated that the new member for the Kimberleys, Mr Bridge, was endeavouring to raise the matter with the Federal Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in Perth on that same day. I understand the Minister was appearing at the summer school at the West Australian University. Whether he actually spoke to Mr Bridge or not I do not know. But it is important to point out to the chamber that Mr Bridge has an Aboriginal background. He has lived in the area for many years. His family has lived there. He knows Halls Creek and he knows the Aboriginal communities. What he would have to say about the Gordon Downs situation would be based on his personal knowledge. The article on 15 January continues:

An adviser to the Aboriginal communities in the Kimberleys, Mr T. Stephens, said that he understood that the new management of Gordon Downs had approached the Commonwealth Employment Service in Kununurra to get help in obtaining white stockmen.
This, presumably, was to replace the black stockmen whom he had told to get off his property. The article continues:
A group of Aborigines at the station, headed by a man called Mick Rallah, had been trying for several years to have some land excised for their own use.
But this had been stopped by the State Government's ban on the transfer of pastoral land to Aboriginal communities.
What a magnificant reputation. The Government had placed a ban on the transfer of all pastoral land to Aboriginal communities. The article further states:
The Acting Premier, Mr Old, said last night the Government knew that a problem existed with the Gordon Downs people at Halls Creek.
A Community Welfare Department officer had been sent from Kununurra to investigate it. He was expected to report today.
We have never heard what that report to that Minister was. Until I asked the question yesterday we had not heard about the report to the Minister in this chamber. The article continues:
Mr Old said he did not know the circumstances that had led to the people leaving the station.
Some of the people were old and Gordon Downs was their traditional land.

The Minister admitted that. I have already spoken about traditional land, sacred sites and sites of significance. I believe that they all mean one and the same thing. It is no good saying that we will determine which is which, because the black people in Australia want the right to determine which is their land. It really does not matter what they call it. What does matter is that we accept what they call it, that we acknowledge their right to it and we should make sure, where possible, that they get it. But it is probably the first time that a Minister in the Court Government of Western Australia has ever used the phrase 'traditional land'. I think it is an admission on the part of the Government that it recognises that it is so. Once again, in the West Australian on the following day, 16 January, Senator Baume is reported to have said that he was concerned about the expulsion and that his Department was sending an officer from Kununurra to investigate and that he would be reporting. We had to get that report from the Minister during Question Time yesterday. Senator Baume is reported to have said:

If the reports are correct, we would be seeking the return of the Aboriginal people traditionally associated with Gordon Downs to their original location pending the outcome of discussions or any alternative arrangements that may prove necessary.
The article continued:
Senator Baume said that his department would be seeking talks with the station management, the Aborigines and the State Government.

I do not know whether they have been able to have any contact with Mr Sherwin because he has not been accessible to the State Government. I doubt very much that he has made himself accessible to the Federal Government because he has thumbed his nose at both. He has said: 'I do not want to discuss the matter and you are not going to make me'. Both governments have backed down and said: 'No, that is quite all right old fellow. Carry on. We will acknowledge that you have a right to treat Aborigines as you like'.
