The Minister for Community Welfare in Western Australia, Mr Hassell, decided that it might be worth while his getting in on the act. All he said was that he was awaiting a report on the situation. Goodness only knows where he was going to get his report from. Was he going to get it from Mr Old's report or was he going to confer with the Federal Minister? We have not heard any of that. The chairman of the Aboriginal Lands Trust, Mr Ken Colbung, suggested that, in actual fact, there is already provision in the State Parliament for the Western Australian Government to provide those Aboriginal people on Gordon Downs with that land under the Aboriginal Heritage Act. So now we have not only the Lands Act in on it but also the Aboriginal Heritage Act. No one is moving under any of those Acts. The Aborigines are still sitting in Halls Creek. They have been there now for almost seven weeks in the wet. Quite frankly, I do not know how they are feeling, but I am quite frustrated about the whole matter.

We move on to the report on the front page of the West Australian of 17 January. For three consecutive days the West Australian has seen fit to bring to the attention of the people of Western Australia and, we hope, the people of Australia what is happening. It turns out that when three of the men from the community went from Halls Creek back to the station they found that 50 dogs had been shot and poisoned. At the same time the State Government and the Federal Government were accepting that Mr Sherwin was unavailable for comment. I wonder what the situation would have been had those doys belonged to white people. Surely there would have been prosecutions under some Act? We have already got in enough of them, so perhaps we can drag in the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. As a matter of fact, the general secretary of that Society said that the Aborigines should lodge a complaint about the poisoning of the dogs. I think the Senate would agree that it is pretty reprehensible that a man should shoot and poison dogs, just as it is reprehensible that a man would turn off his property 50 Aboriginal people, including young children and old people. The West Australian of 17 January reported as follows:
A meeting of members of the Gordon Downs community in Halls Creek yesterday called on the Federal Government . . .

This was a report which appeared on 17 January, so presumably on 16 January the Federal Minister received a communication of some sort asking for help immediately to re-establish their camp on the station. The Minister said yesterday that they did not want to go back to the station. Yet in the West Australian it is reported that they had communicated with him. The report says quite clearly:
A meeting of members of the Gordon Downs community in Halls Creek yesterday called on the Federal Government to help them immediately re-establish their camp on the station.
The Minister said in this chamber that they did not want to go back to their station, that they wanted to go to Ringers Soak.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is correct.

—I think the Minister has a lot of answers to provide to the Senate and to the people of Gordon Downs community. What he said yesterday does not conform with what the Aboriginal community is quoted as having said in the West Australian.
—That is what the newspaper says.

—That is what the newspaper said was communicated to you in a letter of 16 January. Once again, we see the entrance of the Western Australian Minister for Community Welfare, Mr Hassell. He has decided that he had better say something a little more constructive than 'I am awaiting a report'. The West Australian carried the following report of Mr Hassell's remarks:

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Community Welfare, Mr Hassell, said an officer from his department and from the Department of Aboriginal Affairs had taken steps to ensure that members of the community in Halls Creek had shelter and food.
The report continued:
Attempts to contact Mr Sherwin had not been successful. There were problems with the telephone link to Mr Sherwin's Northern Territory station.
Apparently that is where he had gone. The report then went on:
Mr Hassell said he was advised that pastoral leaseholders were entitled to exclude people from their leases.
However, Section 106 of the Land Act conferred on Aborigines the right at all times to enter pastoral leases in areas which were unenclosed and unimproved to seek sustenance in the accustomed manner.

One has to question what is meant by 'the accustomed manner'. It seems to be a pretty ridiculous phrase to put in legislation anyway. We do not know what the accustomed manner of those Aborigines who were resident on the Gordon Downs station is. Are we suggesting that the accustomed manner is as they lived perhaps 20 years ago where they hunted all their own food, or are we suggesting that they could then petition to the station management for sustenance in the form of food and accommodation? It is a ridiculous statement to be contained in legislation, but then anything can happen in Western Australia. The Western Australian Government likes to have a little bit of two bob each way. It put up the Lands Act and the Aboriginal Heritage Act, and one contradicts the other. It asked for a report from the Aboriginal commissioner attached to the State organisation. What did it do? It ignored his report. It ignored a report that it had specifically requested from the museum authorities. It said: 'Go up and get a report on what is happening in Noonkanbah'. So it got a report on what was happening in Noonkanbah or what the likely results of oil exploration on Noonkanbah would be. When it was brought back the Government would neither release it nor act on that report. This is the two-faced attitude that is being adopted by the Western Australian Government.

There is legislation to enable pastoral leaseholders to tell people not to go on to their properties. At the same time, there is legislation which enables or entitles Aborigines to go on to pastoral leases. Where on earth are these people going? They do not even know which particular piece of legislation they come under. They do not even know whether they are entitled to be on this land, or whether they are entitled to be told to clear off. I remind the Government that some of these people, and presumably their families, were employed on Gordon Downs. If it were a strictly industrial situation, what has happened could be considered to be a lock out. The Government has not taken any action in that regard either. No reasons have been given for the dismissal or the eviction of these people. The State Government has sat on its hands and the Federal Government is doing exactly the same thing.

As I said before, I congratulated the print media on the way in which they handled this story. There have been two very important leaders. Time is getting away from me, so I will not have time to read both of them. A particularly important one appeared on 30 January, which was 15 days after the Press first became aware of what had happened and a full month from the time that those people were evicted from Gordon Downs. We all admit that the West Australian is not the most progressive newspaper in the country. I do not think anyone will quarrel with that statement. Under the leader 'Feeble effort', this is what the West Australian had to say:

What a feeble attitude the State Government has shown over the expulsion of 50 Aborigines from the Gordon Downs cattle station in the Kimberleys. What a contrast to the determination shown over Noonkanbah.
Unable to get in touch with the Gordon Downs leaseholder, the Minister for Community Welfare, Mr Hassell, has simply given up.
This is the man who said he was waiting for a report and then said he could not get one. I repeat:
Unable to get in touch with the Gordon Downs leaseholder, the Minister for Community Welfare, Mr Hassell, has simply given up. No explanation, so end of the matter.
Never mind that the Aborigines appear to have been harshly treated, legally or not.
How one would legally harshly treat a group of Aborigines I do not know. The article continues:
To the Government, apparently, it is just one of those things.
Others, however, will see it as further evidence that in Western Australia Aborigines are people to be pushed around.
The article concluded:
Like Pontius Pilate, Mr Hassell might be able to wash his hands of the matter. It may not be so easy for the State to wash another stain from its reputation.

This article is contained in a conservative newspaper in a very conservative State under the most conservative State Government that one is ever likely to come across unless of course one makes a comparison with the situation that pertains in Queensland. But the conservative Press in the conservative State of Western Australia has been prepared to come out and say that the State Government is wrong. I am standing here tonight saying that not only is the State Government wrong but also the Federal Government is wrong because it has not moved on this matter. It has done nothing. It has been sitting on its bottom for nearly the last seven weeks while people are living in deplorable conditions. These people have canvas shelters and tents. We are told that it just happens to be the wet in Western Australia. The wet comes round every year. Almost invariably with the wet comes problems with Aboriginal communities. We have a problem in Western Australia not only because of the State Government but also because of what is happening to people on communities such as Gordon Downs and Noonkanbah. It is time that the Federal Government stood up and was counted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister for Aboriginal Affairs) (9.22)-I start by reminding the Senate of the maiden speech which we heard earlier tonight and by adding my congratulations to those already made to Senator Hearn on her first contribution in this place. I am rising only briefly tonight to respond to a couple of points made by Senator Coleman in her speech. The important thing to keep in mind is that we have to think about the interests of the Aboriginal people at all times. I want to be certain that nothing said in this chamber will diminish opportunities to advance the best interests of the Ngoonjuwah people in the very difficult situation that has arisen.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable senator has raised a whole series of matters only three of which I wish to address now. I wish first to say something about what I understand the wishes of the community to be. I think it is fair to make known to the Senate the information I have which indicates the wishes of the communities in this matter, to set down the sequence of events insofar as they need to be filled in and perhaps to say something about the present position. I think not all honourable senators will know the story of what has happened at Gordon Downs. Senator Coleman has with a little rodomontade--

TALK.START.PARA: —With what?

—That is just an English word. The honourable senator has filled in some of the details. The fact is that the Aboriginal people from Gordon Downs were evicted by the station management on 2 January and they then moved to Halls Creek. The people have established a camp at a rock hole about one kilometre east of Halls Creek town centre. Since that time they have been assisted by the Western Australian Department of Community Welfare with emergency needs. The honourable senator has also referred to those and given her opinion of their adequacy. I must say that my Department has been concerned to try to assist in finding some longer term solution. When that solution is found my Department will try to assist in providing longer term facilities for the people.

SPEECH.PARA: Arrangements were made for senior officers of my Department to go to Halls Creek as soon as they could with officers of the State Department. Not all honourable senators will know that the arrangements made in Western Australia link very closely officers of the Commonwealth Department with officers of the State Department. Commonwealth officers went with those from the Department of Community Welfare and also with a member of the Aboriginal Lands Trust. In addition to those groups which attended the meeting on 23 January at Halls Creek were Mr Peter Yu from the Kimberley Land Council and Mr Ribna Green, the Aboriginal resident community worker training officer for the Ngoonjuwah Council at Halls Creek. The reason that 23 January is an important date is that it is about a week later than the newspaper report to which the honourable senator referred. I think that is approximately right.

We had to be careful that the wishes expressed in the newspapers at one time were contemporary wishes. I will suggest to the honourable senator in a moment that the report I will give of the outcome of the meeting will indicate a different set of instructions. I am not saying that the honourable senator's information of a week earlier is wrong. I am simply saying that my information, dated from 23 January, is the information that I want to put before the Senate. The people I have mentioned met with about 30 members of the Gordon Downs community. The purpose of the trip was explained at the meeting and three members of the community were nominated to travel with the group to Ringers Soak to look at the place. The purpose of the trip was to confirm with members of the community the actual areas on which they wished to re-establish themselves. Ringers Soak had been suggested as one of them.

The communal group had been split over the last two years. This is the point; some of them had been living on the station while others had moved into Halls Creek. The community had not been unified, and that is not an unusual condition in Aboriginal or non-Aboriginal communities. But, there had been a split in the communal group. Some of the people, in fact, had been camped at Ringers Soak. They assured Government representatives nevertheless that they were all members of one group in the sense that Senator Coleman used the term; that is, they were one group in terms of language, clan and other factors. In fact, the people are incorporated as a group and have office bearers such as Mr Lightning Djooringah and Mr Mick Rahlah, who is the vice-chairman, representing them.

The spokesman for the group confirmed to the departmental officers that all of them-approximately 80 people-wanted to go to the area they called Yaruman, the area around Ringers Soak, and that none wanted to return to Gordon Downs homestead. That is the first important point that emerged. Up to that stage we had been uncertain as to whether the Aboriginal people wanted, as the first option, to go back to Gordon Downs. They did not want to go back; they made that clear to the officers. That fact has been reported back to me. But, the people did more than that; they also provided a copy of a letter they had recently written to the West Australian Minister for Lands seeking reconsideration of their earlier request to obtain a large area of land to which the honourable senator referred. It covers vacant Crown land and excisions from Gordon Downs--

TALK.START.PARA: —Gordon Downs and Coronado.
—And the Coronado lease, that is correct, Senator Coleman. We understood those instructions from the local people to mean that they did not want to go back to Gordon Downs.
—You said the letter stated that they wanted part of Gordon Downs.

—No, Senator Coleman, they did not want to return to the Gordon Downs area from which they had been excluded. Members of the group reported that though they had retrieved very few of their possessions from Gordon Downs unfortunately there had been contamination by dog carcasses. This is another example of the total unpleasantness of the whole situation. Their dogs had been poisoned or shot. They stressed that they wished to return to the area known as Yaruman or Ringers Soak as soon as possible. They were concerned about staying at Halls Creek for reasons which I think Senator Coleman has set out. They were concerned about overcrowding and about social pressures particularly those related to the presence of alcohol. The impression that we got was that the move to Yaruman, to Ringers Soak, was a preferred solution of the group.
—On a temporary basis.

—The honourable senator is adding a qualification. That may be right or it may not be right. The area is about seven kilometres south of the Gordon Downs homestead. It is not a long way. The honourable senator drew attention to the association with the land which these people have. The Ringers Soak area is part of their country as well. It is as much their land as any other part of the area. They would still be in their own country, in their own land. A number of factors make Ringers Soak quite attractive, including the location of airstrips, the capacity to service the area with community services and the fact that there are transport possibilities.

SPEECH.PARA: As I think I said yesterday, the Western Australian Government has decided to grant a temporary lease of 3,500 hectares over this area. A temporary lease apparently is what it issues straightaway while it is examining other possibilities. I hope that in due course the Western Australian Government can proceed to a more permanent grant of land in that area or in one of the other areas. I do not think Mr Sherwin's actions, this precipitate eviction of people, should go unanswered. We are anxious now to provide support for this community when it is set up at Ringers Soak. The honourable senator made light of the wet, but we cannot move to establish or to build facilities which we are planning until we can get good access to the area. The Federal Government has already informed the Commissioner for Aboriginal Planning that it will provide financial assistance for basic facilities on the land made available to the group near Gordon Downs. If further proposals for financial assistance are put to us, they will also be considered. In other words, we are very anxious to help with what the group needs, namely, money to establish itself.

I think I agree with everything the honourable senator said about the unsuitability of Halls Creek for what the Aboriginal group needs. So I do not want to talk for too much longer except to say that the honourable senator referred to Mr Ernie Bridge, the local member of the Legislative Assembly, who has been very helpful throughout this whole episode. The honourable senator is not the only person who has consulted with him. The consultations I have had with him have confirmed in my mind what I felt within myself-not what I heard from officers-that the action we are taking is appropriate and acceptable to him. I just place that on the record too because he is the Labor MLA for Kimberley. That is another point to be remembered. In summary, the relocation at Ringers Soak appears to have the backing of the community involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a temporary measure.

—The Western Australian Government has granted a temporary reserve of 3,500 hectares and the Minister for Lands in Western Australia is still considering separately the proposal for the group to acquire the other area of land that has been put up.
—No, he is not. He has said that he has not given reconsideration to that matter.

—He is considering separately the proposal for the group to acquire the land around the area which could include part of the Coronado pastoral lease. I think the action of Mr Peter Sherwin and his defiance of the Western Australian Government has created a new ball game as regards the attitude of the Western Australian Government to the disability suffered by some of these Aboriginal people.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, on checking on the situation today our afternoon reports are that Halls Creek has been cut off by floods and that we are now having to airlift food into Halls Creek. It is a very severe wet at the moment which is creating very great difficulty. We are seeking urgent reports on the situation, but it emphasises the access problems which the Aboriginals have and the sorts of problems which will be associated with moving and relocating them. It is one thing to have the intention, the desire and the commitment of resources. It will be another thing actually to do it physically. I do not think this situation will be helped by politicians trading insults; I do not think that will help it at all. I think what we have to do is to continue to build on every bit we can. We have Ringers Soak. Let us get that working now and let us pursue the question--

TALK.START.PARA: —But they don't want to stay there.

—I am assured by my officers that that is where they want to go now. I do not know when the honourable senator talked to the Aborigines. My officers have been talking face to face. This is the kind of situation which the honourable senator raises quite rightly in the Senate, but I put it to her, on the basis of goodwill and the best kind of community building, that what is required now is proceeding calmly to try to put into effect the things we have achieved and to continue to try to gain a longer term solution for the people. I honestly believe that is the way to get the best result.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to use this Address-in-Reply debate to raise an issue which I believe concerns more Australians at the moment probably more closely than almost any other. It is an urgent matter for clear-cut and decisive action by this Parliament, which I hope we will get. I refer to the state of health care in this country, a region of general muddle, inefficiency and a quite terrifying escalation of costs which must stop. I assert that it must stop because I think it has become more than just a financial matter but an actual danger to many members of the community. Matters have reached a stage at which the cost of insurance to meet health needs has become a frightening burden to tens of thousands of Australian families, especially those with children, and it shows no signs of getting any better. This should be a matter of great concern to this Parliament and should be, as I said, an area of action soon.

SPEECH.PARA: We have the opportunity to take that action because a report which was presented to the other place today and which will be presented to the Senate tomorrow-the Jamison report-would allow us surely at least to come to grips with this problem after so long. It is a truly complex and massive problem and in no way do I underestimate it. I hope that the Senate can at some time provide ample time for full debate on it because the Australian Democrats do not pretend in any sense to a monopoly of wisdom in this area-far from it-nor do I believe can anybody else. But we think it is so important that we must raise it. In doing so I will make some comments on the Jamison Commission of Inquiry into the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals which I trust will be tabled in this place tomorrow.

The problem overall is so massive that I think it will require an honest and co-ordinated effort on the part of all concerned. That has been lacking in the past. It needs the Federal Parliament, State parliaments, the Australian Medical Association, the Doctors' Reform Society, hospital administrations and all other areas of interest and possible input to get together to try to sort out the mess. If ever there were a job of importance for a government to carry out with success, surely this is the one. I do not think from my contacts with the community that anything is really more important to the general well-being and indeed to the peace of mind of most Australians than the knowledge that they can have access to efficient, practical and effective health care at reasonable cost. They do not have that knowledge now. They certainly do not have that assurance. Are we all going to give up? Are we going to say that government, the medical profession and hospital adminstrations have failed? Are we going to continue to flaunt our failure and to say to the Australian people that they must continue to bear the burdens of higher costs and perpetual worry about family health costs?

When an issue becomes too troublesome and too hot to handle governments can remove it from the public arena by establishing a commission to inquire into the problem. A possible approach by government is to set up a commission of inquiry, to set it impossible time deadlines and to insist on quick results. When such a commission presents its report a government committee can extract those elements it thinks suits its philosophy or its ends and ignore the rest. The more various and numerous the recommendations are-and they are very many and various in the Jamison report-the denser the smokescreen that might prevent all but the most careful inquirers from detecting a process of heavy selection. I trust that that unsatisfactory fate is not in store for the Jamison report. It has already been much criticised in the media and elsewhere as naive and ambivalent in its important basic themes. One of those is that the cost of health care must stop accelerating. I think the Australian community and indeed every honourable senator in this place would agree with that proposition. We cannot really see any reason why these costs should not come down. Certainly they ought to be able to come down, provided some chronic maladies of the system can be cured.

The Jamison report also stresses the thought that the private sector rather than the public sector ought to be encouraged in the health care area. The Australian Democrats and I are not altogether sure that in the region of health care those two objectives can be reconciled. Selling health care is not like selling shoes or butter or motor cars and, indeed, it ought not be like that. Possibly our problems are associated a good deal with the fact that it is getting too much like that, and if that is a criticism of wide areas of the medical profession then let it be so: It is intended that way.

I propose to tell the Senate a story I heard recently, to me, a very disgraceful but at the same time, illuminating story. A constituent of mine, like many other ladies, regularly and prudently has pap smear tests to ensure that she does not have cancer. For many years her doctor had these smears processed by a public sector pathology facility which sent out a card promptly and regularly notifying the results. However, this has changed in recent times. A private pathologist has come into the act at a very high fee. Fair enough, one might say, but on one recent occasion the lady did not get the pathologist's bill. She had paid previous bills. Perhaps she should have asked for a bill, I do not know. She waited for some time then rang her doctor's office to see what was the result from the smear test. She was told that the results of that test could be released only after she had paid the pathologist's bill. I suppose that is a normal commercial judgment but, I asked myself, what would have happened if the lady had thought: 'Perhaps everything is okay. I won't worry about inquiring. They might let me know if anything is wrong'? Would that pathologist have done anything about it if in fact that person had needed urgent medical attention? I suppose there is an ethical problem here which derives directly from a commercial approach and certainly needs some examination.

The Australian Democrats are a private enterprise party but we believe in private enterprise being enlightened. It must be responsible. It ought to concede that it has a primary duty to the community to provide a service and that is perhaps more important in the medical profession than in any other area of private enterprise. Doctor friends have complained to me about the shrinking public esteem of the medical profession. I can only say, as I have said to them: Is this to be wondered at when we hear stories of the type I have just related, to say nothing of the story about the group of seven pathologists in South Australia who earned $6m gross in one year and another about a doctor who can afford a private helicopter to service his string of blood shops, as I believe they are called in the trade, around Sydney? Such things are becoming notorious and if the private sector of the medical profession is to continue to be allowed to make a contribution to health care in this country and if it has any conscience at all it must smarten up, get its own house in order and through some process of effective self-regulation force out of business these ghouls who are grossly exploiting this community or at least get them to the stage where the rewards given to them are reasonable, even by medical standards because they are certainly not reasonable now. I say that there should be self-regulation because, of course, most doctors are honest and decent men and women who do want to provide a service. Those decent ones, I suggest, have a special responsibility to clean up the unsavoury areas of their own profession because unsavoury areas there certainly are and the public is becoming increasingly aware of them.

The Australian Democrats feel that the huge volume of health costs is coming from several major maladies which ought to be recognised for what they are and ought to be corrected. We do not believe that they are beyond solution: Far from it. The first of these would appear to be over-treatment, a controversial subject, I know. A volume of evidence suggests that 80 per cent of the costs of medical treatment are doctor initiated, for one reason or another. Statistics from various parts of the world where health maintenance schemes exist suggest that many procedures would appear to be quite unnecessary. What I am saying is that in areas in America where there are health maintenance schemes there are much lower rates of certain types of operations, certain types of procedures, than in adjacent areas which are statistically much the same and which are deemed to be nuisance control groups where a fee for service situation prevails. This is a reality and I think it is something that has to be considered in Australia. Should we have significant changes towards a health maintenance scheme and by that I mean a situation wherby a group of doctors perhaps with a hospital or with other supporting professional people charges a flat fee to a certain number of people a year with the job of keeping them healthy? So it is in their interest for the patient to be kept healthy, for preventive medicine to take the accent and for a proper system of health maintenance to be adopted rather than there being a situation whereby if something goes wrong with a patient the doctor makes money out of it. We are all human beings, doctors included.

I suggest this is a terrifyingly bad basic approach to any type of service to the community. I know this has been said before but I say it again without apology: I think it is something which this Parliament must look at as an option for Australia. I think a proper, honest change towards health maintenance would have a much greater effect than the recommendation of the Jamison report that patients ought to pay a certain proportion of medical costs themselves and that they should not be reimbursed completely by insurance. That is at first sight perhaps an attractive proposition. One says: 'Joe Blake will go along to the doctor with a sore toe because he thinks it is not going to cost him anything'. But this brings us back to the estimate that only some 20 per cent of medical costs are patient originated. One wonders really whether the deterrent to the patient of paying a small sum of money would be as great as seems to be envisaged. I wonder whether the patient who is worried about himself will be deterred in that way.

The Jamison report has had some hard and just words to say about hospital accounting. From the report it does seem that many areas of health care in the hospital region are unduly expensive. It is not hard to find examples which I propose to mention to the Senate. The Jamison report castigated the hospitals for their inability to identify just what these huge areas of spending within their budgets had amounted to. They seem to be very careless over their accounting.

There is much controversy over expenditure on intensive care units and I believe, and the Australian Democrats believe, this should increasingly become a matter of community debate. Intensive care is very expensive. Its results in restoring not only life but a reasonably healthy life-I think that is an important consideration-are in many cases doubtful. Should the community proceed indefinitely along a line of thought which says that every human being should be kept alive for as long as possible and by whatever means possible, and if hospitals costs are huge now what will they be in another decade's time if this principle is to be actively projected into the future? If it can be questioned then, it ought to be questioned now and that is something else which I believe the community itself should make decisions on, not doctors. Some doctor friends of mine say that a grave ethical question is involved. So there is, but I think it is an ethical principle, a question of priority which the community itself ought to be able to consider.

Associated with this area of hospital costs could be the question of extensions of hospital services and equipment. I was in Perth earlier this month and I noticed that the Health Care Consumers Association had criticised the Western Australian Government's approval of spending three-quarters of a million dollars on a new body scanner for the Royal Perth Hospital. Three-quarters of a million dollars for one piece of equipment is a lot of money and one wonders whether some hospital administrators believe they should have a completely open cheque for hospital costs and that the community somehow ought to meet any cost whatsoever which will further some health aim. This, I suggest, is contributing to the dangerous situation I mentioned earlier where people are being forced into a situation whereby they cannot afford health care. That is a very dangerous situation for any community to allow itself to come to.

I quote briefly from an account in the West Australian of the criticism by the Health Care Consumers Association. It pointed out that this purchase gave Western Australia its fourth scanner while interestingly enough there were only four such scanners operating in the whole of Britain. A spokesman for the Association, Judyth Watson, was reported as saying:
We already have more scanners per head of population than Britain, yet the government is going ahead with the purchase of another.
It is a really crass decision for them to make at this time, when so many essential health-care services are being cut due to a supposed lack of funds.
That is the case in Western Australia where even nursing services were being cut by the Government apparently because of lack of money. Judyth Watson went on:
It is just another case of duplication of services already available to patients.
These scanners do nothing for the actual treatment of patients. They simply make the diagnosis more pleasant and safer.
The final outcome and treatment is not aided. Perhaps the money could have been better spent on preventive medicine.'
I am sorry to say this plea appears to have fallen on deaf ears. The article further stated:
The Minister for Health, Mr Young, said RPH had put up a sufficiently valid case for a new body scanner. It should be installed within a year.

Such a view must assist the cause of those who are worried about proposals in the Jamison report for block funding to States and who believe that if this recommendation was adopted then extension services, community health services and things of this kind might suffer because the money would inevitably go through the sort of government institutional way of budgeting to expensive institutionally oriented equipment and services. There again on this question of hospital control I think it is worth noting at this point the Jamison report's recommendation, supported by other enlightened people in this area, that area boards ought to be instituted instead of hospital boards in Australia so that there is not necessarily a feeling that the hospital board is responsibly only for what goes on within the walls of its institution but that it has responsibilities to a general area of the community and in fact should provide community health services and various other things to that area. That one recommendation alone, if implemented-the Government could encourage it-might make a tremendous difference in the long run to the way in which our hospitals are run and the way in which their costs are escalating.

There is a huge fact of importance in the report, one so vast that the mind boggles at it although it is very simple. According to the Jamison report, some 60 per cent-I repeat, 60 per cent-of hospital beds in Australia are occupied by people over the age of 65. Many of these cases simply are geriatric cases which could be accommodated in hospitals especially designed for them and in which I am assured they would be much happier and would be much better treated, and most of which would involve a very much lower bed cost than the general hospitals which are now accommodating them. As a layman, I feel that if our medical planning has reached the degree of insanity which that single fact demonstrates, it should not be too difficult to make improvements. Surely, in this case if the decision makers have allowed our hospital facilities to be misused to that extent through lack of planning they ought to be properly castigated. Every effort should be made to induce them to develop a more balanced situation of smaller hospitals which provide all facilities and which would certainly provide hospital accommodation as well for elderly people but still with health care nearby and with domiciliary care also in the community.

These things are well known in the community. Why can the hospital administrations and those concerned with health care not actually do it instead of moaning, screaming and complaining about higher costs and then throwing up their hands and saying that nothing can be done about it. Of course something can be done about it. That is one thing that could be done very quickly. Nursing homes represent major and expensive problems. I shall quote now from the report of the Auditor-General on efficiency audit of 13 February of this year which in fact was released today. It is the report of the Auditor-General on efficiency audit of Commonwealth administration of nursing home programs. It would have arrived in the offices of most honourable senators, I believe, today. The report states:
More than 50,000 people received benefits in 1979-80 and Commonwealth expenditure on the programs in that year exceeded $340 million.
That is no mean sum. The report observes:
A number of studies report that 20% of nursing home patients could more appropriately be cared for in alternative accommodation.
We come back to the same problem of a lack of planning and of a misuse of facilities because nobody has thought about the future clearly enough. The report goes on:
If this is so the additional cost to the community is in the order of $72 million p.a.
Again, a not inconsiderable sum which the community would have removed from its health cost budget. The report continues:
Of more than 137,000 admissions in New South Wales from 1973 to 1980 only one was rejected.

This indicates the lack of proper control over this area of admission to nursing homes. I have a friend, a social worker, who deals in this area, and she says that a lot of this work is done on the telephone. Of course, when one rings up a nursing home and says: 'Can you have this patient?' the home asks: 'Does he or she need intensive care?' They want a certificate from a doctor to the effect that intensive care is required. Why? Not because these people need intensive care at all but because the nursing home gets an additional $6 per patient on that basis. That is something that should be looked at very promptly. The Auditor-General's report states:
Over-expenditure by the Commonwealth could have exceeded $4.2m because of nursing home owners calling patients 'extensive care' unnecessarily and getting an extra $6.00 per day per patient.

So it is not just the Democrats making this statement; it is there in one of the Government's own reports. I should have thought that our health administrators who considered ducking that sort of thing would look at that and say: 'I have a duty in all conscience to do something about that'. The report continues:
50% of non Government nursing homes in New South Wales during 1979 overstated wage costs costing the Commonwealth some $2m. If this is so in other states, then we are being 'ripped-off' by $4m.
Again a not inconsiderable amount. The report continues:
In 3 cases in New South Wales, false information submitted by nursing homes cost the Commonwealth $159,649.

That is relative peanuts by governmental standards but still to most average people a large sum of money. The report of the Auditor-General cites as problems accommodation of more than the number of patients approved for the hospital-this is known in the trade, I believe, as cramming-charging more than the approved fees, reducing wages for staff without notification and charging for services not provided. I should have thought from that that there was an area that the Commonwealth Department of Health or whoever is responsible for this might look at quite quickly. Indeed, all of us would be glad to see that done. It is again an example that there are gross errors of waste and mismanagement in our health care area which are the real problems and that those real problems are being ducked or evaded by those who are paid huge salaries in this society to deal with those problems. It is time they were brought to book. If they cannot do their jobs properly, let us fire them and get somebody in who can do them. I think it ought to come to that stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the real crux of the problem in the provision of health care.

—I know. I am aware of that. The profit motive is the problem. I mentioned earlier that, although we are a private enterprise party, I did not believe that private health care and private enterprises were always reconcilable, and that was one of my reasons for saying that.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to medical insurance. There is something in the Jamison report which worries me a lot and which worries the Australian Democrats. If indeed we are to accept-there are rumours that the Government may well do so-the Jamison report's recommendation that the Commonwealth benefit be removed from people who should be able to take out private insurance and do not do so, then the Australian Democrats believe that a very liberal and compassionate interpretation of need or disadvantage will have to be associated with that. This is because-I refer to my earlier point-very large numbers of families who could not necessarily be called poverty stricken or disadvantaged just average families, are in quite difficult financial circumstances. Those financial circumstances are not getting easier, the way things are going in the community. In many cases the wife worked and lost her job. These people have very real problems. The financial constraints on them are harsh and real. That is why they are not taking out health insurance. It is not because they do not want to have it or because they are lazy; it is because it it too expensive for them and they are setting it against other things and are taking a calculated risk. A decent, reasonable society should not force them to take that risk, especially when the health or our next generation and of our children is at stake.

Say the Government does take this action and does use a big stick against these people. Will they take out health insurance in large numbers if the benefit of $20 is taken from them? I doubt it. I do not think it will make any difference at all. The proposition may seem tempting and easy as a categorical government action, but I assert that it ignores the reality for many Australians in funding health care. As a government action I suggest it would achieve very little except to cause a great deal of hardship and to exacerbate the problems which already exist.

I refer briefly to recommendation 35, which is another very hairy one. This is the one which calls for an immediate investigation into a scheme of taxing benefits received by all free patients, that is public patients, in public hospitals. The degree of intrusion into people's affairs and the administrative horrors that this raises, worries me greatly. I suggest that honourable senators might think about that and consider whether they would agree with me that it is unworkable and wholly undesirable.
A better prospect lies in the subsequent proposition in recommendation 36, which urges the Government to establish a working party to devise a health insurance scheme which:
. . . satisfies the principles of equity, freedom of access, and payment by those who can afford it, and promotes universal participation.
Those are good words. They are not cliches. They mean, and ought to mean, something in this society. I repeat:
. . . satisfies the principles of equity, freedom and access, and payment by those who can afford it, and promotes universal participation.

No major political party in this country has demonstrated when it has been in government that it is in any way competent to develop an effective and equitable health insurance system. Its philosophical hangups have prevented a satisfactory consensus. That satisfactory consensus is the only way in which we will ever get to first base in relation to this problem. Political expediency or ideology instead of the only barometer which should matter in society-the needs of the people-has dictated the terms of health insurance. The past decade has seen a tragic situation of change after change in the health insurance system. It is the one thing in a society, one would think, that ought to stay stable, that people ought to be able to rely on. It is the one thing that governments ought to leave alone and not tamper with for political reasons, because it affects so many people so fundamentally. Each change has led to more confusion and less understanding for the public and has undermined confidence in the system, so that that confidence is now at the lowest possible ebb. That also is tragic.

The failure to contain, to rationalise or even to explain costs, because the medical establishment sets itself like God above any explanation, has, as we know, led to thousands of people deserting the system. They will go on deserting it until something is done. Government has no reason to congratulate itself for that state of affairs; it will have been the fault of government. It will have neglected a job for which it was put into power and which it is paid to do. It has failed to do it effectively.

The Australian Democrats believe that the working party should involve not only insurance bodies, government officers and health administrators but also consumer groups, State authorities, health commissions, professional organisations and appropriate education authorities, all of whom from time to time have had points of view to express but have too often not been listened to. Without such broad participation we risk losing sight of a health system which can provide the highest possible standards of care without bankrupting the country, as was the case in Britain, or bankrupting the patient, which can be the case in the United States of America. Recommendation 36, we believe, is one of the most positive of the Jamison inquiry's proposals. It is no mere cliche but is something which could well be undertaken by this Government.

The Jamison inquiry has, we believed, laid bare the problems, warts and all. It has presented some plausible solutions. It has clearly defined the problem areas and the shortcomings and it has provided the framework, the guidelines for a more extensive study of the problems, leading perhaps to a complete overhaul without the impositions, the pressures created by decisions made piecemeal or merely for political expediency. The Australian Democrats would deeply regret and urge the Government against snatching any sort of piecemeal, small decision from the report. We are worried about certain reports in the Press, which may or may not be true, that the Federal Government is contemplating rushing headlong into the field and introducing hasty legislation to implement isolated individual recommendations which might satisfy one section of the community without considering the ramifications that such legislation would have on the rest of the community. That is what we do not want to see happen.

The whole report, every point, every issue, needs to be analysed-not by an interdepartmental committee established by the present Government, which committee we would quite readily expect to be appointed, with due respect to its members-to produce opinions in line with the Government's policies. So far this Government is no different from its predecessors in this respect in that it has not been able to solve the problems. That, after all, is what it is there to do.

We believe that what is required is a more broadly based inquiry, perhaps even an all-party parliamentary committee which would consult and involve all concerned with health and hospital administration, health insurance, the handicapped, the aging and so on. We know that this will take time. It will take trouble. There is no way in which this problem will be solved easily or quickly by anybody, but if we have waited the 80 years since Federation to begin looking at the problems constructively perhaps we can wait a little longer to find this time equitable and real solutions to these problems.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Address-in-Reply debate affords honourable senators an opportunity to canvass a whole number of issues. Obviously, honourable senators have availed themselves of that opportunity. My purpose in entering the debate this evening is to talk about a matter which has not been raised in this Parliament in the Address-in-Reply debate to the Governor-General's address. I wish to speak about electoral reform. Before I do so I extend congratulations to Senator Jean Hearn on her maiden speech this evening. She put forward a variety of views which express in a very forthright way the philosophical position of the Australian Labor Party and the Australian labour movement. She expressed the aspirations, expectations and desires of our movement to build a better society, which is clearly on the agenda for the Australian people. She applied herself also to the problems of the undeveloped parts of the world-the Third World countries-and the widening gap between the rich and the poor. Senator Hearn, by the manner in which she dealt with these matters, I think produced an unusual situation insofar as a very considerable number of senators were in the chamber when she made her contribution. I congratulate the Government and Opposition senators who listened to her when she made that contribution.

SPEECH.PARA: I support the amendment moved by Senator Button which indicts this Government for its lack of concern about the growing unemployment, the state of the economy, the reduction in living standards, the high taxation and the rising level of inflation in this country. This is one of the few opportunities that the Senate has to deal with these matters, which are of considerable substance and of considerable concern in the Australian community.

I think it is a matter of great regret and it is always unfortunate when the office of the Governor-General is perverted for party political purposes. We saw this in 1975, we saw it at the opening of the Parliament in 1977 and we saw it last year in the Governor-General's address at the opening of the Thirty-second Parliament. In that address the Governor-General referred to the people of Australia returning the Government, to use his words, 'with a substantial majority'. Let us look at that statement that the Government had been returned with a substantial majority. In the time that is available to me I will deal with the electoral imbalance, manipulations and frauds that make up the substance upon which the Governor-General's Speech relied. Lest the people of Australia are misled by the words of the Governor-General and the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) that the Government was elected with a substantial majority I wish tonight to clarify this matter by looking at this so-called substantial majority and in so doing bringing to the attention of the Senate and the people of Australia the inadequacies of the present electoral system in this country. I do so in my capacity as shadow Minister for Administrative Services, with particular emphasis on electoral matters. I hope to focus some attention upon the deficiencies of the existing system. I hope that ultimately there will be a vigorous, rational and tripartisan debate on the whole field of electoral reform and the representative parliamentary democracy that ought to flow from a proper electoral system.

Honourable senators will recall that after the election results were announced late last year there was considerable disquiet in the community regarding the fairness and justice of our system of electing representatives to our Parliament. It is true that the Labor Party has been aware for a considerable period of the inbuilt bias that exists in the present electoral system. But when it became apparent to the public at large that Mr Fraser and his Government had been returned with so many seats in their control when there had been a substantial swing to the Labor Party, the questioning and perplexity in the community grew. That was seen in a number of editorial comments, letters to the newspapers and important articles written by those concerned, as they are, with the imbalance that now exists in the national Parliament with respect to the total majority vote of the Australian people.

It should not be necessary for me to point out that the credibility of our parliamentary institutions is at stake, because justice must be seen to be done as well as be done. Statistics that have been prepared by our own Parliamentary Library-I think they cannot be challenged-show that in national two-party preferred terms the minority party, the Australian Labor Party, polled 49.8 per cent for the House of Representatives and the coalition parties polled 50.2 per cent. That was a margin of 0.4 per cent for the Government. When the seats in the House of Representatives were counted and allocated the Government controlled 73, or nearly 60 per cent of the total number. The Labor Opposition's 51 seats were a mere 40 per cent of the number of seats.

The people are entitled to ask whether this is a fair system. Is this really what democracy is about when such imbalance can occur because of the way in which the electoral system operates? The question has been asked before, and justifiably, because since the major alterations in electoral redistribution were made by the Chifley Labor Government, which first took effect in the 1949 Federal election, the Labor Party has secured on more than five occasions in that intervening period, on a national two-party preferred vote, a majority of votes-in the years 1954, 1961, 1969, 1972 and 1974-and yet has gained government only twice for a total of three years out of 33 years. One needs only to refer to those three years when Labor was in government to appreciate how the entrenched conservative majority in the Senate reacted and acted during that period to negate even that situation.

Anyone who is involved in politics-let us not beat about the bush; let us accept the facts for what they are-knows that when electoral commissioners are appointed they are appointed for the purpose of contriving to bring about a desired result. Consequently, electoral redistributions take place which invariably, in the great majority of instances, favour the government of the day. That is a matter that cannot be contested. They would not be appointed to those positions to carry out a redistribution unless they produced a result that was satisfactory to the political party occupying the majority view in the Houses of Parliament. It will be argued that in 1949 the Chifley Government, in appointing the commissioners, did so on the basis of equity and fairness and that it was the principle factor in bringing about the changed political situation at that time. It will be argued that men who occupy some positions of influence and power within our community are beyond political persuasion and influence. Those who believe that believe in fairyland. Those who believe that influences do not exist even within the judicial system do not understand, or do not want to understand, the way in which these things operate.

The present electoral system is designed to prevent a majority of votes returning to power a party with a majority of seats. That electoral system has been manipulated over the years by successive coalition governments-denying the basic majority viewpoint. This has been expressed in the number of seats held in the lower House. The 1980 result did not provide a majority of votes for the Labor Party but the result was very close. We do not criticise that. It is proper that a party which does not get the majority of votes should not have the majority of seats. It is this closeness which serves to bring home the discrepancy between the seats held and the seats gained. If we had a proper electoral system the representation in the lower House today would be something along the lines of 65 seats for the coalition parties, the conservative parties, and 60 seats for the Opposition, the Australian Labor Party.

This system operates in this way because we have been persuaded for a great number of years to rely upon the proposition that single member constituencies provide for clear majorities, enabling a government to work effectively. I suggest that that factor is not relevant, is not fair, is not pertinent and is not democratic. The present situation exists to pervert the democratic process. The present situation persists to ensure that only a Liberal-National Country Party government enjoys an inflated majority. Even when the Labor Party received a clear majority of votes on a two-party preferred basis in 1972 and 1974, it will be recalled that it still had a struggle to find a small parliamentary majority. While ever we have a single constituency basis for our electoral voting system, Labor can never expect a large majority.

This situation has caused many letters to be written to the newspapers and many comments to be made in special articles in a number of the more thoughtful journals in our community about the need to change the emphasis away from the single member constituencies. Of course, the situation is very starkly shown if one looks at the result of the 1977 election in Western Australia-I bring this to the attention of Government senators-when the Labor Party obtained 40 per cent of the votes and 10 per cent of the seats. The party which obtained 60 per cent of the votes got 90 per cent of the seats. Honourable senators on the Government side have the audacity to suggest that that is a fair and equitable system. It is a system that needs to be changed. It is a system that will be changed. I throw down the challenge to the Government. Make no mistake about it, it is a system that will be changed. In New South Wales the Labor Party received 50.4 per cent of the votes and won only 42 per cent of the seats. In Queensland, with 47 per cent of the votes, it gained 26 per cent of the seats. The same sort of analysis can be applied to Western Australia. In Tasmania and the Northern Territory--
Senator Knight-That is not analysis.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Knight claims to be a democrat. In Tasmania and the Northern Territory, where the Labor Party polled 47 per cent and 49 per cent of the votes respectively, there is no Labor representation at all in the lower House. Effectively, just under half of the electors in those areas have representatives in the House of Representatives whom they voted against. That is not a democratic process. In all 3,412,750 people, or 41 per cent of the Australian voters, have representatives in the House of Representatives whom they preferred not to have. That means there is a deficiency, a manipulation and an unsatisfactory state of affairs in the way the present voting system operates. The system of single member constituencies has much to answer for in this respect. The manifestation of the people's choice, which the Governor-General spoke about, is not only warped but is an unproportional manifestation. The Governor-General stated that the election result was a manifestation of the people's choice. Certainly, in a majority sense it was, but not in the imbalanced and unfair proportion of seats finally allocated because of the single member constituency.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to compare the situation in the lower House with that which operates in this place. It is very peculiar and very interesting to find that honourable senators who are elected on a system of proportional representation would not be here if it had not been for the change in the voting system of the Senate which was introduced in the late 1940s by the Labor Party in order to bring about a balance in the way in which the Senate should operate. They seem to have some objection to the operation of that system for the House of Representatives. The present situation in this chamber reflects more accurately the electoral position. Of course, after 1 July it will properly reflect the views of the Australian people when there will be a much more balanced situation in this Senate. What does the vote for the Senate election in 1980 show? It shows that the Labor Party with 44 per cent of the vote got 44 per cent of the seats. It shows that the coalition with 44 per cent of the vote got 44 per cent of the seats. It shows that the Australian Democrats with 10 per cent of the vote got eight per cent of the seats. This is the sort of system that ought to be looked at, examined and adopted for the lower House as well.

What we of the Labor Party are concerned to bring about is a system whereby the party that gets 50 per cent of the vote gets 50 per cent of the seats in the lower House. The only way this can be brought about is by introducing a new system, of proportional representation, that is, on a State-wide basis. Proportional representation, a system which can properly reflect the will of the people, can be implemented by incorporating a system of multi-member constituencies within a State, as is the procedure that now operates in the State of Tasmania. It is known as the Hare-Clark system. All points of view are represented in the Parliament. Proportionally almost to the last digit in percentage terms, seats are won according to the number of votes polled. This system also has the advantage of maintaining links between the representatives and their constituencies and establishes an awareness of regional identity, something which is sadly lacking in the present system in this place. Some combination of single-member electorates and proportional representation may hold the key or a refinement of the present system may be possible to establish the basic principle of parliamentary, representative and majority democracy. Certainly that system does not operate so far as the lower House is concerned.

Without losing sight of the most pressing need of our electoral system, that of true expression of the people's will, there are many other matters to which we must address ourselves in the meantime to achieve a more effective representation. Let us look at the present system which this chamber is primarily responsible for. The entrenched conservative majority capriciously used its majority from 1972 to 1975 and refused to adopt the amendments to the Electoral Act which the Whitlam Government was attempting to implement. What does it mean in practice? It means that a significant number of Australian people, because of their education standards and their inability to understand our electoral system, vote informally and therefore negate their vote. I suggest to honourable senators and the public at large that they ought to examine the voting figures at the recent election. Those figures reveal that in all the areas where migrant communities exist, in all the areas where rural poverty exists and those areas in which education facilities are not up to standard, there is a pattern of about 10 per cent of the vote being informal. In the circumstances those people are denied an effective say in their choice of government. The conservative majority in this place refused to allow optional preferential voting to be instituted in the electoral changes that the Labor Party proposed during 1972 to 1975. If the expressed will of the voter were clear that vote would be regarded as a valid vote.

It is significant that this Government which claims to be concerned about the rights of minority groups, this Government which claims to be concerned about the democratic processes, this Government which always talks about the need to bring more migrants to this country, perpetuates a system that denies to those people, after they have been in this country for long enough to be placed on the electoral roll through the due processes of the law, the right to vote effectively because of their inability to understand our voting system. Because of the perversity of the conservatives in this chamber approximately one in ten votes is declared invalid, whether it be in the electorate of Melbourne, Gellibrand, Wills, Lalor, Melbourne Ports, Grayndler or Sydney. A bias is working against the democratic rights of our non-English speaking migrant communities.

Whatever system we decide upon, we have a duty to ensure that all those people who wish to vote are able to do so unhindered by mechanisms which by their very complexity effectively disenfranchise them. We ought to be adopting an electoral Act which in fact protects the rights of people and gives them the opportunity to record a vote in a way that expresses their desire and their will instead of placing impediments upon them to the degree that their vote is negated. For example, in a Senate election in which about 50 candidates are involved and in which the clear will of a voter has been expressed up to candidate No. 43, because the voter has marked two 44s or two 45s the vote is declared by the electoral officer to be informal. What an absurdity! What a stange system of illogics bearing in mind the sorts of amendments which we attempted to introduce to change that process so that the vote became effective! After all, if a person had voted for the dozen or so candidates whom it was necessary to elect, that ought to have been sufficient indication of choice and that vote ought to be regarded as an effective vote. If we want to be associated with the democratic process, if we want people to be able to have the vote of their choice recorded, we must consider the introduction of optional preferential or limited preferential voting whereby the elector is required only to vote for a minimum number of candidates to record a formal vote. Of course the State Labor Government in New South Wales has done precisely that in local government elections. The candidates are elected on the principle of proportional representation. If three candidates are to be elected out of 30, the voter has to vote for only twice the number of vacancies to be filled plus one. So the voter needs to vote for only one to seven, and that becomes a formal vote. Of course voters are given how-to-vote cards which show how to vote for candidates who have nominated. If they fail, perforce of a lack of understanding, a lack of education or any other reason, to complete the ballot paper, provided they have marked the card one to seven, that vote becomes an effective, formal vote. Honourable senators on the other side of this House say that they believe in the democratic processes. Yet they took the steps that they did in 1975 to prevent the passage of our amendments to reform the Electoral Act. It just shows how far out their understanding is of the whole of the democractic process. It indicates very clearly that they are not concerned about the democratic right of the people to vote. They are concerned only about maintaining their place in power; they are concerned only about the principle that pervades the conservative parties in this country-the right to rule; the born to rule concept which is so much synonomous with the conservative attitude and which was clearly reflected in the obstructionism of the Senate during the whole of the period from 1973 to 1975.

We must also allow the political affiliation of candidates to be shown on the ballot paper. This would prevent confusion in the minds of electors who do not know the names of a Party's candidate. After all, the political parties themselves go through the process of selecting candidates. As we well know there are those who win and there are those who lose. The candidate who is selected by the political party is not always well known locally in the community. When people vote they want to vote for the candidate belonging to the political party which they have been persuaded they ought to support in the particular election. On the ballot paper we need to have the name of the candidate and the name of the party or group-Independent or whatever it is-that he represents.

It seems to me that we must also find some way-and the Senate perhaps ought to be exercising its powers of inquiry-in which we can reduce the capricious number of candidates who nominate, particularly for the Senate, without denying the right of a citizen to seek election to the Senate. I am thinking particularly of the candidates who deliberately nominated in 1974 and 1980 for the purpose of gaining publicity and causing confusion. They exhibited sheer flippancy in their attitudes. Their whole purpose was to negate the majority vote. Let us face it; in 1974 in New South Wales that was a precise tactic designed by the conservatives. They succeeded in causing a greater number of informal votes to be recorded on that occasion. Something like 80 candidates nominated for that election. We all know that even the brightest people in our community, even those who claim that their education level is above standard and even those who claim to understand the democratic process, found great difficulty in filling out that ballot paper, not to mention the elderly, the people who might have some disability in eyesight, the people who did not understand the voting system and all the great diversity of groups within our community who are not tuned in, as it were, to the whole political process.

We must also consider a technique such as rotating the names of the candidates on the ballot papers in order to eliminate the mathematical advantage accruing to those candidates on the top of the ballot. During the recent election campaign in Queensland I went though the list of candidates standing for the National Party and the Liberal Party in Queensland. I found that more than 60 per cent of those who nominated were at the top of the ballot paper. In other words it was the Abels, the Bakers and the people with names beginning with A, B or C. Was that just an accidental occurrence or was it a deliberate political ploy? I submit that it was a deliberate political ploy by the political parties in order to gain the advantage of what is known as the donkey vote.

Similarly, particularly in marginal seats in the various States of the Commonwealth, we can point to the conservative parties specifically selecting a candidate whose name will head the ballot paper. How important that is because seats are won or lost by those people who perhaps do not have much interest in the voting processes and who just decide to vote for the candidates as they are listed straight down the ticket. That has happened in numerous electorates and even in the last election. So we suggest that if there is any sincerity in the Government parties and if there is any sincerity amongst the Australian community about bringing in a fairer electoral system we ought to have either a draw out of a hat or a system whereby the political parties rotate on the ballot paper from one election to another. These are details which are on the agenda, which need to be examined by the Senate and which ought to be worked out.
