SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
National Companies and Securities Commission Amendment Bill 1981

This Bill is the first of four Bills that I have introduced today pursuant to the Commonwealth's obligations under the co-operative companies and securities scheme. Before I discuss the Bills, I would like to outline, for the benefit of honourable senators, the administrative and legislative context in which these Bills will operate.
FORMAL AGREEMENT ON COMPANIES AND SECURITIES

Background material on the formal agreement and on the four basic elements of the co-operative companies and securities scheme is contained in paragraphs four to 18 of the explanatory memorandum on the National Companies and Securities Commission Amendment Bill 1980 which has been circulated to honourable senators. The aim is that, as far as possible, any person or company should be able to deal on all general companies and securities matters as if that person or company were subject only to one system of law and administration throughout Australia. The co-operative scheme thus provides a framework for uniform general laws on companies and securities matters that will apply throughout Australia. It was, however, never intended to fetter the sovereign right of any parliament to pass particular laws which are not inconsistent with the general legislation agreed to under the scheme.
THE SUBSTANTIVE CODES

In addition to the legislation establishing the National Commission and supporting its operation in jurisdictions other than the Australian Capital Territory, the substantive legislation for the scheme will at this stage be contained in four codes: (a) a share acquisition code which will regulate the acquisition of company shares; (b) a securities industry code which will regulate the securities industry; (c) a companies code which will cover the remaining areas dealt with in the current companies and marketable securities legislation; and (d) an interpretation code which deals with the interpretation of the Commonwealth legislation under this scheme.
PUBLIC CONSULTATION

The formal agreement foreshadowed a major exercise in legislative uniformity and law reform where this was necessary. In embarking on this exercise, this Government and the other governments which are parties to the formal agreement have sought to ensure that there is at all times adequate opportunity for the proposed legislation to be considered by interested persons. Comments were sought and received on the proposed share acquisition code, the proposed securities industry code and the proposed companies code. Further comments are presently being sought on the companies code.

In addition, committees of interested Government and Opposition members and senators have been regularly briefed on the scheme and the Commonwealth legislation under it. It was necessary that these briefings take place because of the nature of the co-operative scheme. Following exposure of the various Commonwealth Bills, public submissions were examined by the Ministerial Council which then approved the Bills in their final form for presentation to this Parliament in accordance with the procedures laid down in the formal agreement. Accordingly, it was necessary for any criticisms and review within the ranks of the Opposition and the members of the Government parties to take place in this rather unusual way.
THE PRESENT POSITION

We have now reached the stage where there is substantial and visible progress towards the completion of the co-operative companies and securities scheme. As is to be expected where seven governments are involved, there will from time to time be differences which require resolution at a political level. To date all differences have been resolved and I am hopeful that we will continue to be able to resolve any future differences that may arise.
THE FUTURE

There are, of course, many matters which remain to be attended to. First, there is the need to make certain amendments to the Commonwealth Acts which have already been passed to take account of the further work that has been done on the scheme legislation. The four Bills I am presenting today cover these amendments. Secondly, there is a need to finalise the content of the regulations that will be required under these Commonwealth Acts. Thirdly, there is a need to settle the form and content of the companies code which was introduced into the House of Representatives on 27 August 1980 to allow further study of the code's provisions by honourable members and senators and the public. Fourthly, each State will have to pass a series of Bills. There will be a National Companies and Securities Commission (State Provisions) Bill to support the National Commission in each State. There will also be an application of laws Bill for each of the four codes in each State. The State Bills other than the Companies (Application of Laws) Bill have been cleared by the Ministerial Council for introduction into individual State parliaments. However introduction and passage of the State Bills will depend on the prgram of the individual State parliaments. Fifthly, the National Commission will have to proceed with its adminstrative arrangements for the administration of the scheme.

It is hoped that in the longer term it may be possible to provide for the establishment of automatic data processing facilities which will assist the National Commission and the State and Territory corporate affairs offices in maintaining a unified system of administration. Accordingly, Ministers have directed their advisers to examine a feasibility study prepared by the Commonwealth-State working group. This working group reported on ADP systems which could be used to assist with the administration of the co-operative scheme. It is the hope of Ministers that the new share acquisition code, the new securities industry code and the interpretation code will be able to be brought into operation by mid 1981. Following further community consultation in relation to the companies code we would hope to have the Commonwealth companies Bill ready for introduction into the Commonwealth Parliament during the first half of 1981.

I would now like to discuss very briefly the first of the Bills that I am presenting today, the National Companies and Securities Commission Amendment Bill. A detailed explanation of the amendments contained in this Bill is set out in the explanatory memorandum which has been circulated with the Bill. The definition of 'agreement' will be amended so that references to the formal agreement made between the Commonwealth and the States on 22 December 1978 will cover that agreement as amended or affected by subsequent agreements. The provisions in the National Companies and Securities Commission Act relating to the application of moneys of the National Commission will be amended so that moneys that vest in the National Commission under another law can be dealt with in accordance with that law. The provisions in the NCSC Act dealing with audit by the Auditor-general will be amended to ensure that the State governments participating in the co-operative scheme retain exclusive control over the auditing of the books or records kept by their authorities or officers where they are acting as delegates of the National Commission. The provisions in the NCSC Act relating to divisions of the National Commission will be amended to allow a division to be constituted by members other than the chairman of the National Commission.

The NCSC Act is also being amended to provide for the establishment of a secretariat for the Ministerial Council. Staff and facilities for the secretariat will be provided by the National Commission. The Bill will come into effect on the day on which it receives royal assent. The National Companies and Securities Commission Amendment Bill has been approved by the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities for introduction into the Commonwealth Parliament. I commend this Bill to the Senate.
Companies (Acquisition of Shares) Amendment Bill 1981

The purpose of the Companies (Acquisition of Shares) Amendment Bill is to amend the Companies (Acquisition of Shares) Act 1980 which sets out the substantative law for the proposed new Australian code which will regulate the acquisition of company shares. A detailed explanation of the provisions of the Amendment Bill is contained in the explanatory memorandum which has been circulated with this Bill.

The first two clauses of the Bill deal with the short title and the Bill's commencement of operation. The remainder of the Bill is concerned with substantive amendments and drafting changes to the Companies (Acquisition of Shares) Act. Among other things, the principal Act will not now apply to a compromise or arrangement under section 181 or section 183 of the existing companies legislation. Where an expert's report accompanies a Part B statement, the target company will now lodge with the National Companies and Securities Commission a notice signed by the expert stating that the expert consents to his report accompanying the Part B statement. If such a report contains a project forecast or a statement on the target company's asset valuations then it may not accompany the Part B statement unless the National Commission consents. A new provision on the variation of formal takeover offers will be inserted into the principal Act. Variations are to be made only with the consent of the National Commission unless the variation is in accordance with the provisions of the relevant section or the regulations.

Finally, Part A and Part C statements will be required to set out the bidder's intentions regarding continuing the target company business, any major changes to be made to that business, and also the future employment of its staff. The Companies (Acquisition of Shares) Amendment Bill has been approved by the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities for introduction into the Commonwealth Parliament. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Securities Industry Amendment Bill 1981

The purpose of the Securities Industry Amendment Bill is to amend the Securities Industry Act 1980 which regulates the securities industry in the Australian Capital Territory. The other jurisdictions that are covered by the formal agreement on companies and securities will pass legislation applying the securities industry code in those other jurisdictions. A detailed explanation of amendments in the Amendment Bill is set out in the explanatory memorandum which has been circulated with the Bill.

Among other things, the principal Act will be amended by the Bill to ensure that the National Companies and Securities Commission can exercise its powers of inspection only for the purposes of the co-operative scheme. The Commission will now be able to require information from a person only if that person is able to provide such information. Where a person takes possession of books under the provisions of the Act, any lien on those books will now be protected. There will now be a defence to a prosecution for offences relating to false or misleading information if the defendant had reasonable grounds to believe that the information was true and not misleading. Proven copies of extracts of books will now be allowable as evidence. There are a number of amendments to the investigation provisions in the principal Act. The National Commission will now have additional powers to obtain information from certain persons in specified circumstances and subject to specified safeguards. Where the record of an examination under the investigation provisions is reduced to writing, the inspector may require the person being examined to sign the record. Copies of the written record will be able to be provided by the National Commission to certain persons and they may be provided subject to conditions imposed by the National Commission. There are also a number of drafting changes made in the amending Bill. This amending Bill will come into operation on the same day on which the principal Act comes into operation.

The Securities Industry Amendment Bill 1980 has been approved by the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities for introduction into the Commonwealth Parliament. I commend this Bill to the Senate.
Companies and Securities (Interpretation and Miscellaneous Provisions) Amendment Bill 1981

The purpose of the Companies and Securities (Interpretation and Miscellaneous Provisions) Amendment Bill is to amend the Companies and Securities (Interpretation and Miscellaneous Provisions) Act which provides for the interpretation of the Commonwealth legislation under the co-operative companies and securities scheme. This Amendment Bill will assist in the uniform interpretation of all of the legislation that is to be administered by the National Companies and Securities Commission. A detailed explanation of the Amendment Bill is contained in the explanatory memorandum which has been circulated with the Bill. Among other things this Bill will amend the definition of formal agreement to take account of amendments to that agreement before the principal Commonwealth Act comes into operation.

The definition of 'statutory declaration' will be omitted as these declarations will not now be required under any of the provisions of any of the substantive codes. The Bill will ensure that the present law relating to the persons in each jurisdiction who are entitled to present indictments remains unaltered. The Bill also indicates which offences should be treated as indictable offences and which offences should be treated as summary offences under the co-operative scheme. Provision is also made in the Bill for recognition to be given for evidentiary purposes to corresponding laws in a State or another Territory.

The Bill will come into operation on the day on which the Companies and Securities (Interpretation and Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1980 comes into operation. The Companies and Securities (Interpretation and Miscellaneous Provisions) Amendment Bill has been approved by the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities for introduction into the Commonwealth Parliament. I commend this Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak only briefly to the Senate on a matter about which I have written to the Treasurer (Mr Howard) but in relation to which I would now like to draw some further information to the attention of the Government. It is the matter of the imposition of sales tax on the cost of the manufacture of sets and properties used in productions of non-profit theatre companies. This matter came to light in October last year and was mentioned in one newspaper article-only one to my knowledge-and has drawn no further comment. Recently I think honourable senators would have received a letter from the Confederation of Australian Professional Performing Arts Ltd on the subject. I am sure a large number of members and senators have made representations to the Treasurer. Since I did so myself a couple of weeks ago there have been additional representations to me in Queensland about the effect of the imposition of this tax on these non-profit companies. It is worth mentioning in passing that the tax is not levied on those non-profit subsidised theatres which are either statutory bodies, such as the Queensland Theatre Company, or attached to universities. So not all theatre companies in this position are so affected.

SPEECH.PARA: The concern that I expressed is one that I am sure many members would share and certainly one which is now exercising the theatre companies. It has fairly lately come to their attention and they are now making representations to members. As I said, since contacting the Treasurer about the matter I have had further contact with people in Queensland about it and a very particular concern has been expressed. In the article I referred to some publicity is given to very large amounts of tax that could be levied on some companies. Advice that I have received from the Australian Taxation Office does not comfort anyone, I am sure, when it is pointed out that the exemption is applicable if sales of taxable goods do not exceed $12,000 a year or the tax payable is less than $250 a year. I give to the Senate the example of the TN Company in Brisbane, which has estimated that that tax would cost it $350 for each of the six annual plays. The professional non-profit theatre companies that I know of can all look forward to paying some of this tax.

Particular concern in Queensland arises out of the fact that Queensland is a State in which the arts are very important. Those senators and members who do not come from Queensland but who have travelled there and who are interested in the arts never cease to comment to me, if I am involved in their trip, just how involved in the arts the citizens of Queensland are and how very much they care about them. They have a very high degree of participation in the arts. Visits by professional companies are therefore regarded as being very important to people living in provincial cities and towns. They will suffer most if subsidised theatre, opera and ballet companies in Queensland are forced to face extra costs. Our companies attempt, as best they can, to meet the cultural needs of the State. But thousands of Queenslanders outside the metropolitan area rarely, and sometimes never, get a chance to see professional performances which I am sure honourable senators would agree are important in the standards of the arts. I include also those performances which are amateur. These people will have even less chance if our non-profit companies have their funds further reduced since theatrical touring is a high cost business, particularly in Queensland.

People living in Brisbane are given a reasonable choice in live entertainment. In far north Queensland there will be an extended choice in more regular theatre soon with the establishment of a subsidised company. However, Queensland is the country's most decentralised State. It is a very large State. We are merely seeing the start in Queensland of a consolidation of the developments in cultural activities. I hope that the Government will do all that it can to assist rather than hinder this development on a Statewide basis. It seems a ridiculous anomaly, as was commented on in the newspaper article that I referred to earlier, that the Commonwealth Government gives money to non-profit companies through the Australia Council and then that money is taken back through the Australian Taxation Office. Already the subsidised companies pay other taxes such as group, payroll and general sales tax on the purchase of equipment. The imposition of sales tax on the manufacture of the companies' own stage sets and properties could have a crippling effect on what are very tight theatre budgets. It must lead, on the information I have been given by these companies, to a reduction in planned activity.

People in the non-profit performing arts in Queensland, and, I understand, nationally, were unaware until late last year that they had to pay this tax. I believe that the tax should be examined by the Government to discover whether it is contrary to the spirit of the Act as pointed out by CAPPA. CAPPA went on to make further requests which could be considered. But I would be sorry to see a situation emerge where the Government, in giving grants to the arts, finds that the benefit of those grants is whittled away through the implementation of a section of the taxation Act which I believe was never meant to have this effect. I want to extend a plea to the Government to take into consideration in reaching a determination on this matter the types of points that I have raised tonight and how very important-in fact in some cases decisively important-it will be for the performance of a number of professional theatre companies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last evening while speaking on the 1979-80 annual report of the Australian National Railways Commission I cited figures from page 8 of the report under the heading 'Statistical Summary: Passenger Operations'. I find on examining Hansard today that I was incorrect in some of the figures I cited. I now wish to set the record straight. In doing so I shall quote from Senate Hansard of 24 February. The incorrect figures appear in column 1 of page 21. I have cited the figures in dollar terms and they should, in fact, read 'Gross tonnes hauled one kilometre'. Where I have stated that ANR had suffered a drop in revenue despite increased fares I now find on reading the report today that there was an increase in revenue, due to the increased fares charged, by 6 per cent from $12m in 1978-79 to $12.7m in 1979-80. This is shown on page 11 of the report. However, page 13 of the report reveals that 9,600 fewer passengers were carried on the Indian Pacific and the Trans Australian, Port Pirie-Kalgoorlie section, during 1979-80 than were carried in 1978-79, with a reduction of 33,900 from 1976-77 to 1979-80.

SPEECH.PARA: The errors I made and have now corrected were due to the fact that I did not have a copy of the report to study in depth in sufficient time prior to its being tabled in the Senate. Mr President, you will recall that on more than one occasion senators have lodged a complaint in the Senate that if those senators who have an interest in any of the reports that are tabled want to speak to them they have to do it in great haste and by looking at the report as they are on their feet. Unfortunately that is where I fell into error last night. I have corrected the error. I hope now I will not have the Commissioner for Railways down on my neck by saying that he had such a massive amount of revenue because I was citing, in the one instance, $1,467m and in fact it was 12.7m and $12m.

Another short comment I wish to make relates to an answer given to Senator Jessop by Senator Baume on the provision of television services to the west coast of Eyre Peninsula. This is a matter which has been aired on many occasions in the Senate. I will not deal with it in depth tonight except to place on record a question for Senator Baume to answer. He may be able to come up with an answer before the Parliament rises tomorrow. I understand that a very important local government meeting is to be held on the west coast next week which I am sure the honourable member for Grey (Mr Wallis) will be attending. The people who attend that meeting from the local government bodies will be interested to know just when television services will be available. Senator Baume in his answer today gave an indication of when they will be available. The people on the west coast will be concerned about the origin of the current affairs programs which that television station will be showing. I am given to understand that these programs will not be South Australian current affairs programs; they will be beamed in from either New South Wales or Western Australia. Many people on the west coast of Eyre Peninsula would have no interest at all in current affairs programs which deal purely with events that take place in New South Wales, Queensland or Western Australia.

I ask Senator Messner who is at the table tonight to relay my question to Senator Baume. He may be able to tell the Senate tomorrow just what the origin of those programs will be so that if the matter comes up for discussion at the local government meeting on the west coast on Monday the people in attandance will be correctly informed as to the types of programs that they will be able to tune into if these television services are in fact made available. As I said, there is a long history of promises about television for the west coast. Today when I was going through my files I came across an editorial in the West Coast Sentinel of Wednesday, 3 September 1980. The editor said: 'What a bore'. He then went on to refer to Senator Jessop's having promised nearly four years ago that television would come to the west coast if the Liberal Government were returned to office. Senator Baume said in the chamber today that television for the west coast is getting a little closer-four years after the promise was made that it would come into being.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise very briefly this evening at this late hour simply to bring to the attention of the Senate the plight of the East Devonport Child Care Centre. This centre fulfils, in a very friendly and constructive way, a very real need in the community centred on east Devonport in north-west Tasmania. It is a centre which, as I say, fulfils a real need as is shown by its constant utilisation. It is always fully booked. It is a child care centre which, like so many throughout Australia, enables many women to contribute to the upkeep of their families. Of course, in the case of a woman without a husband in the household, it allows her, in many instances, to undertake such work that enables her to support totally a family situation. The need for this centre has been recognised throughout the general community around Devonport. This is particularly evidenced by the gathering of some two and a half thousand signatures on a petition over the last few weeks. It is also evidenced by the fact that many community groups such as the Apex organisation, Parents Without Partners, the local council and many other community groups-I have singled out some for particular mention-have indicated their strong support. The question is whether that need, attested by so many people in north-western Tasmania, is equally recognised and would gather support from the Federal Government. In order to continue beyond 18 March the centre needs a recurrent grant.

SPEECH.PARA: We know that whilst such centres rely in large part on a great degree of voluntary support, both from some of the mothers concerned and from community groups such as I have outlined, nevertheless to fulfil the responsibility towards the children concerned professional child care attendants are required. In order to attract people of the proper quality and disposition it is necessary to offer them a salary commensurate with their responsibilities. What this particular centre needs, after several years of operation without any Federal funding, is a recurrent grant in the order of $12,000 per annum to enable such a person to be engaged with the security of tenure involved with the certainty of such a salary being available.

At the invitation of Mrs Jeffries, the public relations officer of that centre, I have visited the home which has been converted. It remains a home in its atmosphere and the construction which has been undertaken in order to enable it to handle some numbers of children has in no way detracted from the friendly and homely atmosphere which I believe is so beneficial to the young children concerned. I draw the attention of the chamber to the fact that a Catch-22 situation is involved in that I believe that special grants, which have been formerly made by way of subsidies for special needs children, have been withdrawn and certainly will not be available in the future because the centre is not federally funded. If that understanding of the situation is correct, it exacerbates the plight in which this centre, amongst many in Australia, finds itself. We have had some replies to Senator McLaren from the Minister concerned, I think on Tuesday, to the effect that the Department is already overcommitted to the tune of some $7m in respect of the funding of child care centres already undertaken, let alone the Department's undertaking any new venture in this direction.

If the centre closes, as it must do on 18 March if such funding is not available, many households will be disrupted and many children's emotional and indeed material development will be retarded. I make a very strong plea to the Minister to use whatever discretionary powers he may have to make such a grant as will enable this much-needed facility in East Devonport to remain open.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I relate my remarks firstly to Senator Martin's remarks in connection with the problems with theatres in Queensland. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 27 November 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Minister for Defence agree that the new American nuclear strategic doctrine makes American bases in Australia nuclear targets.

(2) Does the Minister for Defence agree that Nurrungar, within the Woomera Restricted Area in the north of South Australia, plays a key role in American monitoring of Soviet missile tests, and is thus a potential nuclear target.
(3) What are the functions of this base.

(4) What would be the effects of fallout from a 0.5:1 megaton nuclear strike, either air burst or ground burst on this station, and in particular what is the probability or wind speed and direction being such that nuclear fallout would reach Adelaide in the event of such a nuclear strike.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I assume that the term 'American bases' in fact refers to the joint US/Australian defence facilities. I refer to my answer to Question on Notice No. 6374 (Hansard, 18 September 1980, page 1634). The existing US strategic nuclear doctrine is the result of a progressive evolution of doctrine over more than a decade. It can hardly be described as 'new'. It cannot be discounted that in a nuclear war Australia along with a lot of other countries could come under nuclear attack. But the likelihood of nuclear war is low and the policies of this Government, and those of the governments of the US and other like-minded countries, are directed towards ensuring that nuclear war does not occur at all and that no part of Australia will therefore be subject to nuclear attack. It has been the view of successive Australian governments that the presence of the joint US/Australian defence facilities in Australia is of benefit to Australian and Western security.

(2) and (3) In conformity with the practice of successive Australian Governments, speculation or assertion on the role or functions of the Joint Defence Space Communications Station at Nurrungar will be neither confirmed nor denied. The honourable senator will be aware however that the Leader and Deputy Leader of the Opposition as well as certain members of the Government are briefed on the facility.
(4) The effects of fallout in the immediate area of a nuclear explosion would not be significant when compared with the effects of blast and heat that would precede it.

In the case of an air burst of an 0.5 to 1.0 megaton nuclear weapon over Nurrungar a small quantity of fission products would be carried into the upper atmosphere generally in an easterly direction and would slowly deposit over the whole area covered by the middle latitudes of the southern hemisphere.

In the case of a ground burst of such a weapon at Nurrungar a small quantity of fission products might similarly be carried into the upper atmosphere. Most of the fallout, however, would be distributed in an area up to about 100 miles from the burst point.
Data available to the Department of Defence indicates that the chance of a fallout cloud passing over Adelaide in the event hypothesised by the honourable senator, is about one half of one per cent.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 2 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: Are Federal Police empowered to confiscate patients' medical records when undertaking an investigation into possible fraud against the Department of Health; if so: (a) what guidelines are followed by the Federal Police in the confiscation of such private medical records; and (b) does this practice conflict with the accepted classification of medical files as private and confidential.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I am informed that the Australian Federal Police are not empowered to confiscate medical records; but by virtue of a search warrant issued vide Section 10 of the Crimes Act 1914, they are empowered to seize records which may be of evidentiary value relating to the commission of an offence. Documents of evidentiary value are maintained in police custody until the conclusion of any subsequent court hearing.

(a) and (b) I am informed that in view of the confidential nature of the doctor/patient relationship, the following specific instructions relating to seized medical records have been issued to all members of the Force:
(1) All records seized are to be marked and entered as an exhibit and stored in safe storage.

(2) All records will be photocopied, the photocopies being given to the doctor concerned as soon as possible. If, before the supply of photocopies, a doctor urgently needed records for patient treatment, every effort is to be made to respond to the need by supplying photocopies of the required records.

(3) A patient whose medical record has been seized may wish to seek information as to why his/her record was seized. A request for this information is to be directed through the Commissioner's office.
(4) All original records are to be kept in lockable cabinets.
(5) Keys to cabinets holding the records are to be restricted to no more than two persons.
(6) Records which are no longer required are to be returned to the doctor as soon as possible.
(7) The contents of all records are to be treated with the utmost confidentiality.
(8) Any movement of the records is to be recorded.
(9) A member or other person is to sign for records given into his/her possession.
The President of the AMA has seen the above instructions and has expressed his agreement with them.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 4 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the present guidelines for Commonwealth medical officers in determining 85 per cent permanent incapacity in an invalid pension claim.
(2) How do the guidelines differ from the guidelines applied by the Department of Veterans' Affairs in determining total and permanent incapacity.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourble senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The present guidelines require Commonwealth medical officers (CMOs) to assess whether or not a claimant for invalid pension is permanently incapacitated for work to the extent of not less than 85 per cent as provided for in the Social Services Act 1947. This assessment is based primarily on medical/clinical considerations of the disabilities, severity and degree of permanent incapacity. Broadly, the assessment of a person's capacity (or incapacity) for work involves an evaluation by the CMO of the person's present and future capacity to engage in any field of employment which might be considered suitable for the person to undertake. In addition to assessing the person's degree of medical impairment, such factors as age, sex and education are relevant in assessing the degree of incapacity for work. An incapacity is regarded as 'permanent' if no fundamental or marked change can reasonably be expected in the future.

(2) Total and permanent incapacity is the degree of incapacity specified in the Repatriation legislation for the payment of disability pension at the Special (T & PI) Rate. A Repatriation disability pension is a compensatory payment payable for a Service-related incapacity and the Special Rate of $122.75 per week is the maximum rate of this pension.

Schedule 2 of the Repatriation Act 1920 provides for the Special (T & PI) Rate disability pension to be paid to a veteran who is totally and permanently incapacitated. A veteran is regarded as totally and permanently incapacitated if he is, because of service-related incapacity, incapacitated for life to such an extent as to be precluded from earning other than a negligible percentage of a living wage. The determination of whether a person is totally and permanently incapacitated is made by the respective independent determining authorities established under the Repatriation Act.

The disability pension is not comparable to the invalid pension because, during assessment, only incapacity from Service-related disabilities is taken into account. A more suitable parallel would be the Service pension which is payable for permanent unemployability by the Department of Veterans' Affairs. The Repatriation service pension is a social-welfare type payment similar to the invalid pension. It was introduced for those veterans who served in a theatre of war and who are permanently unemployable. It is payable at the same rate as an invalid pension and incapacity from both Service and non-service-related disabilities is taken into account.

Permanently unemployable, as applied to the Service pension, is defined in section 23 of the Repatriation Act as meaning permanently incapable, by reason of physical or mental disablement, of being employed in a remunerative occupation in which, in the opinion of the Repatriation Commission, he can reasonably be expected to obtain regular employment.
The Commission's interpretation of the term is that a veteran will be deemed to be permanently unemployable for Service pension purposes if, by reason of:
(a) physical or mental incapacity from all disabilities or,
(b) physical or mental incapacity coupled with any limitations imposed by his age or unsuitability for training, or the unavailability of suitable work locally,
he will for the foreseeable future (and probably permanently) be unable to retain remunerative employment of a kind for which he is fitted.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 3 December 1980 (Hansard, page 268) Senator Walters asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce the following question, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Does the Government support the expansion of the electronics industry in Australia? If so, does the Minister agree that the continued importation, duty-free, of components such as integrated circuits, thick film hydrant circuits, semi-conductors and even copper and aluminium wire by Commonwealth departments, corporations and commissions undermines the expansion of the local industry?
The Minister for Industry and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Government's industry policy is directed towards and supportive of the development of an industry structure, including the electronics industry, which has a greater degree of specialisation, is more internationally competitive and export oriented, and is less reliant on Government assistance.
The Government's purchasing policy is to give preference to goods of Australian origin, or of relatively greater Australian content, unless there are substantial reasons to the contrary.
Under this policy Departments and authorities are also required to ensure that tender specifications are not drawn up to exclude Australian products suitable or reasonably adaptable to their needs.
To assist Australian industry a preference margin of 20 per cent of the value of the Australian content is applied when considering competitive tenders.

In evaluating competitive quotations and tenders local products are compared with imported goods on a duty paid basis even though they can be imported duty free for use by the Commonwealth. This ensures that Australian producers receive the same protection against competition from imports in Government purchasing as they would in commercial transactions. The level of assistance against import competition provided for most electronics industry products produced in Australia is higher than that accorded manufacturing industry generally.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 December 1980 (Hansard, page 434) Senator Archer asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: At a recent symposium on small business held in Melbourne attention was drawn to the fact that much of the failure in small business had to be attributed to the fundamental lack of teaching at primary, secondary and tertiary levels, Professor Meredith stated:

'In Australia, innumerable Government departments, agencies, tertiary institutions and private organisations are associated with education and training programs for small enterprises without any visible co-ordination or national plan.'

Can the Minister have the Minister for Education institute an examination of this matter at ministerial council level and have a special curriculum committee set up to prepare appropriate courses for use throughout Australia?
The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The problems of small business management in particular the need for adequate training, have been considered in the survey, 'Small Business Education and Training in Australia', which was commissioned by the National Training Council in late 1979.
A summary report on the survey (the Bailey Report) was released by the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs on 11 January 1981.

The report is to be widely distributed with copies being sent to all State Small Business Agencies, all respondents to the Survey, all universities, colleges of advanced education and TAFE institutions, and to accounting firms. It is available for purchase also, from the Australian Government Publishing Service Bookshops.

Within the advanced educational and technical and further education sectors, a wide range of courses is available for people who operate or are planning to commence small businesses. However, in the Bailey Report it was concluded that:
'a large majority of small business owner/managers in Australia are not oriented toward involvement in traditional education and training programs'.

The survey suggests that people who operate small businesses prefer training and advice which is tailored to their own particular circumstances. Hence nationally co-ordinated curricula, whilst of possible application as part of a general education, are likely to lack the flexibility and applicability needed to be of benefit in the wide range of business ventures which must be considered.

The Government has established an Inquiry into Management Education which, inter alia, is examining the special needs of small business for management education. The inquiry will consider the roles of universities, colleges of advanced education and technical and further education institutions. The Chairman of the Inquiry delivered the keynote address at the International Symposium on Small Business to which you referred in your question.
The Report of the Inquiry is expected to be available by the end of this year and will contain recommendations on ways to improve the availability and effectiveness of education for small business.
